revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2016}} {{good article}} {{Infobox film | name = Chimes at Midnight | image = Falstaff-1967-Poster.jpg | caption = U.S. theatrical release poster | director = [[Orson Welles]] | producer = {{ubl | Ángel Escolano | [[Emiliano Piedra]] | [[Harry Saltzman]] | Alessandro Tasca di Cuto }} | based on = {{ubl | [[Falstaff]]
by [[William Shakespeare]] |''[[Holinshed's Chronicles]]''
by [[Raphael Holinshed]] }} | screenplay = Orson Welles | narrator = [[Ralph Richardson]] | starring = {{ubl | Orson Welles | [[Keith Baxter (actor)|Keith Baxter]] | [[Margaret Rutherford]] | [[John Gielgud]] | [[Jeanne Moreau]] | [[Norman Rodway]] | [[Marina Vlady]] | [[Fernando Rey]] }} | music = [[Angelo Francesco Lavagnino]] | cinematography=[[Edmond Richard (cinematographer)|Edmond Richard]] | editing = Fritz Muller | studio = Internacional Films Esrolano | distributor = Peppercorn-Wormser Film Enterprises | released = {{Film date|1965|12|22|Spain|1966|5|8|France|1967|3|17|USA}} | runtime = 119 minutes | country = Spain
Switzerland | language = English | budget = $800,000 |gross = 516,762 admissions (France)[http://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?depth=1&hl=en&prev=search&rurl=translate.google.com.au&sl=fr&u=http://www.boxofficestory.com/box-office-orson-welles-c25320542&usg=ALkJrhhxH2PrC9aZtsMZPjsNZBUe3iaBhw Orson Welles box office information in France] at Box Office Story }} '''''Chimes at Midnight''''' (onscreen titlehttp://imgur.com/a/URsRh and UK title: '''''Falstaff (Chimes at Midnight)''''', Spanish release: '''''Campanadas a medianoche'''''), is a 1965 English-language Spanish-Swiss{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=290}} [[Historical period drama|period]] [[comedy-drama]] film directed by and starring [[Orson Welles]]. The film's plot centres on [[William Shakespeare]]'s recurring character [[Falstaff|Sir John Falstaff]] and the father-son relationship he has with [[Henry V of England|Prince Hal]], who must choose between loyalty to his father, [[Henry IV of England|King Henry IV]], or Falstaff. Welles said that the core of the film's story was "the betrayal of friendship." It stars Welles as Falstaff, [[Keith Baxter (actor)|Keith Baxter]] as [[Prince Hal]], [[John Gielgud]] as [[Henry IV of England|Henry IV]], [[Jeanne Moreau]] as [[Doll Tearsheet]] and [[Margaret Rutherford]] as [[Mistress Quickly]]. The script contains text from five of Shakespeare's plays; primarily ''[[Henry IV, Part 1]]'' and ''[[Henry IV, Part 2]]'', but also ''[[Richard II (play)|Richard II]]'' and ''[[Henry V (play)|Henry V]]'', as well as some dialogue from ''[[The Merry Wives of Windsor]]''. [[Ralph Richardson]]'s narration is taken from the works of chronicler [[Raphael Holinshed]]. Welles had previously produced a Broadway stage adaptation of nine Shakespeare plays called ''Five Kings'' in 1939. In 1960, he revived this project in Ireland as ''Chimes at Midnight'', which was his final on-stage performance. Neither of these plays were successful, but Welles considered portraying Falstaff to be his life's ambition and turned the project into a film. In order to get initial financing, Welles lied to producer [[Emiliano Piedra]] about intending to make a version of ''[[Treasure Island]]'', and keeping the film funded during its production was a constant struggle. Welles shot ''Chimes at Midnight'' throughout Spain between 1964 and 1965; it premiered at the [[1966 Cannes Film Festival]], winning two awards there. Initially dismissed by most film critics, ''Chimes at Midnight'' is now regarded as one of Welles' highest achievements, and Welles himself called it his best work. Welles felt a strong connection to the character of Falstaff and called him "Shakespeare's greatest creation". Some film scholars and Welles' collaborators have made comparisons between Falstaff and Welles, while others see a resemblance between Falstaff and Welles' father. Disputes over the ownership of ''Chimes at Midnight'' made it difficult to view the film legally until recently. It was released in the UK on DVD and Blu-ray in 2015. A new restoration by [[Janus Films]] and [[The Criterion Collection]] was screened at the [[Film Forum]] in New York January 1–12, 2016. The Criterion Collection released the film on Blu-ray and DVD on August 30, 2016.{{Cite web|url=https://www.criterion.com/films/28756-chimes-at-midnight|title=Chimes at Midnight|website=The Criterion Collection|access-date=May 17, 2016}} == Plot == The film opens with Sir John Falstaff and Justice Shallow walking through the snow, then to a warm fire inside the Boar's Head Tavern, as the two reminisce. After a main credit sequence, the narrator explains that King [[Henry IV of England]] has succeeded [[Richard II of England|Richard II]], whom he has killed. Richard II's true heir, [[Edmund Mortimer, son of the 3rd Earl|Edmund Mortimer]], is a prisoner in Wales, and Mortimer's cousins Northumberland, Worcester, and Northumberland's son Hotspur demand that Henry rescue Mortimer. The king refuses, and thus Mortimer's cousins begin to plot Henry's overthrow. To Henry's great dissatisfaction, his son Prince Hal spends most of his time at the Boar's Head Tavern, drinking and carousing with prostitutes, thieves and other criminals under John Falstaff's patriarchal influence. Falstaff insists that he and Hal should think of themselves as gentlemen, but Hal warns Falstaff that he will one day reject both this lifestyle and Falstaff. The next morning Hal, Falstaff, Bardolph, Peto, and Poins disguise themselves in Gadshill to prepare to rob a group of traveling pilgrims. After Falstaff, Bardolph, and Peto rob the pilgrims, Hal and Poins jump out in disguises and take the stolen treasure from Falstaff as a joke. Back at the Boar's Head Tavern, Falstaff begins to tell Hal and Poins with increasing exaggeration the story of how the money was stolen from him. Hal and Poins poke holes in Falstaff's tale until they reveal their joke to the entire group. In celebration of the newly recovered stolen treasure, Falstaff and Hal take turns impersonating Henry, with a cooking pot crown and vocal impressions. Falstaff's Henry chastises Hal for spending his time with common criminals, but names Sir John Falstaff as his one virtuous friend. Hal's Henry calls Falstaff a "misleader of youth". Hal visits the King at the castle and Henry scolds him for his criminal and unethical life-style. Henry warns Hal about Hotspur's growing army and its threat to his crown. Hal passionately vows to his unimpressed father that he will defend Henry and redeem his good name. The King's army, including Falstaff, parades through the streets and off to war. Before the battle, Henry meets with Worcester and offers to forgive all of Hotspur's men of treason if they surrender immediately. Hal vows to personally kill Hotspur. Worcester returns to his camp and lies to Hotspur, telling him that Henry intends to execute all traitors. The two armies meet in the [[Battle of Shrewsbury]], but Falstaff hides in shrubs for most of the conflict. After a long and bloody fight, the King's men win the battle, after which Hotspur and Hal meet alone and duel; as Falstaff watches, Hal kills Hotspur. Henry sentences Worcester to death and takes his men as prisoners. Falstaff brings Hotspur's body to Henry, claiming that he killed Hotspur; Henry does not believe Falstaff, instead looking disapprovingly at Hal and the ignoble company he keeps. {{quote box|bgcolor=#CCDDFF|align=right|width=18%|quote="I know thee not, old man: fall to thy prayers;
How ill white hairs become a fool and jester!
I have long dream'd of such a kind of man,
So surfeit-swell'd, so old and so profane;
But, being awaked, I do despise my dream."
— ''Henry IV, Part 2'', Act 5, Scene 5}} The narrator explains that all of Henry IV's rebellious enemies had been killed by 1408, but that Henry's health has begun to deteriorate. At the castle, Henry becomes upset when told that Hal is once again spending time with Falstaff, and collapses. Hal visits the castle and discovers that Henry is sicker than he had realized. Hal vows to Henry to be a good and noble king. Henry finally has faith in Hal and advises him on how to be a king. Henry dies and Hal tells his men that he is now King Henry V. Falstaff, Shallow and Silence sit in front of a warm fire, continuing from the first scene of the film. They receive news of Henry IV's death and that Hal's coronation will be held that morning. Falstaff becomes ecstatic and goes directly to the castle, thinking that he will become a great and powerful nobleman under King Henry V. At the coronation, Falstaff cannot contain his excitement and interrupts the entire ceremony, announcing himself to Hal. Hal turns his back on Falstaff and proclaims that he is now finished with his former lifestyle. As Falstaff looks up at Hal with a mixture of pride and despair, the new king banishes Falstaff. The coronation continues into the castle as Falstaff walks away, stating that he will be sent for that evening. That night, Falstaff dies at the Boar's Head Tavern, and his friends mourn him, saying that he died of a broken heart. The narrator explains that Hal went on to become a good and noble king.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=31–254}} == Cast == *[[Orson Welles]] as [[Sir John Falstaff]], a knight and father-figure to Prince Hal *[[Keith Baxter (actor)|Keith Baxter]] as [[Henry V, King of England|Prince Hal]], the Prince of Wales and the heir to the throne of England *[[John Gielgud]] as [[Henry IV of England|King Henry IV]], the King of England *[[Margaret Rutherford]] as [[Mistress Quickly]], hostess of the Boar's Head Tavern *[[Jeanne Moreau]] as [[Doll Tearsheet]], a prostitute *[[Alan Webb (actor)|Alan Webb]] as [[Justice Shallow]], a country justice and old friend of Falstaff *[[Walter Chiari]] as Justice Silence, a country justice *[[Michael Aldridge]] as [[Ancient Pistol|Pistol]], a friend of Falstaff *[[Tony Beckley]] as [[Ned Poins]], a friend of Falstaff and Hal *[[Patrick Bedford]] as [[Bardolph (Shakespeare character)|Bardolph]], a friend of Falstaff and Hal *[[José Nieto (actor)|José Nieto]] as [[Henry Percy, 1st Earl of Northumberland|Earl of Northumberland]], an Earl in rebellion against the King, and cousin of Edmund Mortimer *[[Fernando Rey]] as [[Thomas Percy, 1st Earl of Worcester|Earl of Worcester]], Northumberland's brother, and cousin of Edmund Mortimer *[[Norman Rodway]] as [[Henry Percy (Hotspur)|Henry Percy, called Hotspur]], Northumberland's son, and second cousin of Edmund Mortimer *[[Marina Vlady]] as [[Elizabeth Mortimer|Kate Percy]], Hotspur's wife *[[Andrew Faulds]] as [[Ralph de Neville, 1st Earl of Westmorland|Earl of Westmorland]], an Earl loyal to the King *Jeremy Rowe as [[John of Lancaster, 1st Duke of Bedford|Prince John]], Henry IV's second son *[[Beatrice Welles]] as Falstaff's Page, a servant (Also played by Bruno Yasoni after Beatrice could not finish filming) *[[Charles Farrell (Irish actor)|Charles Farrell]] *Fernando Hilbeck *Andrés Mejuto *Julio Peña *[[Keith Pyott]] *[[Ralph Richardson]] as The Narrator (voice) *[[Ingrid Pitt]] as Courtesan (uncredited) == Original stage productions == Welles' inspiration for ''Chimes at Midnight'' began in 1930 when he was a student at the [[Todd Seminary for Boys|Todd School for Boys]] in [[Woodstock, Illinois]]. Welles tried to stage a three-and-a-half-hour combination of several of Shakespeare's historical plays called ''The Winter of Our Discontent'' in which he played Richard III.France, Richard. ''The Theatre of Orson Welles''. Lewisberg and London: Bucknell University Press. 1977. {{ISBN|0838719724}}. pp. 24-26. School officials forced him to make cuts to the production.{{sfn|Leaming|1985|pp=35–36}} ''Chimes at Midnight'' originated in 1939 as a stage play called ''Five Kings'', which Welles wrote and partially staged. It was an ambitious adaptation of several Shakespeare plays that chronicled the stories of [[Richard II of England|Richard II]], [[Henry IV of England|Henry IV]], [[Henry V of England|Henry V]], [[Henry VI of England|Henry VI]] and [[Richard III of England|Richard III]]. Its sources were ''[[Richard II (play)|Richard II]]'', ''[[Henry IV, Part 1]]'', ''[[Henry IV, Part 2]]'', ''[[Henry V (play)|Henry V]]'', ''[[The Merry Wives of Windsor]]'', ''[[Henry VI, Part 1]]'', ''[[Henry VI, Part 2]]'', ''[[Henry VI, Part 3]]'' and ''[[Richard III (play)|Richard III]]''{{mdash}}sometimes collectively called the "[[The War of the Roses (Shakespeare)#The .22Wars of the Roses.22 cycle|War of the Roses cycle]]".{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=3–4}} The grouping of ''Henry IV, Part 1'', ''Henry IV, Part 2'' and ''Henry V'' are often referred to as the ''[[Henriad]]''.{{sfn|Anderegg|1999|pp=124}} === ''Five Kings'' (1939) === ''Five Kings'' was announced as part of the newly revived [[Mercury Theatre]]'s second season in 1938.{{sfn|Callow|1996|pp=358}} [[John Houseman]] had secured a partnership with the prestigious [[Theatre Guild]] to produce the play for {{US$|40,000}}, with an initial tour of Baltimore, Boston, Washington D.C. and Philadelphia before debuting on Broadway.{{sfn|Callow|1996|pp=423}} Welles' intended to stage only the first part of the play{{mdash}}which was primarily taken from ''Henry IV Parts 1 and 2'' and ''Henry V''{{mdash}}during the tour while simultaneously rehearsing Part Two and finally debuting the full production on Broadway.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=3–4}}{{sfn|Leaming|1985|pp=448}}{{sfn|Callow|1996|pp=424}} Houseman stated that the play's aim was "to combine the immediate quality of the Elizabethan with all the devices and techniques possible in the modern theatre."{{sfn|Anderegg|1999|pp=29}} The cast included Welles as Falstaff, [[Burgess Meredith]] as Prince Hal, [[John Emery (actor)|John Emery]] as Hotspur, Morris Ankrum as Henry IV and [[Robert Speaight]] as the Narrator.{{sfn|Callow|1996|pp=427–428}}{{sfn|Welles|Bogdanovich|1992|pp=350}}France, Richard. ''Orson Welles on Shakespeare''. New York/London: Routledge. 2001. {{ISBN|0-415-93726-4}}. pp. 174-175. The play's music was composed by [[Aaron Copland]].{{sfn|Thomson|1996|pp=115}} Welles commissioned an elaborate revolving set to be built, but it was not completed during the five weeks allotted to rehearsals. Welles avoided attending the rehearsals or finishing the play's final script and instead often went out drinking and socializing with co-star Meredith, with the result that only specific scenes or fragments of the play were ever rehearsed.{{sfn|Callow|1996|pp=428–430}} The Baltimore performance was eventually dropped and at the first dress rehearsal in Boston, it was discovered that the play was over five and a half hours long and contained 46 scenes. Welles cut 14 scenes and shortened others, which caused the built-in timer for the revolving set to move out of synchronization.{{sfn|Callow|1996|pp=432}} ''Five Kings, Part 1'' premiered at the [[Colonial Theatre (Boston, Massachusetts)|Colonial Theatre]] in Boston on February 27, 1939, and was a disaster.{{sfn|Callow|1996|pp=433–434}} Critics were either scathing or apologetic, and only the play's battle scenes received praise.{{sfn|Callow|1996|pp=440}} By the end of the Boston run, the Theatre Guild was on the verge of dropping the production, and canceled the D.C. engagement. Welles then edited the show to three and a half hours.{{sfn|Callow|1996|pp=434}} The play closed after only a few performances in Philadelphia, and the Theatre Guild terminated its contract with the Mercury Theater.{{sfn|Callow|1996|pp=438–439}} Photographs of the play's rehearsals show similarities to ''Chimes at Midnight'', including the Boar's Head Tavern set and the character blocking of the "chimes at midnight" scene with Falstaff, Shallow and Silence.{{sfn|Anderegg|1999|pp=139}} === ''Chimes at Midnight'' (1960) === Welles returned to the project in 1960, with performances in [[Belfast]] and [[Dublin]]. This version, now retitled ''Chimes at Midnight'',{{sfn|Callow|1996|pp=443}} was produced by Welles' old friend [[Hilton Edwards]] through his Dublin-based company [[Gate Theatre]].{{sfn|Leaming|1985|pp=448}} The cast included Welles as Falstaff, [[Keith Baxter (actor)|Keith Baxter]] as Prince Hal, Hilton Edwards as the Narrator,{{sfn|Thomson|1996|pp=364}} Reginald Jarman as Henry IV{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=268}} and [[Alexis Kanner]] as Hotspur.{{cite web|url = http://www.wellesnet.com/?cat=16 |title = From THE TRINITY NEWS (a Dublin University Weekly) |accessdate = June 10, 2012 |work = http://www.wellesnet.com, March 10, 1960}} At one point, Welles and Edwards wanted [[Micheál Mac Liammóir]] to replace Jarman as Henry IV, but Mac Liammóir would only accept the role of Prince Hal.{{sfn|Lindsay-Hogg|2011|pp=68}} Hilton Edwards was officially credited as director, but Welles is usually acknowledged as the actual director and was often the director throughout rehearsals.{{cite web|url = http://www.wellesnet.com/?cat=16 |title = "I have heard the CHIMES AT MIDNIGHT" Orson Welles plays Falstaff in his final theatrical performance on the Dublin stage in 1960 |accessdate = June 11, 2012 |work = http://www.wellesnet.com, November 25, 2011}} {{sfn|Lindsay-Hogg|2011|pp=64–65}} Welles' alleged biological son [[Michael Lindsay-Hogg]] also worked on the play as an actor and as Edwards's personal assistant.{{sfn|Lindsay-Hogg|2011|pp=63}} Welles' opinion of Falstaff had intensified since first playing the part, and his new version of the play focused more upon the relationship between Falstaff and Prince Hal than on the historical story of Hal's defeat of Hotspur.{{sfn|Callow|1996|pp=441–442}} Most of the scenes from ''Henry V'' used in the first version before were removed.{{sfn|Leaming|1985|pp=448}} Welles intended to perform the play in Belfast, Dublin and [[London]] before filming it in Yugoslavia.{{sfn|Leaming|1985|pp=448}} Rehearsals began in Russell Square, London, with a read-through. After a week of rehearsing, Welles left to secure further funding and Edwards directed the play, working on blocking and lighting. Welles returned two days before the premiere and the cast had their first dress rehearsal, which lasted until 3 a.m.{{sfn|Lindsay-Hogg|2011|pp=63–66}} After premiering at the Grand Opera House in Belfast on February 13, 1960, and receiving a good review from a ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' correspondent, the play closed after five performances because of low attendances. It moved to the Gaiety Theatre in Dublin, where it fared no better. By the end of the second week, Welles had resorted to reading portions of the works of Irish author [[J. M. Synge]], and from ''[[Riders to the Sea]]'', to attract an audience.{{sfn|Leaming|1985|pp=448}} Eventually the play simply became a version of ''An Evening with Orson Welles'', which would often include a question and answer section with the audience and Welles' solo performance of ''[[Moby Dick—Rehearsed]]'' or the works of [[Isak Dinesen]].{{sfn|Lindsay-Hogg|2011|pp=75}} Welles continued to adjust the play throughout its short production, and at one point moved Mistress Quickly's speech about Falstaff's death to the very beginning of the play.Hapgood, Robert & Beja, Morris (editor). ''Perspectives on Orson Welles''. New York: G. K. Hall & Company. 1995. {{ISBN|0-8161-7344-3}}. pp. 197. Welles finally abandoned the entire project in late March 1960, when his friend [[Laurence Olivier]] offered him the chance to direct him in [[Eugène Ionesco]]'s play ''[[Rhinoceros (play)|Rhinoceros]]'' on London's West End.{{sfn|Welles|Bogdanovich|1992|pp=427}} According to Keith Baxter, Welles ended the play's run because he was bored with it, and at one point told Baxter "This is only a rehearsal for the movie, Keith, and I'll never make it unless you play Hal in that too." Five years later, Baxter and Welles' youngest daughter, [[Beatrice Welles]], who played Falstaff's page, were the only cast members from the play to appear in the film.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=268}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.wellesnet.com/beatrice-welles-to-introduce-restored-chimes-at-midnight-at-film-forum/|title=Beatrice Welles to introduce restored ‘Chimes at Midnight’ at Film...|last=wellesnet|date=December 31, 2015|language=en-US|access-date=August 5, 2016}} ''Chimes at Midnight'' was Welles' final performance in a theatrical play. == Production == === Preproduction === In 1964, Welles met and befriended Spanish film producer [[Emiliano Piedra]], who wanted to work with him. Piedra did not think a Shakespearian film was marketable enough and proposed that Welles make a version of ''[[Treasure Island]]'' instead. Welles agreed to this on condition that he could simultaneously make ''Chimes at Midnight'', and Piedra agreed not knowing that Welles had no intention of making ''Treasure Island''. Although some B-roll footage of the Alicante departing from port was shot early in the production, no scenes from ''Treasure Island'' were ever shot or even scripted. Welles got away with this trick throughout preproduction by building sets that could be used in both films, such as Mistress Quickly's Boar's Head Tavern, which would double as the Admiral Benbow Inn. Welles also cast each actor in both films, casting himself as Long John Silver, Baxter as Dr. Livesey, Beckley as Israel Hands and Gielgud as Squire Trelawney.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=267}} Ironically Welles would eventually play Long John Silver in the unrelated [[Treasure Island (1972 live-action film)|1972 film version]] of ''Treasure Island''.{{sfn|Welles|Bogdanovich|1992|pp=249}} Welles said that the Boar's Head Tavern was the only full set built for the film, and the other sets were simply dressed or decorated on location. Welles stated that he designed, painted and blow-torched the set, and designed all of the film's costumes.{{sfn|Welles|Bogdanovich|1992|pp=249}} Early in pre-production Welles was approached by [[Anthony Perkins]] to play Prince Hal, but Welles had already promised the role to Keith Baxter.{{sfn|Thomson|1996|pp=380}}{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=274}} Hilton Edwards was initially cast as Justice Silence, but was replaced after he became ill.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=277}} The title ''Chimes at Midnight'' derives from ''Henry IV, Part 2'', where in response to Justice Shallow's reminiscing of their long-past school days, Falstaff states: "We have heard the chimes at midnight, Master Shallow".{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=32}} Welles scholar Bridget Gellert Lyons said that the film's title, "which is given further resonance by the repeated intoning of bells throughout the film, is associated for the audience with sadness and mortality more than youthful carousal."{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=5}} === Filming === [[File:Orson-Welles-Falstaff.jpg|thumb|right|260px|[[Orson Welles]] in ''Chimes at Midnight'']] The film was shot in Spain from September 1964 until April 1965, with a break in filming from late December until late February.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=30}} Welles' limitations on the film included a budget of $800,000 and actors [[Jeanne Moreau]] and [[John Gielgud]] being available for five and ten days respectively,{{sfn|Leaming|1985|pp=461}} while [[Margaret Rutherford]] was only available for four weeks.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=276}} Welles later joked that during one scene which included seven principal characters, none of the actors were available and stand-ins were used for over-the-shoulder shots of all seven characters.{{sfn|Welles|Bogdanovich|1992|pp=249}} Filming began in [[Colmenar, Málaga|Colmenar]] and included all of John Gielgud's scenes. Welles then traveled to [[Cardona, Spain|Cardona]], where the Royal Court scenes and Marina Vlady's scenes were shot, and to Madrid's [[Casa de Campo]] Park, where the Gadshill robbery scene was filmed. Madrid was also the location of the Boar's Head Tavern set, where Welles shot Moreau's and Rutherford's scenes. The production then traveled to [[Pedraza, Spain|Pedraza]] for some outdoor street scenes, and then to [[Soria]] to shoot in the snow for the opening shots. After shooting some scenes with Justice Shallow and Justice Silence in the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque country]], Welles returned to Madrid in December to film the battle scenes in Casa de Campo Park for ten days.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=281–282}}{{sfn|Welles|Bogdanovich|1992|pp=254}} By late December, Welles had run out of money and the film was put on hold while he searched for additional funding.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=273}} However, some small scenes were shot during the break. Welles later said that he had rejected offers for funding that were conditional upon filming in color.{{sfn|Welles|Bogdanovich|1992|pp=250}} Welles eventually secured funding from [[Harry Saltzman]]{{cite web|url = http://www.wellesnet.com/?p=667#more-667 |title = BLACK AND MIDNIGHT HAGGLES |accessdate = June 11, 2012 |work = http://www.wellesnet.com, October 2, 2003}} and production officially resumed in late February with most of Keith Baxter's longer speeches and the Coronation scene in Madrid. Between March and April, Welles finished the film with filler shots, close-ups, the final rejection scene and most of Falstaff's speeches. According to Keith Baxter, Welles had stage fright and delayed all of his scenes until the very end of filming, except for scenes that included other actors.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=282}} Welles was timid about shooting his love scene with Moreau, and used a double whenever possible.{{sfn|Thomson|1996|pp=378}} Other filming locations included the Chateau [[Calatañazor]], Puerta de San Vincente, the Soria Cathedral{{sfn|Welles|Bogdanovich|1992|pp=432}} and the city of [[Ávila, Spain|Ávila]].{{Cite journal|url=https://www.kansascity.com/entertainment/movies-news-reviews/article76983377.html|date=12 May 2016|journal=[[The Kansas City Star]]|first=Robert W.|last=Butler|title=‘Chimes at Midnight’ rings true to the great Orson Welles}} Welles was harsh with his crew members and according to actor Andrew Faulds, "he spoke in five different languages to them and was pretty offensive{{mdash}}very demanding. I suppose he'd worked out that if you bullied actors, you didn't get the best from them whereas, to hell with the technicians. They had to do as they were told, and pretty quick."{{sfn|Howard|1991|p=166}} A scene depicting the assassination of [[King Richard II]], originally intended to open the film, was cut.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=264}} === Post-production === Keith Baxter said that the film's soundtrack was [[Dubbing (filmmaking)|post-dubbed]] months after filming was completed, and that actors [[Fernando Rey]] and [[Marina Vlady]] were dubbed by different actors because of their heavy accents. Baxter also stated that he, Welles and [[Michael Aldridge]] recorded voices for several characters in post-production.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=278}} Mistress Quickly's speech after Falstaff's death, which was disrupted by the audible hum of a power generator, used the original version of the soundtrack because Welles liked Margaret Rutherford's performance enough to keep it.{{sfn|Leaming|1985|pp=462}} The score was composed by [[Angelo Francesco Lavagnino]], who had worked with Welles on ''[[Othello (1952 film)|Othello]]''. The score was recorded in an Italian studio, which paid Lavagnino for his work on the film in exchange for the rights to the music, and later released a soundtrack album in Italy and the UK.{{cite web|url = http://www.wellesnet.com/?cat=16&paged=2 |title = Angelo Francesco Lavagnino’s magnificent score for Orson Welles’s CHIMES AT MIDNIGHT |accessdate = June 11, 2012 |work = http://www.wellesnet.com, May 24th, 2009}} During the editing, Welles showed a [[rough cut]] to the visiting head of the [[Cannes Film Festival]], who immediately wanted to include the film in the festival, and Welles had to finish the editing more quickly than he preferred.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=282}} == Style == === Cinematography === Welles had originally wanted the entire film to use high-contrast cinematography, resembling engravings of the Middle Ages; only the opening title sequence uses this technique.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=260}} The film's most famous sequence is the Battle of Shrewsbury; only about 180 extras were available and Welles used editing techniques to give the appearance of armies of thousands.{{sfn|Thomson|1996|pp=378}} Welles filmed all of the battle scenes in long takes, but cut the shots into fragments to create the effect that he wanted.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=264}} It took ten days to shoot the scenes and six weeks to edit what became a six-minute sequence.{{sfn|Welles|Bogdanovich|1992|pp=254}} In filming the sequence, Welles often used hand-held cameras, wide-angle lenses, slow motion and speed up shots, static shots, swish pans and constant rapid movement of the characters to create a kinetic and chaotic atmosphere. Anderegg has said that "in the end, both armies have become one huge, awkward, disintegrating war machine, a grotesque robot whose power source slowly begins to fail and finally comes to a frozen halt. Verbal rhetoric—language itself—seems, for the moment, both irrelevant and obscene."{{sfn|Anderegg|1999|pp=132}} The Battle of Shrewsbury sequence has often been called an anti-war statement by film critics and likened to contemporary films like ''[[Dr. Strangelove]]'' and ''[[Culloden (film)|Culloden]]''. Shakespearean scholar [[Daniel Seltzer]] said that "the social consciousness of the movie is as alert as Shakespeare's, and thematically pertinent in Shakespearean terms too ... the footage of the Battle of Shrewsbury itself must be some of the finest, truest, ugliest scenes of warfare ever shot and edited for a movie."{{sfn|Anderegg|1999|pp=132}} Welles scholar [[James Naremore]] said that "the underlying eroticism of the chivalric code ... is exposed in all its cruel perversity."{{sfn|Anderegg|1999|pp=132}} Tony Howard wrote that Welles used Shakespeare's historical plays "to denounce modern political hypocrisy and militarism."Jackson, Russell. ''Shakespeare on Film''. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. 2000. {{ISBN|0-521-63023-1}}. pp. 296. === Sound === Due to budgetary constraints, both the on-set and post-production sound was poorly recorded. Anderegg wrote that this, in combination with Welles' fast-paced camera movements and editing, makes the Shakespearean dialogue more difficult to understand. Many scenes are shot in long takes or with character's backs facing the camera, most likely for practical purposes when actors were not present, creating more sound problems. "In effect," Anderegg writes, "Welles generates a constant tension between what we see and what we hear, a tension that points to the ambiguous status of language in its relation to action."{{sfn|Anderegg|1999|pp=130}} During the [[Battle of Shrewsbury]] sequence, Welles used a complex and layered soundtrack that included the sounds of swords and armor clanking, soldiers grunting and screaming, bones breaking, boots in the mud and the film's musical score to add to the chaos of the scene.{{sfn|Anderegg|1999|pp=132}} === Interpretation of Shakespeare === Welles' adaptation of five Shakespeare plays was not a chronological transcription of the original texts. Shakespearean scholar Kenneth S. Rothwell said that Welles "goes beyond mere tinkering with Shakespeare's scenes; [he] massively reworks, transposes, revises and deletes, indeed reconstructs them." These changes included taking lines of dialogue from one play and inserting them into scenes from another.{{sfn|Rothwell|1999|pp=86—87}} Specific changes include a scene near the end of the film in which Hal pardons an imprisoned street rabble-rouser just before his expedition to invade [[France]]; Welles slightly altered this scene from ''Henry V'', Act 2, Scene 2. In the film it is stated that this man is Falstaff, and that the incident he is pardoning is Falstaff's disturbance of Hal's coronation. Although both the pardoned prisoner and Falstaff are said to drink wine, Shakespeare does not imply that the pardoned prisoner is Falstaff.{{sfn|Rothwell|1999|pp=88}} In both ''Chimes at Midnight'' and in ''Henry V'', this scene is followed by Falstaff's death.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=245–254}} The film contains no true [[Soliloquy|soliloquies]], since characters are never alone and do not speak directly to the audience during their speeches.{{sfn|Anderegg |1999 | pp=130}} Henry IV is usually shown standing or sitting with very little action involved{{mdash}}this, says Anderegg, makes it appear that he speaks only to himself even when others are present. Gielgud was known for his classical interpretation of Shakespeare, and his performance consists almost entirely of words, which are unable to defeat either Northumberland's rebels or Hal's wild behavior. Throughout the film, Falstaff, Hal, and Hotspur imitate Gielgud, mocking the words of Henry IV.{{sfn|Anderegg|1999|pp=133}} == Reception == === Critical response === ''Chimes at Midnight'' premiered to a positive audience reception at the [[1966 Cannes Film Festival]]. However, after ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' critic [[Bosley Crowther]]'s unfavorable advance review, American distributor Harry Saltzman decided to give the film little publicity and minimal distribution when it was released in the U.S. the next year.Wakeman, John. ''World Film Directors, Volume 1.'' The H. W. Wilson Company. 1987. pp. 1181. {{ISBN|0-8242-0757-2}} Critical reception on its first release was mostly negative; the film was not regarded as one of Welles' best until years later. Crowther criticized the film's poor audio track and called it "a confusing patchwork of scenes and characters ... designed to give major exposure to Jack Falstaff." Welles' performance, he said, was "a dissolute, bumbling street-corner Santa Claus."{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=289}} [[Penelope Houston (film critic)|Penelope Houston]] called it "a film which seems to turn its back on brilliance."{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=296}} A ''[[Time magazine|Time]]'' review also criticized Welles, stating that "[he] is probably the first actor in the history of the theater to appear too fat for the role ... he takes command of scenes less with spoken English than with body English", but that he is "never entirely bad."{{sfn|Howard|1991|p=168}} [[Judith Crist]] praised the film as "stark, simple, concentrating on word and performance, serv[ing] as a reminder of where the substance of the play lies."{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=291–292}} [[Pauline Kael]] also criticized the poor sound, but gave a favorable review overall, singling out the film's casting and calling Welles' performance "very rich, very full." She said the Battle of Shrewsbury sequence was "unlike any battle scene done on the screen before."{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=298–300}} ''[[Cahiers du Cinema]]'' critic [[Serge Daney]] also praised both the film and Welles' ability to make great films on the subject of power.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=301}} Welles was disappointed with the film's reception, complaining that "almost nobody has seen it in America, and that drives me nuts."{{sfn|Leaming|1985|pp=465}} === Legacy === Welles held ''Chimes at Midnight'' in high regard. "It's my favorite picture, yes," he told interviewer Leslie Megahey in a 1982 interview for ''[[Arena (UK TV series)|BBC Arena]]'':
If I wanted to get into heaven on the basis of one movie, that's the one I would offer up. I think it's because it is to me the least flawed; let me put it that way. It is the most successful for what I tried to do. I succeeded more completely in my view with that than with anything else.BBC Arena. ''The Orson Welles Story'' BBC Two/BBC Four. 01:51:46-01:52:16. Broadcast May 18, 1982. Retrieved 2012-08-01Estrin, Mark W., and Orson Welles, ''Orson Welles: Interviews''. Jackson, Mississippi: University Press of Mississippi, 2002.{{Rp|203}}
He also considered it to be his most personal film, along with ''[[The Magnificent Ambersons (film)|The Magnificent Ambersons]]''.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=262}} Many critics, including [[Peter Bogdanovich]] and [[Jonathan Rosenbaum]], also consider ''Chimes at Midnight'' to be Welles' finest work. Several years after its initial release, film critic [[Vincent Canby]] of ''The New York Times'' wrote that ''Chimes at Midnight'' "may be the greatest Shakespearean film ever made, bar none."Canby, Vincent, "The Undiminished Chutzpah of Orson Welles." ''[[The New York Times]]'', March 2, 1975, Accessed on June 9, 2012 [[Joseph McBride (writer)|Joseph McBride]] has called it "Welles' masterpiece, the fullest, most completely realized expression of everything he had been working towards since ''[[Citizen Kane]]''."{{sfn|Thomson|1996|pp=383}} In 2006, [[Roger Ebert]] praised the film as "a magnificent film, clearly among Welles' greatest work."{{cite news |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060604/REVIEWS08/606040301/1004 |title=Roger Ebert review |accessdate=June 10, 2012 |work=rogerebert.suntimes.com |date=June 4, 2006}} The Battle of Shrewsbury sequence has been particularly admired, and inspired later movies, including ''[[Braveheart]]'' and ''[[Saving Private Ryan]]''. Film critics have compared it to the Odessa Steps sequence in ''[[Battleship Potemkin]]'' and the Battle on the Ice sequence in ''[[Alexander Nevsky (film)|Alexander Nevsky]]'', both directed by [[Sergei Eisenstein]].Cook, David A. ''The History of Narrative Film.'' W.W. Norton & Company, New York, Third Edition. 1996. {{ISBN|0-393-96819-7}} [[Kenneth Branagh]]'s ''[[Henry V (1989 film)|Henry V]]'' used Welles' Battle of Shrewsbury sequence as an inspiration for the [[Battle of Agincourt]],{{sfn|Anderegg|1999|pp=132}} and depicted Prince Hal's rejection of Falstaff in a way that was more influenced by ''Chimes at Midnight'' than from more traditional interpretations of the scene.{{sfn|Anderegg|1999|pp=140}} In 1988, director [[Patrick Garland]] staged a version of ''Chimes at Midnight'' starring Simon Callow as Falstaff at the [[Chichester Festival Theatre]].{{cite web |url=http://dublintheatrefestival.com/artists/display.asp?m=&artistID=38 |title=Patrick Garland profile |accessdate=June 11, 2012 |work=dublintheatrefestival.com}} Michael Anderegg said that ''Chimes at Midnight''{{'}}s use of wide angle lenses, low-key lighting and costumes, and its focus on the relationship between Falstaff and Prince Hal influenced ''[[My Own Private Idaho]]''{{mdash}}[[Gus Van Sant]]'s 1991 loose adaptation of ''Henry IV Parts 1 and 2''.{{sfn|Anderegg|1999|pp=123}} In 2011, [[Bonhams|Bonham's Auction House]] sold a large archive of Welles' material that had once belonged to the film's executive producer Alessandro Tasca di Cuto. Most of the material was from ''Chimes at Midnight'', and included Welles' original art-work, photographs and memoranda.{{cite web|url = http://www.wellesnet.com/?cat=16 |title = Bonhams to sell a Treasure Trove of Production Material on Orson Welles’s Masterpiece CHIMES AT MIDNIGHT |accessdate = June 11, 2012 |work = http://www.wellesnet.com, November 6, 2011}} This collection was later donated to the [[University of Michigan]] for scholarly study.{{cite web|url = http://www.wellesnet.com/?p=1744 |title = Additions to Orson Welles collection at University of Michigan open to scholars |accessdate = December 7, 2012 |work = http://www.wellesnet.com, September 24, 2012}} In 2012, for the [[British Film Institute]]'s ''[[Sight and Sound]]'' poll, 11 film critics and two directors voted ''Chimes at Midnight'' one of the 10 greatest films of all time, including McBride and [[Todd McCarthy]].{{cite web |url=http://explore.bfi.org.uk/sightandsoundpolls/2012/film/4ce2b6a70cd80 |title=Chimes at Midnight |year=2012 |work=bfi.org.uk |accessdate=December 29, 2014}} Spanish writer and director of the Film Library of Catalonia Esteve Riambau published a book about the film called ''The Things We've Seen: Welles and Falstaff'' in 2015.{{cite web |url=http://www.wellesnet.com/news-from-the-sedona-film-festival-chimes-at-midnight-dvd-art-exhibits-and-more/ |last=Kelly |first=Ray |title=News from the Sedona Film Festival: ‘Chimes at Midnight’ DVD, art exhibits and more |work=Wellesnet |date=February 27, 2015 |accessdate=February 27, 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.wellesnet.com/spanish-book-on-orson-welles-and-chimes-at-midnight-out-now/ |last=Kelly |first=Ray |title=Spanish book on Orson Welles and ‘Chimes at Midnight’ out now |work=Wellesnet |date=May 19, 2015 |accessdate=May 21, 2015}} === Awards === At the 1966 Cannes Film Festival, ''Chimes at Midnight'' was screened in competition for the [[Palme d'Or]] and won the 20th Anniversary Prize and the Technical Grand Prize.{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/2819/year/1966.html |title=Festival de Cannes: Chimes at Midnight |accessdate=March 7, 2009|work=festival-cannes.com}} Welles was nominated for a [[21st British Academy Film Awards|BAFTA]] award for Best Foreign Actor in 1968{{cite web |url=http://www.bafta.org/awards-database.html?sq=orson+welles |title=BAFTA awards Database |accessdate=July 16, 2012 |work= www.bafta.org}} In Spain, the film won the Citizens Writers Circle Award for Best Film in 1966.{{cite web |url=http://www.cinecec.com/EDITOR/premios/palmares/1965.htm |title=CEC Awards for 1965 |accessdate=July 16, 2012 |work=www.cinecec.com}} === Home media === Because of legal disputes over the rights, ''Chimes at Midnight'' has only been released twice on VHS video in the United States, neither of which is currently available. Harry Saltzman's widow Adriana Saltzman, the families of producers Emiliano Piedra and Angel Escolano and the estate of Orson Welles{{mdash}}maintained by [[Beatrice Welles]]{{mdash}} among others have all claimed ownership of the film.{{cite web|url = http://www.wellesnet.com/?p=667#more-667 |title = WELLES FILM IS HELD UP IN DISPUTE |accessdate = June 11, 2012 |work = http://www.wellesnet.com, June 23, 1992}} For many years the only available source was a region-free DVD from Brazil. [[Mr Bongo Records]] screened a restored version in the UK at Picturehouse Cinemas on August 1, 2011.{{cite news|url = https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/orson-welles-rarely-seen-masterpiece-is-restored-and-rereleased-2313302.html |title = independent.com article |accessdate = June 9, 2012 |work = www.independent.co.uk |location=London |first=Geoffrey |last=MacNab |date=July 14, 2011}} In February 2015, the film was screened at the [[Sedona International Film Festival]]. Beatrice Welles attended and announced that "a major DVD/Blu-ray label is interested in restoring and releasing ''Chimes at Midnight''." The pristine 35mm print was discovered by Distribpix Inc., who said it was "in such great condition that it is begging for a full 4k scan restoration."{{cite web |url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/how-a-near-pristine-35mm-print-of-orson-welles-chimes-at-midnight-was-found-20150227 |last=Lattanzio |first=Ryan |title=How a Near-Pristine 35mm Print of Orson Welles' 'Chimes at Midnight' Was Found |work=Thompson on Hollywood |date=February 27, 2015 |accessdate=February 27, 2015}} The film had a European release on DVD and Blu-ray on June 29, 2015.{{cite web |url=http://www.blu-ray.com/news/?id=16525 |website=Blu-ray.com |date=April 10, 2015 |accessdate=June 21, 2015 |title=Orson Welles' Falstaff: Chimes at Midnight and Too Much Johnson Prepped for Blu-ray}}{{cite web |url=http://www.hometheaterforum.com/topic/341540-mr-bongo-chimes-at-midnightfalstaff/?p=4263816 |title=Mr Bongo Chimes at Midnight/Falstaff |website=Home Theater Forum |date=July 1, 2015 |accessdate=July 18, 2015}} === 2016 Restoration === [[Janus Films]] released a restored version of the film on D.C.P. that premiered on January 1, 2016, at [[Film Forum]] in New York City January 1–12, 2016 and [[Cinefamily]] in Los Angeles.{{cite web|url=http://filmforum.org/film/chimes-at-midnight-film |publisher=Film Forum |title=Chimes at Midnight [programme note] |deadurl=yes |accessdate=November 28, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151205114301/http://filmforum.org/film/chimes-at-midnight-film |archivedate=December 5, 2015 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.cinefamily.org/films/chimes-at-midnight/ |title=Chimes at Midnight [programme note] |publisher=The Cinefamily at the Silent Movie Theatre}} This restored version is not derived from the Distribpix print.{{cite web |url=http://www.indiewire.com/2015/12/orson-welles-chimes-at-midnight-returns-to-cinemas-for-the-first-time-in-decades-this-new-years-day-175533/ |author=John Anderson and Matt Brennan |website=IndieWire |title=Orson Welles’ ‘Chimes at Midnight’ Returns to Cinemas For the First Time in Decades This New Year’s Day}} Peter Becker, Criterion's president, said that the release is the product of more than 20 years of effort: "There is no film we have waited longer for or worked harder to free up, and none we are prouder to present", he said.{{cite web |url=http://www.wellesnet.com/criterion-president-peter-becker-talks-about-newly-restored-chimes-at-midnight/ |last=Kelly |first=Ray |title=Criterion president Peter Becker talks about newly restored ‘Chimes at Midnight’|website=Wellesnet |date=December 7, 2015|accessdate=December 8, 2015}} Criterion released this restoration on DVD and Blu-ray on August 30, 2016. == Welles and Falstaff == [[File:Grützner Falstaff mit Kanne.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Eduard von Grützner's ''Falstaff with big wine jar and cup'' shows the traditional jolly and comical depiction of Falstaff that Welles rejected.]] === Welles' views on Sir John Falstaff === Welles considered Falstaff to be "Shakespeare's greatest creation"{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=4}} and said that the role was "the most difficult part I've ever played."{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=261}} Keith Baxter believed that making the film was Welles' life's ambition.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=282}} Before the 1939 Boston premiere of ''Five Kings'', Welles told journalists "I will play him as a tragic figure. I hope, of course, he will be funny to the audience, just as he was funny to those around him. But his humor and wit were aroused merely by the fact that he wanted to please the prince. Falstaff, however, had the potential of greatness in him."{{sfn|Callow|1996|pp=442}} Reviews for the 1939 play mention Welles' choice to downplay the traditional comedic elements of Falstaff in his performance.{{sfn|Anderegg|1999|pp=139}} This reverence for the character increased over the years and by the time Welles made ''Chimes at Midnight'', his focus was entirely on the relationships between Falstaff, Hal and Henry IV. He believed that the core of the story was "the betrayal of friendship."{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=5}} Welles called Hal's rejection of Falstaff "one of the greatest scenes ever written, so the movie is really a preparation for it. Everything prepares for it."{{sfn|Leaming|1985|pp=464}} Throughout the film, Hal constantly turns his back on Falstaff, foreshadowing the film's ending.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=7}} Welles said, "the film was not intended as a lament for Falstaff, but for the death of [[Merry England|Merrie England]]. Merrie England as a conception, a myth which has been very real to the English-speaking world, and is to some extent expressed in other countries of the Medieval epoch: the age of chivalry, of simplicity, of Maytime and all that. It is more than Falstaff who is dying. It's the old England dying and betrayed."{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=262}} Many film theorists and Welles biographers have written about the recurrent theme of the "Lost [[Garden of Eden|Eden]]" in Welles' work and of characters who are nostalgic for an idealized past, which Welles called "the central theme in Western culture."{{sfn|Anderegg|1999|pp=124}} Welles told Peter Bogdanovich that "even if the good old days never existed, the fact that we can conceive of such a world is, in fact, an affirmation of the human spirit."{{sfn|Welles|Bogdanovich|1992|pp=100}} Film scholar Beverle Houston argued that this nostalgia made Welles' depiction of Falstaff infantile and called his performance a "[p]ower baby ... an eating, sucking, foetus-like creature."{{sfn|Anderegg|1999|pp=130}} Welles also called Falstaff "the greatest conception of a good man, the most completely good man, in all of drama",{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=261}} and said that "the closer I thought I was getting to Falstaff the less funny he seemed to me. When I played him before in the theater, he seemed more witty than comical. And in bringing him to the screen, I found him only occasionally, and only ''deliberately'', a clown."{{sfn|Callow|1996|pp=442}} === Welles' personal connections to Sir John Falstaff === {{quote box|bgcolor=#CCDDFF|align=left|width=25%|quote="[Falstaff]'s good in the sense that the hippies are good. The comedy is all about gross faults in the man, but those faults are so trivial: his famous cowardice is a joke— a joke Falstaff seems to be telling himself against himself...he asks for so little, and in the end gets nothing." - Welles on Falstaff{{sfn|Welles|Bogdanovich|1992|pp=100}}}} Keith Baxter compared Welles to Falstaff, since they were both perpetually short of money, often lied and cheated people to get what they needed and were always merry and fun loving.{{sfn|Lyons|1989|pp=282}} Film scholar Jack Jorgens also compared Welles to Falstaff, stating that "to a man who directed and starred in a masterpiece and has since staggered through three decades of underfinanced, hurried, flawed films, scores of bit parts, narrations, and interviews which debased his talent, dozens of projects which died for want of persistence and financing, the story of a fat, aging jester exiled from his audience and no longer able to triumph over impossible obstacles with wit and torrential imagination might well seem tragic."{{sfn|Anderegg|1999|pp=138–139}} When [[Joss Ackland]] played Falstaff on the stage in 1982, he said that he was more inspired by Welles than by Welles' performance as Falstaff, stating that "like Falstaff, I believe he could have achieved so much, but it was frittered away."{{sfn|Anderegg|1999|pp=140}} Kenneth S. Rothwell has called Hal's rejection of Falstaff allegorical to Hollywood's rejection of Welles.{{sfn|Rothwell|1999|pp=86}} Welles had become deeply depressed in the late 1950s after the disappointment of making ''[[Touch of Evil]]'', his intended Hollywood come-back.{{sfn|Feder|2009|pp=180—181}} Welles' biographer [[Simon Callow]] has compared Falstaff to Welles' father Richard Head Welles, stating that like Falstaff, Welles' father was "a drunkard, a trickster, a braggart, a womanizer, a gentleman and a charmer{{mdash}}and he is rejected by the person he loves the most."{{sfn|Callow|1996|pp=442}} Welles' father was an alcoholic and womanizer who would often take a teenage Welles along with him when he was indulging in his vices. Welles observed his father much like Falstaff is observed by Hal and depends on his young protégé to bail him out of trouble.{{sfn|Leaming|1985|pp=463}} The love triangle between Prince Hal and his two father figures, Henry IV and Falstaff, is also similar to Welles' relationships with his father and the two men who became surrogate fathers to him: family friend Dr. Maurice Bernstein and Todd School for Boys headmaster Roger Hill.{{sfn|Leaming|1985|pp=463}} Both of Welles' surrogate fathers disapproved of Richard Welles' life-style and negative influence on Welles. When the younger Welles turned fifteen, he took the advice of Roger Hill and told his father that he would not see him again until he cleaned up his act and stopped drinking; Welles' father died shortly afterwards, alone and lonely, and Welles always blamed himself for his father's death, stating, "I always ''thought'' I killed him."{{sfn|Leaming|1985|pp=32}} Welles' alleged biological son [[Michael Lindsay-Hogg]], who was born out of wedlock to Welles and actress [[Geraldine Fitzgerald]], first met Welles when he was 15 and later worked on the 1960 stage play ''Chimes at Midnight''. This was the only significant amount of time that the two spent together and afterwards Lindsay-Hogg only saw Welles sporadically. Like Welles, Lindsay-Hogg had two surrogate fathers in addition to his biological father.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/02/books/review/luck-and-circumstance-by-michael-lindsay-hogg-book-review.html?_r=1&nl=books&emc=booksupdateema4 |title=Are You My Father, Orson Welles? |date=September 30, 2011 |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=July 7, 2012 |first=Alex |last=Witchel}} In the late 1950s when she was sixteen years old, Welles' eldest daughter Christopher Welles Feder cut off all ties with Welles under pressure from her mother, who disapproved of Welles' influence on her.{{sfn|Feder|2009|pp=162}} Welles and Feder later reconnected but their relationship never fully recovered.{{sfn|Feder|2009|pp=203}} Welles' youngest daughter Beatrice, who resembled her father as a young boy, appears in the film version of ''Chimes at Midnight''.{{sfn|Leaming|1985|pp=465}} == References == '''Bibliography''' {{refbegin}} * {{cite book |last=Anderegg |first=Michael |title=Orson Welles, Shakespeare and Popular Culture |publisher=Columbia University Press |location=New York |year=1999 |isbn=0-231-11228-9 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Callow |first=Simon |title=Orson Welles, Volume 1: The Road to Xanadu |publisher=Viking Penguin |location=New York |year=1996 |isbn=0-670-86722-5 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Callow |first=Simon |title=Orson Welles, Volume 3: One-man Band |publisher=Viking Penguin |location=New York |year=2016 |isbn=978-0-670-02491-9 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Feder |first=Christopher Welles |title=In My Father's Shadow |publisher=Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill |location=Chapel Hill |year=2009 |isbn=978-1-56512-599-5 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Howard |first=James |title=The Complete Films of Orson Welles |publisher=Citadel Press |location=New York |year=1991 |isbn=0-8065-1241-5 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Leaming |first=Barbara |title=Orson Welles |publisher=Penguin Books |location=New York |year=1985 |isbn=0-670-52895-1 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Lindsay-Hogg |first=Michael |title=Luck and Circumstance: A Coming of Age in Hollywood, New York and Points Beyond |publisher=Alfred A. Knopf |location=New York |year=2011 |isbn=978-0-307-59468-6 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Lyons |first=Bridget Gellert |title=Chimes at Midnight |publisher=Rutgers University Press |location=New Brunswick and London |year=1989 |isbn=0-8135-1339-1 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Rothwell |first=Kenneth S. |title=A History of Shakespeare on Screen |publisher=Alfred A. Knopf |location=New York |year=1999 |isbn=0-521-59404-9 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Thomson |first=David |title=Rosebud: The Story of Orson Welles |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge University |year=1996 |isbn=0-679-41834-2 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last1=Welles |first1=Orson |last2=Bogdanovich |first2=Peter |title=[[This is Orson Welles]] |publisher=Harper Collins Publishers, Inc |location=New York |year=1992 |isbn=0-06-092439-X |ref=harv}} {{refend}} '''Citations''' {{reflist|30em}} == See also == * {{cite book|last=Riambau|first=Esteve|title=Las Cosas Que Hemos Visto: Welles y Falstaff (Things We Have Seen: Welles and Falstaff) |publisher=Luces Galibo |location=Spain |year=2015 |isbn=978-8-415-11734-6}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|id=0059012| title=Chimes at Midnight}} * {{Amg movie|9321|Chimes at Midnight}} * {{Rotten-tomatoes|id=chimes_at_midnight_1965|title=Chimes at Midnight}} * {{tcmdb title|70831|Falstaff}} * {{AFI film|22279|Chimes at Midnight}} * [http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060604/REVIEWS08/606040301/1004 Roger Ebert "Great Movies" review] * [http://www.cinescene.com/reviews/chimes.html Cinescene review] * [http://video.google.com/videosearch?q=chimes+at+midnight+1&emb=0# Google Video] * [http://www.wellesnet.com/?cat=16 Wellesnet.com, the Orson Welles Web Resource, articles on the film] {{Orson Welles|state=autocollapse}} {{Harry Saltzman|state=autocollapse}} {{Henriad}} [[Category:1960s drama films]] [[Category:1966 films]] revision.comment: removed [[Category:Economics]]; added [[Category:Market failure]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Ref improve|date=July 2012}} '''Conspiracies against the laity''' is a term coined by [[George Bernard Shaw]] in his 1906 play [[The Doctor's Dilemma (play)|The Doctor's Dilemma]]. The conspiracies refer to the methods used by professions to acquire prestige, power and wealth.
On the subject of such conspiracies, [[Tim Harford]] argued the following in his 2006 book [[The Undercover Economist]]: "... doctors, actuaries, accountants and lawyers manage to maintain high wages through... erecting virtual 'green belts' to make it hard for competitors to set up shop. Typical virtual green belts will include very long qualification periods and professional bodies that give their approval only to a certain number of candidates per year. Many of the organisations that are put forth to protect us from 'unqualified' professionals in fact serve to maintain the high rates of the 'qualified' to whom we are directed."
Shaw's sentiments echo Adam Smith's earlier writing: "People of the same trade seldom meet together, even for merriment and diversion, but the conversation ends in a conspiracy against the public, or in some contrivance to raise prices."<ref>Smith, A., An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations, 1776.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Social concepts]] [[Category:Market failure]] [[Category:Social justice]]

revision.comment: /* The end of the curse */ change it to negative in the last sentence
revision.text:
The '''Curse of Coogan's Bluff'''/'''Curse of Eddie Grant''' (1958–2010) was a [[sports-related curses|baseball-related superstition]] that allegedly prevented the [[San Francisco Giants]] [[Major League Baseball]] franchise from winning the [[World Series]] following the club's [[relocation of professional sports teams|move]] from [[New York City]] to [[San Francisco]] after the conclusion of the 1957 season. The curse began when upset Giants fans in the [[New York metropolitan area]] placed a hex on the relocated franchise. The curse ended when the Giants won the [[2010 World Series]] in their fourth World Series appearance since the move to San Francisco.
== Background and origin of the curse == Although the actual curse began in 1958, the story goes back to 1918 when [[Eddie Grant (baseball)|Eddie Grant]] was killed while fighting in World War I. The team honored him with a commemorative plaque on the center field wall at the [[Polo Grounds]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://entertainment.howstuffworks.com/5-legendary-baseball-curses6.htm|title=10 Legendary Baseball Curses|date=2012-08-16|work=HowStuffWorks|access-date=2017-12-16|language=en}}</ref> While the franchise was based in New York, the Giants won five World Series titles, with the longest drought between titles being 21 years. The last championship as the New York Giants came against the [[Cleveland Indians]] in [[1954 World Series|1954]], notably featuring [[Willie Mays]]' famous [[The Catch (baseball)|catch]] in Game 1.
In the 1950s, Giants' owner [[Horace Stoneham]] began to consider moving the team to another city while needing a new stadium to replace the crumbling Polo Grounds. San Francisco mayor [[George Christopher]] negotiated with Stoneham, approving the move to San Francisco starting with the 1958 season. The approval caused the upset Giants fans to storm the field during the last home game before the relocation, stealing the Eddie Grant plaque and losing the team identity.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{cite news|last=Bondy|first=Filip|title=Bondy: Giants should be in N.Y. state of mind|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/baseball/giants-hope-world-series-curse-texas-rangers-embrace-new-york-roots-article-1.188519|newspaper=New York Daily News|date=October 25, 2010|access-date=May 2, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> Following the move, upset Giants' fans in New York allegedly placed a hex on the [[San Francisco Giants]], claiming the franchise would never win the World Series while based in San Francisco.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hayden|first1=Matthew|title=6 Insane Sports Stories|url=http://www.cracked.com/article_17209_6-insane-sports-stories-that-will-make-you-believe-in-curses.html|website=Cracked.com|date=April 3, 2009|accessdate=6 November 2016}}</ref> Many believed all of the team's good luck is in New York.<ref>{{cite news|last=Turner|first=Gus|title=The Curse of Coogan's Bluff – The Worst Curses in Sports History|url=http://www.complex.com/sports/2014/05/worst-curses-sports-history/the-curse-of-coogans-bluff|publisher=Complex|date=May 20, 2014|accessdate=August 8, 2016}}</ref>
== World Series appearances during the curse == During the 50 years after placing the alleged Curse of Coogan's Bluff, the Giants made three World Series appearances and lost each time, two of which in 7-game Series. In 1962, in Game 3 of the playoff series that decided who would win the [[National League]] pennant and play in the World Series, the Giants overcame a two-run deficit in the 9th inning against the [[Dodgers–Giants rivalry|rival]] [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] to clinch the pennant. In Game 7 of the [[1962 World Series]] against the former crosstown [[Giants–Yankees rivalry|rival]] [[New York Yankees]], down 1–0 and with runners on second and third, [[Willie McCovey]] hit a sharp line drive, but the ball was caught by Yankees' second baseman [[Bobby Richardson]] to end the game and the Series.
In the [[1989 World Series]], the Giants were swept by another [[San Francisco Bay Area]] team, the [[Oakland Athletics]]. The 1989 Series was infamous for the [[1989 Loma Prieta earthquake|large earthquake]] that struck the San Francisco Bay Area, delaying Games 3 and 4 of the World Series by 10 days. In the [[2002 World Series]] against the [[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim|Anaheim Angels]], the Giants led 3 games to 2 heading back to Anaheim for Games 6 and 7, but the Giants lost the last two for the third World Series loss since moving to San Francisco. In Game 6 of that Series, the Giants held a commanding 5–0 lead heading into the 7th inning. However, the Giants allowed the Angels to score 6 unanswered runs in the 7th and 8th innings for one of the greatest comebacks in World Series history. The Giants lost Game 7 (and the Series) the next day 4–1.
== The end of the curse == In 2001, historian and author Mike Hanlon suggested to Giants owner [[Peter Magowan]] to have a new plaque to be installed at [[AT&T Park]] in the effort of ending their curse. In 2006, the development of the new plaque began but took two years due to problems of production. In 2008, the Eddie Grant plaque was installed on the tower at the right field.<ref name=":1" /> The installation of the plaque would prove effective for the team's chances of winning the championship. In 2010, the Giants won the division after passing the [[San Diego Padres]] for the [[National League West|NL West]] division lead late in the season. The Giants qualified to play in the World Series after defeating the [[Atlanta Braves]] in the [[2010 National League Division Series|National League Division Series]] and the [[Philadelphia Phillies]] (who made back-to-back World Series appearances in the previous year) in the [[2010 National League Championship Series|National League Championship Series]]. The Giants defeated the [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]] in five games to win the [[2010 World Series|World Series]] championship for the first time since moving to San Francisco in 1958, thus ending the 52-year Curse of Coogan's Bluff. Following their 2010 championship, the Giants would win two more world championships in the next four years—in [[2012 World Series|2012]] and in [[2014 World Series|2014]]. However they have yet to win the World Series clincher while playing in San Francisco.
==See also== * [[Baseball superstition]] * [[Curse of the Bambino]] – A similar superstition surrounding the [[Boston Red Sox]] (ended in 2004) * [[Curse of the Billy Goat]] – A similar superstition surrounding the [[Chicago Cubs]] (ended in 2016) * [[Curse of the Black Sox]] – A similar superstition surrounding the [[Chicago White Sox]] (ended in 2005) * [[Curse of Rocky Colavito]] – A similar superstition surrounding the [[Cleveland Indians]] (ongoing) * [[Curse of the Colonel]] – A similar superstition surrounding the [[Hanshin Tigers]] (Japanese baseball) * [[Sports-related curses]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{San Francisco Giants}} {{Sports-related curses}}
[[Category:San Francisco Giants]] [[Category:Baseball-related curses]] [[Category:Sports-related curses]] [[Category:Curses]] [[Category:Urban legends]]

revision.comment: /* Fire and aftermath */ which?
revision.text:
{{Coord|37.560882|N|126.982714|E|display=title|format=dms}}
{{Infobox event | title = Daeyeonggak Hotel fire | image = 1971년 12월 25일 대연각호텔 대화재 사고(大然閣 -大火災事故)2.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = | time = 9:50 am, 1971-12-25 | place = [[Chungmuro]], [[Jung District, Seoul]], South Korea | coordinates = | also known as = | cause = [[Gas explosion]]{{R|陈军}} | reported deaths = 164 | reported injuries = 63 | reported property damage = | suspects = }}
'''Daeyeonggak Hotel fire''' was a [[skyscraper fire]] in Seoul, South Korea on December 25, 1971, that killed 164 people and injured 63 people.{{R|章孝思}} It remains the deadliest hotel fire in world history.
==Background== The 22-storey Daeyeonggak Hotel (also called Hotel Taeyongak) was a luxury hotel completed in 1969.<ref name="insufficient"/> It had 222 rooms.<ref name="seoulhotel">{{cite news|title=Seoul hotel fire: 8 arrested|work=South China Morning Post|date=29 December 1971|page=16}}</ref>
==Fire and aftermath== The fire burned for ten hours.<ref name="UPI"/> Many were unable to find the exit in the darkness. The fire department's ladders only reached the eighth floor, trapping those from the ninth to the 22nd storeys.<ref name="UPI"/> At least 38 people died leaping from windows to escape the inferno, some clinging to mattresses in an attempt to survive the fall.<ref name="UPI"/> 12 helicopters were mobilised to try to rescue guests from the roof using aerial slings. One man fell to his death from a helicopter.<ref name="UPI"/>
The authorities arrested eight people in connection with the disaster.<ref name="FireExperts"/> These included Kim Yong-san and four other hotel officials, who were charged with carelessness and improper construction, as well as two former city officials and a fire officer on charges of negligence.<ref name="seoulhotel"/>
The 162nd death was that of Yu Sien-yung, the minister of the Taiwanese embassy in Seoul, who lived alone in the hotel. He was trapped in the burning building for more than 10 hours and died in hospital, aged 64, on 4 January 1972.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hotel fire toll up|work=South China Morning Post|date=5 January 1972|page=18}}</ref>
The design of the building was said to have played a part in the high death toll. The two internal staircases were designed for use in case of lift failures and not as fire exits, and filled with smoke during the fire, acting as chimneys.<ref name="insufficient">{{cite news|title=Insufficient fire exits pushed up hotel deaths|work=South China Morning Post|date=30 December 1971|page=18}}</ref><ref name="UPI">{{cite news|title=Fire turned hotel into death-trap chimney expert|work=South China Morning Post|agency=United Press International|date=28 December 1971}}</ref> The building had no external emergency staircase. The walls between the hotel rooms were not sufficiently fire resistant, hastening the spread of the blaze.<ref name="insufficient"/> The tower lacked many other safety features, including battery-operated exit lights.
Two senior fire services officers of the [[Hong Kong Government]] flew to Seoul on 11 January 1972 to confer with the South Koreans on fire prevention.<ref name="FireExperts">{{cite news|title=Fire experts off to Seoul|work=[[South China Morning Post]]|date=11 January 1972|page=18}}</ref>
The building was remodeled after the fire. There was another fire there on 27 February 2010.
==See also== * [[2010 Shanghai fire]]
==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= <ref name="陈军">{{cite book|author=陈军|title=《人民警察素貭敎育全书》|publisher=中国检察出版社| url = https://books.google.com.tw/books?hl=zh-TW&id=HFd0AAAAIAAJ | date = 1998 | page=337}}</ref> <ref name="章孝思">{{cite book|author=章孝思|title=《高层建筑防火》|date=Feb 1985|publisher=中国建筑工业出版社|isbn=711200750X | url = https://books.google.com.tw/books?id=-LPSAAAAMAAJ}}</ref>
}}

revision.text:
[[Image:Corbould edward henry thejoustbetweenthelordofthetournament.jpg|thumb|250px|The joust between the Lord of the Eglinton Tournament and the Knight of the Red Rose]] The '''Eglinton Trophy''' or '''Eglinton Testimonial'''<ref name="G">Girouard, Page 105</ref> is a Gothic style [[Sterling silver]] centrepiece presented by friends and admirers to the [[Archibald Montgomerie, 13th Earl of Eglinton|13th Earl of Eglinton]] to commemorate the medieval re-enactment known as the [[Eglinton Tournament of 1839|Eglinton Tournament]] held at [[Eglinton Castle]], [[Kilwinning]], North Ayrshire in 1839. At 4 foot 8 inch (140 cm) in height and 1600 ounces (45 kg) in weight it is one of the largest and most extravagant trophies of its kind.
==History== ===Fund raising=== A committee, including [[John Fane, 11th Earl of Westmorland|Lord Burghersh]], and chaired by the [[Charles Vane, 3rd Marquess of Londonderry|Marquess of Londonderry]],<ref name="G"/> King of the Tournament, was formed to set up a subscription to "present Eglinton with a piece of plate, to commemorate the revival of the days of chivalry".<ref name="A232"/> Two hundred and thirty-nine people subscribed to the production of the trophy, each being limited to a maximum of twenty guineas (Circa £900 in modern terms).<ref name="A232">Anstruther, Page 232</ref>
===Design and production=== [[Image:Detail of the Eglinton Trophy, Earl of Eglinton..jpg|thumb|upright|Detail of the Eglinton Trophy]] [[File:Eglinton castle interior 5.jpg|thumb|left|200px|A contemporary photograph showing the trophy in its case in the castle's library.]] The 4 foot 8 inch (140 cm) high trophy, weighing in at 1600 ounces (45 kg), was designed by Edmund Cotterill (1795–1860), made in a medieval [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic]] style by [[Garrard & Co|Messrs. R & S Garrard]], Silversmiths of London at a cost then of £1,775 (£78,277 in modern terms)<ref>[http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/currency/results.asp#mid Currency Converter] Retrieved : 2011-03-18</ref> and took four years to complete.<ref name="A233">Anstruther, Page 233</ref>
Edmund Cotterill was in charge of the design studio at Garrards in 1843 and at the time of the Empire Exhibition (1851) he was said to stand "at the head of the class of artists who model for silversmiths and his productions, annually exhibited at Messrs Garrard, have earned that house a celebrity which no other can equal".<ref>[http://www.royalcollection.org.uk/microsites/vanda/MicroObject.asp?item=2&themeid=1019&object=1570&row=2&detail=about Victoria and Albert.] Retrieved : 2011-03-17</ref> The trophy is formed from modelled and cast silver components which were assembled together to create the final piece.<ref name=gad>[http://www.garrard.com/home/ Garrards & Co.] Retrieved : 2012-08-16</ref>
The Eglinton Trophy has a [[Hallmark]] and is therefore silver and not silver plate, it rises from a wide [[crenelated]] base on the sides of which are located the shields bearing the coats of arms of the fourteen Knights of the Tournament; a fifteenth shield is blank and four of the shields are in alcoves that extend from the base, accompanied by swords, quills, coronets, laurel leaf crown, etc. The 4 foot 8 inch (140 cm) trophy rises up as a highly ornate Gothic pulpit sitting beneath a pinnacled canopy under which Jane Georgiana, Lady Seymour, the Queen of Beauty stands in the act of placing a wreath upon the brow of the Earl of Eglinton, Lord and victor of the Eglinton Tournament.<ref name="A">Anstruther, Pages 231-232</ref>
Beside the figure of the earl are the Knight Marshal, Sir Charles Montolieu Lamb, with a dismounted squire, and a [[halbard]]ier, his escort and the presentation party.<ref name="A"/> Two hunting dogs are also present, together with two pages, one male and one female, and a lady in waiting. The squire and the lady in waiting give the impression of exchanging glances. A coat of arms is also displayed on a shield behind Lady Seymour.
The glass case that covers the trophy has wooded framed sections and rises up from an ornately carved eight-sided wooden base emblazoned with four coats of arms, earls coronets, and with a silver engraved dedicatory shield. This base stands around 2 feet and 10 inches (85 cm) in height.<ref name="G"/> The dedicatory shield reads "Presented to Archibald, Earl of Eglinton, by the Visitors to the Eglinton Tournament held at Eglinton Castle. MDCCCXXXIX."
===The Hallmark=== A [[Hallmark]] is stamped on the base of the trophy, at the front. The Silver Standard Mark is a Lion [[Attitude (heraldry)#Passant|passant]] indicating .925 purity, known as Sterling silver; the City Mark is an uncrowned Leopard indicating London as the city of manufacture, after the year 1822; the Maker's Mark is an "RG" beneath a Crown, indicating [[Garrard & Co|R & S Garrard]] after 1835 when James Garrard retired. The Crown indicates that the company had become official Crown Jewellers, an honour conferred on them by Queen Victoria in 1843;<ref name=gd/><ref name=hm/> the Date Letter however is a Gothic "G" for the year 1842;<ref>[http://freespace.virgin.net/a.data/dateletters/Lond/londonframe.htm Date Letters] Retrieved : 2012-08-13</ref> and finally the Duty Mark stamp of Queen Victoria's head indicating that duty was paid on the item and that it was made before 1890.<ref name=hm>[http://www.925-1000.com/british_marks.html British Hallmarks] Retrieved : 2012-08-14</ref>
The apparent disparity in dates just reflects the fact that the trophy was returned from the [[Assay Office]] in 1842 and finally assembled, completed and stamped by the maker for delivery to the committee and its presention to the earl in 1843.<ref name=gd>[http://www.silvercollection.it/ENGLAGARRARD.html History of Garrard & Co Ltd] Retrieved : 2012-08-14</ref> The Maker's Mark is not in alignment with the official Hallmark, lying slightly above.
===Use=== [[File:The Eglinton Trophy.JPG|left|thumb|upright|The Eglinton Trophy]] [[File:Eglinton Trophy base with dedicatory base.JPG|thumb|200px|The trophy base and dedicatory plaque.]] The trophy, presented to [[Archibald Montgomerie, 13th Earl of Eglinton]] in 1843, was originally housed within the library at [[Eglinton Castle]] and later at the Ayr County Hall in Ayr.<ref name="A233">Anstruther, Page 233</ref> It was featured and illustrated in ''The Illustrated London News'' of June 1843. The trophy is now kept, housed within its original glass and wood case, in Cunninghame House, headquarters of [[North Ayrshire Council]], having been loaned to the people of Ayrshire by the 14th Earl<ref>Montgomeries of Eglinton, Page 87.</ref> it is however still the property of the present Earl of Eglinton.<ref>[http://www.north-ayrshire.gov.uk/chiefexec/minutes.nsf/a5ed4770df04d9db802572dd00471a99/64e857801db1d956802577c100341c77?OpenDocument NAC Minutes] Retrieved : 2011-03-17</ref>
For a while during the construction of the headquarters of the then Cunninghame District Council it was housed at Wellwood, the home of the [[Irvine Burns Club]] and the official Royal Burgh of Irvine Museum.
It was moved to the [[Eglinton Country Park]] visitor centre in 1989 for the re-enactment that marked 150 years since the tournament and was also loaned to the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]].<ref name=gad/> It is insured by [[North Ayrshire Council]] for an undisclosed, but considerable sum, and was lent to [[East Ayrshire Council]] for a short time in 2011 (April 30 to August 20) as the centrepiece to an exhibition of James Henry Nixons (1802–1857) Eglinton Tournament prints<ref>[http://www.abbottandholderjv.co.uk/introduction.aspx Auction catalogue] Retrieved : 2011-03-17</ref> at the Dick Institute in [[Kilmarnock]].
The trophy is of great significance to the local and social history of the area and can be viewed by small groups during normal working hours by prior arrangement, after going through appropriate security procedures.
{{clear}}
==Other Eglinton Tournament trophies== [[File:Ewer or Race Cup by Edmund Cotterill.jpg|thumb|upright|A silver Ewer or Race Cup by Edmund Cotterill.<ref>The Illustrated Exhibitor, Page 88</ref>]] [[File:Jerningham Wine Cooler (black background).jpg|thumb|200px|The Jerningham Wine Cooler made by Elkington's.]] A second silver trophy was presented to the Earl by 300 citizens of Glasgow.<ref name="E2">Eglinton Fair. Page 2</ref> In 2014 a silver statuette measuring 44cm in height representing a knight in full armour with a jousting lance and a horse bearing the Earl of Eglinton's coat of arms was acquired by the East Ayrshire Leisure Trust on behalf of [[East Ayrshire Council]]. It is believed this is the only surviving part of the "second silver trophy" and that the rest of the [[candelabrum]] was melted down for its silver content after it was sold by the Earl of Eglinton in the 1920s.<ref>Kilmarnock Standard, 29-08-2014, Page 17</ref> The silver hallmark shows that the statuette dates to 1840, three years before the Eglinton Trophy was completed. The silversmiths were Benjamin Smith III of London and D.C.Rait of Glasgow.
==References== ===Notes=== {{reflist|2}}
===Sources=== {{refbegin}} # Anstruther, Ian (1986) ''The Knight and the Umbrella''. Gloucester : Alan Sutton. {{ISBN|0-86299-302-4}}. # Girouard, Mark (1981). ''The Return to Camelot. Chivalry and the English Gentleman.'' London : Yale Press. {{ISBN|0-300-02739-7}}. # The Illustrated Exhibitor. (1851). London : John Cassell. # Montgomeries of Eglinton. Strathclyde Department of Education. Ayr Division. # Eglinton Fair. Circa 1930. Privately published. # The Illustrated Exhibitor. 1851. London : John Cassell. {{refend}} {{commons category|Eglinton Trophy}}
==Bibliography== # Eglinton Tournament 1839 (1989). Irvine Development Corporation.
