revision.text:
{{Infobox Song Contest | name = Eurovision Song Contest | year = 1976 | theme = | size = 250px | logo = ESC 1976 logo.png | semi1 = | semi2 = | final = 3 April 1976 | presenters = [[Corry Brokken]] | exsupervisor = [[Clifford Brown (scrutineer)|Clifford Brown]] | conductor = [[Jan Steulen]] | director = Theo Ordeman | winner = {{esc|United Kingdom|y=1976}}
"[[Save Your Kisses for Me]]" | vote = Each country awarded 12, 10, 8-1 points to their 10 favourite songs | host = [[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting]] (NOS) | venue = [[World Forum (The Hague)|Nederlands Congresgebouw]]
[[The Hague]], [[Netherlands]] | entries = 18 | debut = None | return = {{unbulleted list|{{Esc|Austria}}|{{Esc|Greece}}}} | withdraw = {{unbulleted list|{{Esc|Malta}}|{{Esc|Sweden}}|{{Esc|Turkey}}}} | null = None | interval = [[Dutch Swing College Band|The Dutch Swing College Band]] | opening = | Green = Y | Green SA = | Purple = | Red = | Yellow = Y }} The '''[[Eurovision Song Contest]] 1976''' was the 21st edition of the contest hosted by [[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting|NOS]] and held in [[The Hague]], [[Netherlands]]. The arena for the event was the [[World Forum (The Hague)|Nederlands Congrescentrum]]. [[Teach-In (band)|Teach-In]]'s victory in [[Stockholm]] the previous year gave The Netherlands the right to host the contest for the third time. The Contest was won by [[Brotherhood of Man]], who sang "[[Save Your Kisses for Me]]" in [[English language|English]], representing the [[United Kingdom]].{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=292|title=Eurovision Song Contest 1976|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=15 August 2012}} == Location == {{details|topic=the host city|The Hague}} [[File:Statenhal Sebas Veldhuisen.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Nederlands Congresgebouw – host venue of the 1976 contest.]] The Hague is the seat of government of the [[Kingdom of the Netherlands]] and the capital city of the [[Provinces of the Netherlands|province]] of [[South Holland]]. It is also the third largest city of the Netherlands, after [[Amsterdam]] and [[Rotterdam]]. Located in the west of the Netherlands, The Hague is in the centre of the [[Haaglanden]] [[conurbation]] and lies at the southwest corner of the larger [[Randstad]] conurbation. The contest took place at the Congresgebouw (presently known as the ''[[World Forum (The Hague)|World Forum]]''). The venue was constructed in 1969. == Format == The scoring system introduced in the previous year's competition returned in 1976. Each jury gave 12 points to the best song, 10 to the second best, then 8 to the third, and then 7 to 1 (from fourth to tenth best song, according to the jury). Unlike today, the points were not given in order (from 1 up to 12), but in the order the songs were performed. The current procedure was not established until [[Eurovision Song Contest 1980|1980]]. == Participating countries == {{Further|List of countries in the Eurovision Song Contest}} Sweden, Malta and Turkey withdrew from this contest reducing the number of participating countries down to eighteen from the previous competitions record of nineteen countries that took part. Austria and Greece returned to the contest. [[Sweden]] withdrew from the contest, as the broadcaster [[Sveriges Radio]] (SR) did not have enough money to host another contest if Sweden won again. A new rule was therefore introduced that in the future each broadcaster participating would have to pay a part of the cost of staging the contest. As the author and historian [[John Kennedy O'Connor]] notes in his book ''The Eurovision Song Contest – The Official History'', there had been public demonstrations in Sweden against the contest, which also played a part in SR's decision to withdraw.{{cite book|last=O'Connor|first=John Kennedy|title=The Eurovision Song Contest: The Official History|publisher=Carlton Books|location=UK|year=2007|pages=64–67|isbn=978-1-84442-994-3}} The same book also notes that the victorious song went on to become the biggest selling winning single in the history of the contest and won with 80.39% of the possible maximum score; a record under the voting system introduced in 1975.{{cite book|last=O'Connor|first=John Kennedy|title=The Eurovision Song Contest: The Official History|publisher=Carlton Books|location=UK|year=2007|isbn=978-1-84442-994-3}} [[Malta]], having selected Enzo Guzman with the song "Sing Your Song, Country Boy" to represent them, then withdrew from the contest for undisclosed reasons, as the singer has confirmed. Malta would not return to the competition until 1991. The entry from [[Greece]] aroused controversy as it was about the [[Turkish invasion of Cyprus]]. The previous year Greece had withdrawn from the contest in protest over this matter. This year it was Turkey's turn to withdraw. [[Liechtenstein]] attempted to submit an entry to the contest, but as they had no broadcasting service of their own, they were not allowed to. Their entry would have been "Little Cowboy" by Biggi Bachmann.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovisionsongs.net/nononever.htm|title=No, No, Never!!! - Songs That Did Not Make It To Eurovision|publisher=''eurovisionsongs.net''|accessdate=2009-07-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301032000/http://www.eurovisionsongs.net/nononever.htm|archivedate=2009-03-01|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/h2g2/A22080368|title=The Eurovision Song Contest 1956 – present|date=2007-04-26|publisher=''[[BBC]]''|accessdate=2009-07-23}} === Conductors === Each performance had a [[conducted|conductor]] who [[maestro]] the orchestra. {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} *{{Esc|United Kingdom}} - [[Alyn Ainsworth]] *{{Esc|Switzerland}} - Mario Robbiani *{{Esc|Germany}} - [[Les Humphries]] *{{Esc|Israel}} - [[Matti Caspi]] *{{Esc|Luxembourg}} - Jo Plée *{{Esc|Belgium}} - Michel Bernholc *{{Esc|Ireland}}- [[Noel Kelehan]] *{{Esc|Netherlands}} - [[Harry van Hoof]] *{{Esc|Norway}} - [[Frode Thingnæs]] *{{Esc|Greece}} - Michalis Rozakis *{{Esc|Finland}} - [[Ossi Runne]] *{{Esc|Spain|1945}} - Juan Barcons *{{Esc|Italy}} - [[Maurizio Fabrizio]] *{{Esc|Austria}} - [[Erich Kleinschuster]] *{{Esc|Portugal}} - Thilo Krasmann *{{Esc|Monaco}} - [[Raymond Donnez]] *{{Esc|France}} - Tony Rallo *{{Esc|Yugoslavia}} - Esad Arnautalić {{div col end}} === Returning artists === Four artists returned to the contest in 1976. [[Fredi (singer)|Fredi]] who represented [[Finland in the Eurovision Song Contest|Finland]] in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1967|1967]], [[Sandra Reemer]] returned having represented [[Netherlands in the Eurovision Song Contest|Netherlands]] in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1972|1972]], [[Peter, Sue and Marc]] also returned having represented [[Switzerland in the Eurovision Song Contest|Switzerland]] in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1971|1971]], and finally [[Anne-Karine Strøm]] represented [[Norway in the Eurovision Song Contest|Norway]] again having last done so in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1974|1974]]; she repeated her finishing result by coming last once more. == Results == The following tables reflect the officially verified scores given by each jury, adjusted after the transmission. During the live broadcast, France failed to announce the 4 points they awarded to Yugoslavia, an error overlooked by the scrutineer, Clifford Brown. Thus in the live show, Norway were placed 17th and Yugoslavia 18th. After the broadcast, the scores were adjusted and the two nations swapped places, with Yugoslavia's score being adjusted from 6 to 10 points, moving Norway down to last place. {| class="sortable wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! background:#aaa;" | |} === 12 points === Below is a summary of all 12 points in the final: {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- ! N. !! Contestant !! Voting nation |- | 7 || '''[[United Kingdom in the Eurovision Song Contest 1976|United Kingdom]]''' || Belgium, Greece, Israel, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Switzerland |- | 5 || [[France in the Eurovision Song Contest 1976|France]] || Austria, Germany, Monaco, Netherlands, Yugoslavia |- | rowspan=6 | 1 | [[Belgium in the Eurovision Song Contest 1976|Belgium]] || Finland |- | [[Italy in the Eurovision Song Contest 1976|Italy]] || Ireland |- | [[Ireland in the Eurovision Song Contest 1976|Ireland]] || Italy |- | [[Monaco in the Eurovision Song Contest 1976|Monaco]] || Luxembourg |- | [[Portugal in the Eurovision Song Contest 1976|Portugal]] || France |- | [[Switzerland in the Eurovision Song Contest 1976|Switzerland]] || United Kingdom |} == International broadcasts and voting == The table below shows the order in which votes were cast during the 1976 contest along with the spokesperson who was responsible for announcing the votes for their respective country. === Voting and spokespersons === {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} # {{Esc|United Kingdom}} - [[Ray Moore (broadcaster)|Ray Moore]] # {{Esc|Switzerland}} - Michel StockerBaumann, Peter Ramón (OGAE Switzerland) # {{Esc|Germany}} - Ekkehard Böhmer # {{Esc|Israel}} - Yitzhak Shim'oni{{cite web|url=http://sf.tapuz.co.il/shirshur-262-1949782.htm |title=פורום אירוויזיון |publisher=Sf.tapuz.co.il |date=1999-09-13 |accessdate=2012-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111008025322/http://sf.tapuz.co.il/shirshur-262-1949782.htm |archivedate=October 8, 2011 }} # {{Esc|Luxembourg}} - Jacques Harvey # {{Esc|Belgium}} - André Hagon # {{Esc|Ireland}} - Brendan Balfe # {{Esc|Netherlands}} – Dick van Bommel # {{Esc|Norway}} - Sverre Christophersen # {{Esc|Greece}} - Irini Gavala # {{Esc|Finland}} - Erkki Vihtonen{{cite web|url=http://www.viisukuppila.fi/phpBB3/yleista/topic1578-30.html |title=Selostajat ja taustalaulajat lĂ¤pi vuosien? • Viisukuppila |publisher=Viisukuppila.fi |date= |accessdate=2012-08-10}} # {{flag|Spain|1945}} - [[José María Íñigo]] # {{Esc|Italy}} - [[Rosanna Vaudetti]] # {{Esc|Austria}} - Jenny Pippal # {{Esc|Portugal}} - Ana Zanatti{{cite web|url=http://21595.activeboard.com/t3895343/comentadores-do-esc/ |title=Comentadores Do ESC – escportugalforum.pt.vu | o forum eurovisivo português |publisher=21595.activeboard.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120421114332/http://21595.activeboard.com/t3895343/comentadores-do-esc |archivedate=April 21, 2012 }} # {{Esc|Monaco}} - Carole Chabrier # {{Esc|France}} - Marc Menant # {{Esc|Yugoslavia}} - [[Sandi Čolnik]] {{div col end}} === Television commentators === Each national broadcaster [with the exception of Israel] also sent a commentator to the contest, in order to provide coverage of the contest in their own native language. {{Col-begin}} {{Col-2}} * {{flag|Austria}} - [[Ernst Grissemann]] ([[ORF2|FS2]]) * {{flag|Belgium}} - Georges Désir ([[La Une|RTB]]),{{cite web|url=http://eurovision.vosforums.com/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=5032 |title=Concours Eurovision de la Chanson • Consulter le sujet – Commentateurs des pays francophones |publisher=Eurovision.vosforums.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-10}} [[Luc Appermont]] ([[één|BRT]])Adriaens, Manu & Loeckx-Van Cauwenberge, Joken. Blijven kiken!. Lannoo, Belgium. 2003 {{ISBN|90-209-5274-9}} * {{flag|Finland}} - Vesa Nuotio ([[YLE TV1]]){{cite web|url=http://www.viisukuppila.fi/phpBB3/yleista/topic1578.html?sid=4004772ec986da0c3795a6f5dd54f0d4 |title=Selostajat ja taustalaulajat lĂ¤pi vuosien? • Viisukuppila |publisher=Viisukuppila.fi |date= |accessdate=2012-08-10}} * {{flag|France}} - Jean-Claude Massoulier ([[TF1]]){{cite web|author=Christian Masson |url=http://songcontest.free.fr/bdd/cec1976.htm |title=1976 – La Haye |publisher=Songcontest.free.fr |date= |accessdate=2012-08-10}} * {{flag|Germany}} - [[Werner Veigel]] ([[Das Erste|ARD Deutsches Fernsehen]]){{cite web|url=http://www.ecgermany.de/archiv/1976esc.htm |title=Eurovision Song Contest 1974 |publisher=Ecgermany.de |date= |accessdate=2012-08-10}} * {{flag|Greece|old}} - Jo Vestly ([[NRK1|NRK]])Dyrseth, Seppo (OGAE Norway){{cite web|url=http://www.nrk.no/debatt/index.php?showtopic=87458&pid=1343226&mode=threaded&start= |title=Hvem kommenterte før Jostein Pedersen? - Debattforum |publisher=Nrk.no |date= |accessdate=2012-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102174151/http://www.nrk.no/debatt/index.php?showtopic=87458&pid=1343226&mode=threaded&start= |archivedate=November 2, 2012 }} * {{flag|Portugal}} - [[Eládio Clímaco]] ([[RTP1]]) * {{flag|Spain|1945}} - [[José Luis Uribarri]] ([[TVE1]]){{cite web |url=http://eurosongcontest.phpbb3.es/viewtopic.php?f=57&t=20310&start=45 |title=FORO FESTIVAL DE EUROVISIÓN • Ver Tema – Uribarri comentarista Eurovision 2010 |publisher=Eurosongcontest.phpbb3.es |date= |accessdate=2012-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317062647/http://eurosongcontest.phpbb3.es/viewtopic.php?f=57&t=20310&start=45 |archivedate=2012-03-17 |df= }} * {{flag|Switzerland}} - Erik Heyerdahl ([[NRK P1]]) * {{flag|Portugal}} - Amadeu Meireles ([[RDP Antena 1]]) * {{flag|United Kingdom}} - [[Terry Wogan]] ([[BBC Radio 2]]), Andrew Pastouna and Richard Astbury ([[BFBS|British Forces Radio]]){{cite book|last=Roxburgh|first=Gordon|title=Songs For Europe – The United Kingdom at the Eurovision Song Contest Volume Two: The 1970's|publisher=[[Telos Publishing]]|location=UK|year=2014|page=116|isbn=978-1-84583-065-6}} * {{flag|Sweden}} (Non-participating country) – Ursula Richter ([[SR P3]]){{cite web|url=http://www.infosajten.com/esc/esc/swedishspokesmen.html |title=Infosajten.com |publisher=Infosajten.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120718022509/http://www.infosajten.com/esc/esc/swedishspokesmen.html |archivedate=July 18, 2012 }} {{Col-end}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Eurovision Song Contest 1976}} * {{Official website|http://www.eurovision.tv/}} {{Eurovision years}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1976}} {{Eurovision Song Contest's Greatest Hits}} [[Category:Eurovision Song Contest by year]] [[Category:1976 in music]] [[Category:1976 in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Eurovision Song Contest 1976| ]] [[Category:20th century in The Hague]] [[Category:April 1976 events in Europe]] [[Category:Events in The Hague]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{notability|date=October 2011}} {{no footnotes|date=October 2011}} {{context|date=April 2012}} {{advert|date=April 2011}} }} '''Searchology 2009''' was an event hosted by [[Google]] announcing several novel changes in the Google search options. In previous years Google has used this platform to showcase two significant improvements in its search: Universal Search and [[Google Personalized Search|Personalized Search]]. Searchology 2009 focused on the users' intent. == Wonder Wheel == {{Unreferenced section|date=October 2017}} Wonder Wheel provides the user with a flash based interface having the searched query in the middle and the related queries at its branches. The text based results are still available but shifted rightwards. As the user clicks on the related query, the Wonder Wheel expands and the results at the right hand side of the page changes. The main aim of the Wonder Wheel is to guide the user to reach to the relevant resource in an intuitive manner. == Google Squared == When a search is made via Google Squared, the results are presented in the form of rows and columns. Further, these results can be exported to an online spreadsheet program whereby it can be stored into a database. Although it was presented to the group of media and people from search industry on May 12, 2009, yet it was not made public as Google’s Associate Product Manager Alex Komoroske admitted that owing to the search flaws in Google Squared, later it was launched in [[Google Labs]] on June 3, 2009. == Rich Snippet == Rich Snippet{{Cite web|title = Rich Snippets|url = https://developers.google.com/structured-data/rich-snippets/|website = Google Developers|accessdate = 2015-09-14}} displays additional data from other pages about the resources being displayed in the search result. In order to work, webmasters must incorporate open standards such as [[microdata (HTML)|microdata]], [[microformat]]s or [[RDFa]], and [[JSON-LD]] in their web pages. Google does not guarantee that the use of these open standards will result in rich snippets. == Rich Card == On May 17, 2016, Google announce a new search result format builder called "Rich Card". Rich cards{{Cite web|title = Rich Card|url = https://seoleap.blogspot.com/2016/08/rich-card-structure-data-in-search-console.html/|website = SEO Leap}} are similar like Rich snippet, use schema.org Structured markup to showcase the content in a new visual format. Rich card for four content categories: Recipes, Events, Product and Reviews. == Featured snippets== When a user asks a question in Google Search, we might show a search result in a special featured snippet block at the top of the search results page. This featured snippet block includes a summary of the answer, extracted from a webpage, plus a link to the page, the page title and URL.{{Cite web|title = Featured snippets in search |url = https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/6229325|website = Search Console Help}} {{cite news|url=https://seo.whoops.com.tw/seo/the-study-shows-featured-snippet-will-have-bad-effect/|title=2017研究顯示：Google精選摘要會對排名產生負面影響|date=2017-06-01|publisher=Whoops SEO|accessdate = 2017-06-13}} ==Notes and references== {{reflist}} *[http://www.shareholder.com/visitors/event/build2/mediapresentation.cfm?companyid=GOOGPR&mediaid=36947&mediauserid=0&TID=639719735:B88A7CEE520E515C1F37669072FF6E9C&popupcheck=0&shexp=200905130053&shkey=4b9bd9506dda3dc36aae67f29b229da4# Google Searchology Webcast] *[http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2009/05/more-search-options-and-other-updates.html Google Official Blog] *[http://searchengineland.com/live-blogging-google-searchology-19032 Search Engine Land] *[https://www.google.com/support/webmasters/bin/answer.py?answer=99170 Microformats or RDFa] *[http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2009/05/google-searchology-search-marissa-mayer-udi-manber.html Los Angeles Times] ===Speakers=== 1. Udi Manber, VP, Engineering (Core Search)
2. Patrick Riley, Software Engineer
3. Scott Huffman, Engineering Director
4. Marissa Mayer, VP, Search Products and User Experience
5. Nandu Jankiram, Associate Product Manager
6. Alex Komoroske, Associate Product Manager
7. Kavi Goel, Product Manager
8. John Taylor, Software Engineer {{Google Inc.|state=expanded}} [[Category:Google events|Searchology]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Benefit concerts]]; added [[Category:Benefit concerts in the United States]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Infobox television | show_name = ''Hurricane Sandy: Coming Together'' | genre = [[Benefit concert]] | starring = [[Christina Aguilera]]
[[Jon Bon Jovi]]
[[Billy Joel]]
[[Jimmy Fallon]]
[[Steven Tyler]]
[[Joe Perry (musician)|Joe Perry]]
[[Brad Whitford]]
[[Sting (musician)|Sting]]
[[Mary J. Blige]]
[[Bruce Springsteen]] | country = [[United States]] | language = English | runtime = 1 hour | first_aired = November 2, 2012 }} '''''Hurricane Sandy: Coming Together''''' was a one-hour, [[Television advertisement|commercial]]-free [[benefit concert]] [[television special]] that aired [[simulcast]] in the United States on November 2, 2012 at 8 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|ET]]/[[Central Time Zone (Americas)|CT]] [[live television|live]] from [[New York City]] and [[Broadcast delay|tape delay]]ed [[Mountain Time Zone|MT]] and [[Pacific Time Zone|PT]]. The special raised money for the relief efforts from the aftermath of [[Hurricane Sandy]], which had struck the U.S. Northeast four days earlier. All proceeds went to the [[American Red Cross]]. ==Production== The concert was an effort of [[NBC]] and its affiliated channels, and its origins lay with [[Today (U.S. TV program)|''Today'' show]] anchor [[Matt Lauer]] suggesting it to [[NBCUniversal]] CEO [[Steve Burke (businessman)|Steve Burke]].{{cite news | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/2012/11/01/nbc-sandy-relief-telethon/1674991/ | title=Matt Lauer suggestion starts starry Sandy telethon | first=Gary | last=Levin | newspaper=[[USA Today]] | date=November 1, 2012}} It featured appearances and musical performances mostly by those associated with the affected areas, especially [[New Jersey]] and [[New York (state)|New York]].{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/04/arts/music/songs-of-sympathy-at-hurricane-sandy-concert.html?_r=0 | title=Songs of Sympathy and Endurance, From Voices Touched by Hurricane | first=Jon | last=Pareles | authorlink=Jon Pareles | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | date=November 3, 2012 | page=A31}} At least one, [[Long Island]]'s [[Billy Joel]], had properties damaged by the storm. Organization for the production was put together in a hurry, in the face of logistical and transportation difficulties in the wake of the storm.{{cite news | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/hurricane-sandy-benefit-plans-came-together-overnight-say-organizers-20121101 | title=Hurricane Sandy Benefit Plans Came Together Overnight, Say Organizers | first=Steve | last=Knopper | magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] | date=November 1, 2012}} The event took place at ''[[The Dr. Oz Show]]''{{'s}} Studio 6A at the [[NBC Studios (New York)|NBC Studios]] in [[30 Rockefeller Plaza]] in New York before a small audience. The event followed somewhat in the manner and format of ''[[Shelter from the Storm: A Concert for the Gulf Coast]]'', which raised money for the relief efforts from the aftermath of [[Hurricane Katrina]] in 2005, and other recent disaster relief telethons. Approximately $23 million was raised by ''Hurricane Sandy: Coming Together'' for the [[American Red Cross]].{{cite news | magazine=[[TV Guide]] | title=Hurricane Sandy telethon raises nearly $23 million | first=Robyn | last=Ross | date=November 5, 2012 | url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Hurricane-Sandy-Telethon-1055520.aspx?rss=breakingnews&partnerid=worldnow&profileid=01}} ==Musical guests and performances== The running order of musical performances was:{{cite news | url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/music/index.ssf/2012/11/hurricane_sandy_coming_togethe.html | title='Hurricane Sandy: Coming Together' telethon (live video stream and blog) | first=Jay | last=Lustig | newspaper=[[Newark Star-Ledger]] | date=November 2, 2012}} *[[Christina Aguilera]], "[[Beautiful (Christina Aguilera song)|Beautiful]]" *[[Jon Bon Jovi]], "[[Who Says You Can't Go Home]]"/"[[Livin' on a Prayer]]" *[[Billy Joel]], "[[Miami 2017 (Seen the Lights Go Out on Broadway)]]" *[[Jimmy Fallon]], [[Steven Tyler]] and [[Billy Joel]] (piano and vocals), with [[Bruce Springsteen]] (guitar and backing vocals) and [[Mark Rivera]] (backing vocals), "[[Under the Boardwalk]]" *Steven Tyler, [[Joe Perry (musician)|Joe Perry]] and [[Brad Whitford]] (all from [[Aerosmith]]), "[[Dream On (Aerosmith song)|Dream On]]" *[[Sting (musician)|Sting]], "[[Message in a Bottle (song)|Message in a Bottle]]" *[[Mary J. Blige]], "The Living Proof" *[[Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band]], "[[Land of Hope and Dreams]]"/"[[People Get Ready (song)|People Get Ready]]" Spoken appearances were made by [[Matt Lauer]], [[Tina Fey]], [[Jimmy Fallon]], [[Jon Stewart]], [[Brian Williams]], [[Danny DeVito]], [[Al Roker]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], and [[Kevin Bacon]]. Clips from [[NBC News]] were also aired, showing some of the physical and emotional devastation the storm had caused. Some of the musical acts made their own remarks before their songs, including Aguilera, who opened the show by stating that she was born in [[Staten Island]].{{cite news | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/springsteen-leads-stars-in-sandy-benefit-20121103 | title=Springsteen Leads Stars in Sandy Benefit | first=James | last=Sullivan | magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] | date=November 3, 2012}} Performances were generally stripped-down arrangements of old songs that either reflected feelings of distress or expressed sympathy and offered hope and encouragement; ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' wrote that the songs "sometimes seemed written for the occasion". In addition, Joel and Blige both modified their songs' lyrics to fit what had taken place. Some microphone failures marked the group rendition of "Under the Boardwalk", the main lead vocal for which was given to Fallon, inspiring a bit of jocularity in the otherwise somber program. ==Broadcast networks== {{inc-video}} ===United States=== ====Broadcasters==== * [[NBC]] ====Cable and satellite==== * [[MSNBC]] * [[Bravo (U.S. TV channel)|Bravo]] * [[CNBC]] * [[E!]] * [[G4 Media|G4]] * [[Style Network]] * [[USA Network]] * [[NBC Sports Network]] * [[Syfy]] * [[The Weather Channel]] * [[Universal HD]] * [[Comcast Network]] * [[HBO]] * [[Sirius Satellite Radio]] ====Radio==== * [[WKXW|New Jersey 101.5]] * [[WWZY|The Breeze 99.7]] * [[WXTU|92.5 XTU]] * [[WBZO|B-103.1]] * [[WXPK|107.1 The Peak]] * [[WBEB|B101 FM]] * [[WAXQ|Q104.3]] ==See also== *[[12-12-12: The Concert for Sandy Relief]] *[[Hand in Hand: A Benefit for Hurricane Relief]] (2017) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.nbc.com/hurricane-sandy-coming-together/ Official website] {{Hurricane Sandy series}} [[Category:2012 in American television]] [[Category:2012 television specials]] [[Category:American telethons]] [[Category:Benefit concerts in the United States]] [[Category:Hurricane Sandy]] [[Category:Music television specials]] [[Category:Simulcasts]] [[Category:2012 in New York (state)]]

revision.comment: /* Architecture */
revision.text:
{{For|the theatre in Moldova|Bălți National Theatre}} {{Infobox theatre |name = Vasile Alecsandri National Theatre
Teatrul Național „Vasile Alecsandri” din Iași |image = Teatrul Național „Vasile Alecsandri” din Iași.JPG |image_size = 250px |caption = Front view |pushpin_map = |pushpin_map_caption = |address = 18 Agatha Bârsescu Street |city = [[Iași]] |country = Romania |architect = [[Fellner & Helmer]] |owner = |capacity = Large Hall 850 seats
The Cube Theatre 180 seats
Teofil Vâlcu Hall 100 seats
The Theatre Plant 100 seats |type = [[List of national theatres|National theatre]] |opened = 1840 |yearsactive = |rebuilt = 1894-1896 |closed = |othernames = Great Theatre of Moldavia |production = Fântâna Blanduziei http://www.imagoromaniae.ro/articole/teatre-edificii-societati-si-asociatii-culturale.htmlhttp://infotravelguide.ro/2010/06/teatrul-national-vasile-alecsandri-din-iasi/ |currentuse = |website = [http://www.teatrulnationaliasi.ro www.teatrulnationaliasi.ro] }} The '''Iași National Theatre''' ([[Romanian language|Romanian]]: Teatrul Național Vasile Alecsandri) in [[Iași]], [[Romania]], is the oldest national theatre and one of the most prestigious theatrical institutions in Romania. In 1956, it was given the name of the renowned Romanian playwright and poet [[Vasile Alecsandri]]. ==History== [[File:TNI 1846.jpg|thumb|left|The old building of the National Theatre, 1846]] One of the first theatrical performance in Romanian language, was organized by [[Gheorghe Asachi]], and held in the capital of [[Moldavia]], Jassy/Iași, on 27 September 1816.[https://books.google.com/books?id=-0mJ7blUGtQC&pg=PA166&lpg=PA166&dq=first+theatrical+performance+in+Romanian&source=bl&ots=tiSaCCg2J7&sig=-4Md-LKCHVTN2O_rilvV5Ta-m9c&hl=en&ei=NZAvTK8chJY468DZ1AE&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CCEQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=first%20theatrical%20performance%20in%20Romanian&f=false History of the literary cultures of East-Central Europe] In 1834, a Romanian production took place in Iași on the stage of the Théâtre de varieté, built in 1832 for the French Fouraux troupe. The National Theatre was founded on 15 May 1840, as the ''Great Theatre of Moldavia'', when the Romanian language troupe, led by [[Costache Caragiale|Costache Caragiali]], was united with the French troupe, under a single direction of [[Vasile Alecsandri]] and the management of Costache Caragiali.[https://books.google.com/books?id=8qMTPAPFGXUC&pg=PA933&lpg=PA933&dq=first+first+theatre+performance+Romanian&source=bl&ots=uK_HV7btXh&sig=64VSDq6lqoxuIc1EYzH9dt2xN_c&hl=en&ei=nn8vTITwL8j_OcuDiIEC&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CDQQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=first%20first%20theatre%20performance%20Romanian&f=false The Cambridge guide to theatre] On 22 December 1846, a new audience hall was inaugurated in the former mansion of [[List of rulers of Moldavia|Prince]] [[Mihail Sturdza]], on the [[Seven hills of Iași|Hill of Copou]].[http://en.teatrulnationaliasi.ro/pages/theatre History] ==Building== On the night of 17/18 February 1888, the theatre building was destroyed by the fire. The efforts to build the new theatre edifice culminated in 1894 when a contract was signed with the Viennese architects [[Ferdinand Fellner|Ferdinand Fellner and Hermann Helmer]], who designed several theatres and palaces across Europe, including the theatres in: [[Cluj-Napoca]], [[Oradea]], [[Timișoara]] and [[Chernivtsi]] (Romanian: Cernăuți). [[File:Teatrul Naţional Interior.jpg|thumb|left|The main auditorium]] For the building work, a contract was signed with a Bucharest company, and the power station was built by a company from Berlin. The Theatre’s power station also supplied with electricity the 12 electric-arc lamps lighting the Theatre Square, marking the beginning of electrification in the city of Iași. The works to building took two years, and on 1 and 2 December 1896, the inauguration festivities took place with [[Alexander Flechtenmacher|Flechtenmacher]]'s ''National Overture'', the vaudevilles ''Muza de la Burdujeni'' (''The Muse from Burdujeni'') by [[Costache Negruzzi]] and ''Cinel-cinel'' (''The Riddle'') by Vasile Alecsandri, as well as the verse comedy ''Poetul romantic'' (''The Romantic Poet'') by [[Matei Millo]]. Nowadays, the building also hosts the [[Iași Romanian National Opera]]. The Iași National Theatre building is listed in the [[National Register of Historic Monuments in Romania|National Register of Historic Monuments]].[http://patrimoniu.gov.ro/images/LMI/LMI-2010_IS.pdf The Romanian Register of Historical Monuments in Iași County] ===Architecture=== With a [[Neoclassic style|Neoclassic]] exterior and a richly decorated interior in [[Rococo]] and [[Baroque]] styles, the building is considered one of the most elegant in Romania.[http://www.romaniatourism.com/iasi.html IASI - City Highlights] at romaniatourism.com The main auditorium is organised in stalls, boxes and a balcony. The curtain painted by the Viennese M. Lenz, presents in the middle, an allegory of life with its three stages and, to the right side, the allegory of [[Greater Romania|Romanian Unification]]. The left-hand side, painted by Lenz’s apprentice, differs from the rest of the curtain in style and colouring. The ceiling and the iron curtain were painted by Alexander Goltz. The iron curtain, which completely separates the scene from the hall, shows ornaments placed symmetrically, while the ceiling has as a narrative basis the Archetypal Story, shown in paradisiacal allegories, with nymphs and cupids framed in rococo stucco.[https://sites.google.com/site/teatrulnationaliasi/home/istoric The main theatre building] The 1,418 electric lights and the chandelier with 109 Venetian crystal lamps light up a playhouse with a unique architectural personality. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|National Theatre in Iaşi}} * [http://www.teatrulnationaliasi.ro/en/ Official website] {{coord missing|Romania}} {{Iași Landmarks}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Iasi National Theatre}} [[Category:Historic monuments in Iași County|Theatre]] [[Category:Culture in Iași|Theatre]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Iași|Theatre]] [[Category:Theatres in Iași]] [[Category:National theatres]] [[Category:Neoclassical architecture]] [[Category:Fellner & Helmer buildings]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1896]] [[Category:Event venues established in 1840]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox terrorist attack |title=July 2010 Kampala attacks |image=July 2010 Kampala attacks.png |caption=Map of the two attack locations |location=[[Kampala]], Uganda |target=Crowds watching broadcasts of the [[2010 FIFA World Cup Final|FIFA World Cup Final]] |date=11 July 2010 |time-begin=10:25 pm |time-end=11:18 pm, approximately<ref name="umc"/> |timezone=[[UTC]]+3 |type= [[Suicide bombing]] |fatalities=74<ref name="bbc20100712"/><ref name="ap20100712"/> |injuries= 71<ref name="bbc20100712"/><ref name="cnn20100712">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/africa/07/12/uganda.bombings/ |title=Death toll in Uganda bomb attacks at 60 |publisher=CNN|first=Faith |last=Karimi |date=12 July 2010 |accessdate=12 July 2010}}</ref> |perps=[[Al-Shabaab (militant group)|Al-Shabaab]] |susperps= |Footage= }} {{Campaignbox War in Somalia (2009–)}} The '''July 2010 Kampala attacks''' were suicide bombings carried out against crowds watching a screening of the [[2010 FIFA World Cup Final]] match at two locations in [[Kampala]], the capital city of [[Uganda]], on {{Nowrap|11 July}} 2010. The attacks left 74 dead and 71 injured. [[Al-Shabaab (militant group)|Al-Shabaab]], an [[Islamist]] militia based in [[Somalia]] that has ties to [[Al-Qaeda]], claimed responsibility for the blasts as retaliation for Ugandan support for [[African Union Mission to Somalia|AMISOM]].<ref name="aol">{{cite web|title=Uganda Blasts: American Killed, Missionaries Hurt|url=http://www.aolnews.com/world/article/uganda-bombing-american-aid-worker-nate-henn-killed-six-us-missionaries-injured/19550468|date=12 July 2010|accessdate=12 July 2010|publisher=AOL News|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100713201244/http://www.aolnews.com/world/article/uganda-bombing-american-aid-worker-nate-henn-killed-six-us-missionaries-injured/19550468|archivedate=13 July 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In March 2015, the trial of 13 Kenyan, Ugandan and Tanzanian alleged perpetrators of the bombings began at the High Court of Uganda.<ref name="Lotoutsb"/>
==Background== The [[Al-Shabaab (militant group)|Al-Shabaab]] militant group grew into a potent force against the [[Transitional Federal Government]] (TFG) of [[Somalia]] and threatened attacks against foreign and [[AMISOM]] troops deployed against it in the country, including those from [[Uganda]]. The July 2010 attack in [[Kampala]] was seen as revenge against the Ugandan forces' presence in Somalia.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/World/Rest-of-World/Barely-4-years-old-Shabaab-is-Qaidas-face-in-east-Africa-/articleshow/6160474.cms | work=The Times Of India | title=Barely 4 years old, Shabaab is Qaida's face in east Africa | date=13 July 2010}}</ref> [[Al Qaeda]] was also [[Al-Qaeda involvement in Africa#Somalia and Kenya|rumoured]] to have been involved in Somalia. The Kampala attack followed American warnings of attacks on [[Air Uganda]] planes in 2010.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/8449965.stm |work=BBC News | title=US warns of attacks on Air Uganda | date=9 January 2010}}</ref>
==Attacks== The first bombing was carried out at a restaurant called the ''Ethiopian Village'', situated in the [[Kabalagala]] neighbourhood, with many of the victims foreigners.<ref name=monitor>{{cite web|url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/-/688334/956212/-/x22qke/-/ |title=50 die in Kampala bomb blasts |date=12 July 2010 | work=[[The Monitor (Uganda)|Daily Monitor]] |accessdate=12 July 2010}}</ref> Fifteen people died in this attack.<ref name="ap20100712">{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hzHMeIMsFmUA1bDTDUdeL_hCMbjAD9GT7O700|title=64 die in bomb attacks in Uganda during World Cup|last=Kron|first=Josh|agency=Associated Press |date=12 July 2010 |accessdate=12 July 2010}}</ref> The Kabalagala bombing occurred during the [[2010 FIFA World Cup Final]].<ref name="NV over 40">{{cite web|url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/12/725545 |title=Over 40 die in Kampala bomb blasts |work=[[New Vision]] |date=12 July 2010 |accessdate=12 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100715054623/http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/12/725545 |archivedate=15 July 2010 |df= }}</ref>
The second attack, consisting of two explosions in quick succession, occurred at {{Nowrap|11:18 pm}} at [[Kyadondo Rugby Club]] in [[Nakawa]], where state-run newspaper ''[[New Vision]]'' was hosting a screening of the match.<ref name=NV>{{cite web|url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/10/10/725548 |title=33 die in Kampala bomb attacks |work=[[New Vision]] |date=11 July 2010 |accessdate=12 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100714023549/http://newvision.co.ug/D/10/10/725548 |archivedate=14 July 2010 |df= }}</ref> According to eyewitnesses, there was an explosion near the 90th minute of the match, followed seconds later by a second explosion that knocked out the lights at the field.<ref name="cnn20100712-A">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/africa/07/12/uganda.bombings/?hpt=T1 |title=Death toll rises to 64 in Uganda twin bombings |first=Faith|last=Karimi|publisher=CNN|date=12 July 2010 |accessdate=12 July 2010}}</ref> An explosion went off directly in front of a large screen that was showing the telecast from South Africa,<ref name="NV over 40"/> killing 49 people.<ref name="ap20100712"/> The discovery of a severed head and leg at the rugby field suggests that it was a [[suicide attack]] carried out by an individual.<ref name="ap20100712"/> A third unexploded vest was later found.<ref name="aljaz"/> A [[Uganda Police Force]] officer stated the total death toll as 64.<ref name="ap20100712"/> A further 71 were hospitalized, 14 of whom were treated for minor injuries and later discharged.<ref name="umc">{{cite web|url=http://www.mediacentre.go.ug/details.php?catId=4&item=922|title=Bomb Blasts in Kampala|publisher=Uganda Media Centre, Office of the President of Uganda|date=12 July 2010|accessdate=12 July 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100718085541/http://www.mediacentre.go.ug/details.php?catId=4&item=922|archivedate=18 July 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Uganda Police Force Inspector General [[Kale Kayihura]] stated, "The information we have indicates the people who have attacked the Ethiopian Village were probably targeting expatriates."<ref name="bbc20100712">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/10593771.stm |title=Twin blasts in Uganda capital Kampala kill at least 64 |work=BBC News |date=12 July 2010 |accessdate=12 July 2010}}</ref>
Initial reports of further blasts in the neighbourhoods of [[Ntinda]] and [[Bwaise]] were false.<ref name="NV over 40"/>
==Casualties== {| class="wikitable centre sortable" |+ Deaths by nationality !Country !Number |- | {{flagu|Uganda}} ! 62 |- | {{flagu|Eritrea}} ! 6 |- | {{flagu|Ethiopia}} ! 1 |- | {{flagu|Ireland}} ! 1 |- | {{flagu|Kenya}} ! 1 |- | {{flagu|Sri Lanka}} ! 1 |- | {{flagu|India}} ! 1 |- | {{flagu|United States}} ! 1 |- |- class="sortbottom" |'''Total''' ! 74 |}
Most of the dead were Ugandan. Others included: a Sri Lankan,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/lankan-among-uganda-victims--5061.html | title=Lankan killed in Uganda | publisher=[[The Daily Mirror (Sri Lanka)]] | first=Gandhya | last=Senanayake | date=13 July 2010 | accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref> an Indian,<ref name="nyt20100712-A">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/13/world/africa/13uganda.html | title=Bombers Kill More Than 60 in Attacks in Uganda Capital | work=The New York Times | first=John | last=Kron | date=12 July 2010 | accessdate=12 July 2010}}</ref> an Irish [[Lay Mission-Helpers Association|Lay]] missionary,<ref name="RTÉ1">{{cite web | url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0712/uganda.html | title=Irish woman reportedly killed in Uganda blast | publisher=RTÉ | date=12 July 2010 | accessdate=12 July 2010}}</ref><ref name="RTÉ2">{{cite web | url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0713/uganda.html | title=Irishwoman killed in Uganda was lay missionary | publisher=RTÉ | date=13 July 2010 | accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref> one American,<ref>{{cite news | title=American killed in Uganda was dedicated to service | author=Chris Reinolds Kozelle | date=14 July 2010 | publisher=CNN | url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/africa/07/12/uganda.american.killed/index.html}}</ref> one Ethiopian,<ref name="Ethiopia">[http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/africa/Ethiopians-Eritreans-Face-Double-Suspicion-in-Post-Bomb-Uganda--98627174.html Voanews.com]. Voanews.com (16 July 2010). Retrieved on 6 July 2011.</ref> six Eritreans,<ref name="Ethiopia"/> and one Kenyan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nation.co.ke/news/Kenyan-killed-in-Kampala-bombing-/1056-958052-6s70d6/index.html|title=Kenyan killed in Kampala bombing|publisher=|accessdate=29 October 2017}}</ref>
The injured also included six Methodist missionaries from a Pennsylvania church.<ref name="aol"/>
==Investigation== Ugandan police made arrests in the days following the attack.<ref name="aljaz">[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/07/201071362446995742.html English.aljazeera.net]. English.aljazeera.net (13 July 2010). Retrieved on 6 July 2011.</ref> Another Ugandan was arrested in Kenya over the attacks.<ref>[http://www.observer.ug/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=9261:ugandan-arrested-in-kenya-over-bombs&catid=34:news&Itemid=59 Obeserver.ug]. Observer.ug (14 July 2010). Retrieved on 6 July 2011.</ref> Twenty people were arrested, including several Pakistanis, and [[Interpol]] also published facial reconstructions of two suspected bombers.<ref>Simon, Ben. (18 July 2010) [https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iwUDMBbJu5U8mSxZPuXk8fJgj0qg Google.com]. Google.com. Retrieved on 6 July 2011.</ref><ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/07/2010718151113338808.html English.aljazeera.net]. English.aljazeera.net (18 July 2010). Retrieved on 6 July 2011.</ref>
Uganda's police said they had come to believe two suicide bombers were part of the attacks. Facial reconstructions of the two suspected suicide bombers suggested one was of Somali origin and the other a black African of unknown origin. "There is strong evidence that these attacks were carried out by suicide bombers." The facial identification were on two bodies which "have remained unclaimed and unidentified."<ref>[http://www.almanar.com.lb/newssite/NewsDetails.aspx?id=146822&language=en Almanar.com]{{dead link|date=July 2011}}</ref>
Three Kenyans — Hussein Hassan Agad, Mohamed Adan Abdow and Idris Magondu — were charged with 76 counts of murder. The Chief Magistrate, however, said they were not allowed to enter a plea because the court does not have jurisdiction to rule on the crime of terrorism. They are due back in court on 27 August, but will not be permitted to plead until the Directorate of Public Prosecutions decides the case is ready to move to the High Court.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/07/201073163039504737.html|title=Three charged in Uganda bombings |work=[[Al-Jazeera]] |date=31 July 2010 |accessdate=12 August 2010}}</ref> On 12 August 2010, chief of military intelligence [[James Mugira]] stated that all suspects at the time had been arrested.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i3Z4DgGCaMSYN46yqrG-4pkN-P8Q|title=All suspects in Kampala bomb attacks 'arrested' |agency=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]] |date=12 August 2010 |accessdate=12 August 2010}}</ref> On 18 August 2010, Ugandan officials charged 32 people with murder. John Kagezi, the state attorney, said four of those charged confessed to the attacks. Court Hearings were to start for the Ugandan, Kenyan and Somali nationals on 2 September 2010; though police said continued investigations were ongoing and that more arrests may follow.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/08/201081843322402397.html English.aljazeera.net]. English.aljazeera.net (18 August 2010). Retrieved on 6 July 2011.</ref>
==Responsibility== Al-Shabaab, one of the groups in the Islamist insurgency in Somalia, has claimed responsibility for the attacks. ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' quotes an unnamed al-Shabaab senior leader stating, "We have reached our objective. We killed many Christians in the enemy capital (Kampala)." Reports also allege confirmation from other al-Shabaab militants.<ref name="wsj20100712">{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704288204575362400675683926|title=Deadly Blasts Rock Uganda's Capital |last=Bariyo|first=Nicholas|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=12 July 2010|accessdate=12 July 2010}}</ref> This is al-Shabaab's first attack outside of Somalia.<ref name="AP Olukya">{{cite web|url=http://www.ajc.com/news/nation-world/22-bomb-attacks-in-568516.html |title=2 bomb attacks in Uganda; 20 feared dead |author=Godfrey Olukya |work=[[The Associated Press]] (''via'' [[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]) |date=11 July 2010 |accessdate=12 July 2010}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> On {{Nowrap|9 July}}, al-Shabaab leader [[Sheikh Mukhtar Robow]] had called for attacks against Uganda and [[Burundi]]. Al-Shabaab leader [[Sheik Yusuf Sheik Issa]] told Reuters "Uganda is a major infidel country supporting the so-called government of Somalia. We know Uganda is against Islam and so we are very happy at what has happened in Kampala. That is the best news we ever heard."<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/world/africa/10602791.stm BBC News Al-Shabab 'very happy' about Kampala World Cup blasts]{{Nowrap|12 July}} 2010</ref> However he refused to confirm or deny responsibility after the attacks, also stating, "Uganda is one of our enemies. Whatever makes them cry, makes us happy. May Allah's anger be upon those who are against us."<ref name="ap20100712"/> By 12 July, Sheik Ali Mohamud Rage from Mogadishu stated "We will carry out attacks against our enemy wherever they are ... No one will deter us from performing our Islamic duty."<ref>[http://abcnews.go.com/WN/uganda-bombing-al-qaeda-group-al-shabaab-responsible/story?id=11142781 Al-Shabaab Claim Responsibility for Uganda Blasts By JIM SCIUTTO 12 July 2010]. Abcnews.go.com (12 July 2010). Retrieved on 6 July 2011.</ref> [[Sheik Ali Mohamud Rage]], a spokesman for the group saying "Al-Shabab was behind the two blasts in Uganda. We thank the [[mujahideen]]s that carried out the attack. We are sending a message to Uganda and Burundi, if they do not take out their Amisom troops from Somalia, blasts will continue and it will happen."<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/07/2010711212520826984.html English.aljazeera.net]. English.aljazeera.net (13 July 2010). Retrieved on 6 July 2011.</ref>
On the 9 July 2017, Al-Shabaab released a video featuring one of the suicide bombers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ent.siteintelgroup.com/Multimedia/kampala-suicide-bomber-incites-muslims-to-seek-martyrdom-in-battlefield-in-first-episode-of-new-shabaab-video-series.html|title=Kampala Suicide Bomber Incites Muslims to Seek "Martyrdom" in Battlefield in First Episode of New Shabaab Video Series - SITE Enterprise|first=|last=Adam|website=ent.siteintelgroup.com|accessdate=29 October 2017}}</ref>
==Reactions== ;Domestic * {{UGA}} – At an [[African Union]] summit in Kampala two weeks later, President [[Yoweri Museveni]] urged other African leaders to defeat "the terrorists" and "sweep them out of Africa."<ref name="aljazAU"/>
;Supranational bodies * {{MWI}}/[[African Union]] – President of Malawi and Chairman of the African Union [[Bingu wa Mutharika]] condemned the perpetrators "in the strongest terms," and asserted that "the African Union stands with you, my brother President [Museveni] and with the people of Uganda."<ref name="aljazAU">[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/07/201072571956380906.html English.aljazeera.net]. English.aljazeera.net (25 July 2010). Retrieved on 6 July 2011.</ref> **Virtually every speaker at the AU summit condemned the attacks.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/focus/2010/07/20107279635950299.html English.aljazeera.net]. English.aljazeera.net (27 July 2010). Retrieved on 6 July 2011.</ref>
;States * {{CHL}} – The [[Government of Chile]] "condemned in the most energetic manner the terrorist attack in Kampala... attributed to the Somali extremist group Al Shabaab. Chile values the contribution of Uganda to peace forces in Somalia (AMISOM), which is part of the joint effors of the United Nations and the African Union to bring peace and development to that nation."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.minrel.gov.cl/prontus_minrel/site/artic/20100714/pags/20100714125643.php |title = Gobierno condena atentados ocurridos en Uganda |author=Minrel.gov.cl |publisher=Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores de Chile|date =14 July 2010}}</ref> * {{SADR}} – The President of the [[Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic]], [[Mohamed Abdelaziz (Sahrawi politician)|Mohamed Abdelaziz]], sent a message of condolence to his Ugandan counterpart and families of the victims of the Kampala bomb attacks, and expressed condemn "in the strongest possible terms these attacks, as well as all forms of indiscriminate violence that aims to terrorise and inflict harm on innocent people".<ref>{{cite news|title=President of Republic consoles his Ugandan counterpart on victims of Kampala bomb attacks |url=http://www.spsrasd.info/en/detail.php?id=12561 |publisher=[[Sahara Press Service]] |date=14 July 2010 |accessdate=19 January 2011 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * {{flag|UK}} – Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] has also passed on his personal condolences to the Ugandan President. Foreign Secretary [[William Hague]] has condemned the bomb attacks in Kampala calling them "cowardly" and stressed the "UK will stand with Uganda in fighting such brutal acts of violence and terror." He also sent "heartfelt sympathies to President Museveni"<ref>[http://www.number10.gov.uk/news/latest-news/2010/07/bomb-attacks-in-kampala-53259 Number10.gov.uk]. Number10.gov.uk (12 July 2010). Retrieved on 6 July 2011.</ref> * {{flag|USA}} – Former president [[Barack Obama]], claimed in an interview with [[South African Broadcasting Corporation|SABC]], that the attack was an example of how Al-Qaeda does not regard "African life as valuable in and of itself."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://southafrica.usembassy.gov/press100714b.html |title=Interview of President Obama by South African Broadcasting Corporation |author=United States Diplomatic Mission to South Africa |publisher=U.S. Department of State |date=13 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100717012524/http://southafrica.usembassy.gov/press100714b.html |archivedate=17 July 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> :An anonymous U.S. government official confided to [[Jake Tapper]] of [[ABC News]] an administration belief that Al-Qaeda is a "racist organisation" which practices discriminatory techniques and sentiments in the deployment of black African operatives (e.g., only targeting black African recruits for lower-level missions such as suicide bombings) because economic conditions in most African countries supposedly make black Africans more susceptible to recruitment than Arabs.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalpunch/2010/07/president-obama-white-house-al-qaeda-is-racist.html |author=Jake Tapper |publisher=ABC News |date = 13 July 2010<!-- 9:17 PM-->|title=President Obama White House Al Qaeda is Racist}}</ref> <!-- The commentary aroused political debate, with ''[[Right Wing News]]'', ''[[Commentary (magazine)|Commentary]]''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.commentarymagazine.com/blogs/index.php/rubin/327771 |title=Obama's Race Obsession |author=Jennifer Rubin |publisher=Commentary|date = 14 July 2010 – 7:20 am}}</ref> and ''[[National Review]]''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://corner.nationalreview.com/post/?q=ZDYzNGZmZjkzZTJmYTNiYjU0MzBhODI0M2UzMjRmYjA= |title=Re: Al-Qaeda Is Racist |author=Andy McCarthy |date = 14 July 2010}}</ref> criticising the "injection" of race as a factor in Islamic fundamentalist violence (and charging it as evidence of Obama's supposed "obsession" with race), while Greg Sargent of the ''[[Washington Post]]'' responded that the conservative criticism of administration statements linking race to Islamic fundamentalist violence was similar to ongoing conservative criticisms that Obama possesses racial biases in favour of black people as opposed to white people.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/plum-line/2010/07/latest_right_wing_attack_obama.html |title=Latest right wing attack: Obama only cares about black victims of terrorism |author=Greg Sargent |work=Washington Post |date =14 July 2010 }}</ref> --> *{{flag|Vietnam}} – Ministry of Foreign Affairs' Spokesperson Nguyen Phuong Nga on 13 July said: "We are extremely indignant upon learning of the two bomb attacks on July 11 in the Ugandan Capital of Kampala, in which many civilians were killed and injured. We express our heart-felt condolences to the Government of Uganda and families of the victims. We strongly condemn the attacks at civilians and hold that perpetrators of these attacks should be appropriately punished."
==Trials==
===2011 sentencings without trial=== In 2011, [[Edris Nsubuga]], aged 31, was sentenced to three concurrent 25-year sentences for his involvement in the Kampala attacks. After expressing regret and indicating that he had taken part in the bombings under threat of decapitation, he was spared the death penalty. Additionally, 24-year-old [[Muhamoud Mugisha]] was sentenced to five years imprisonment for conspiring to commit terrorism.<ref name="Lotoutsb">{{cite news | title='Long-overdue' trial of Uganda terror suspects begins | url=https://news.yahoo.com/long-overdue-trial-uganda-terror-suspects-begins-204539536.html | accessdate=18 March 2015 | agency=AFP | date=17 March 2015}}</ref> They later provided importance evidence in the subsequent trial of 13 men.<ref name="ISS">{{cite news | url=https://issafrica.org/iss-today/kampala-bombings-justice-at-last | title=Kampala bombings: justice at last? | publisher=[[Institute for Security Services]] | date=31 May 2016 | first=Ottilia Anna | last=Maunganidze | accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref>
===2015 sentencings after trial=== In March 2015, the trial of 13 other men suspected of having been involved in the 2010 Kampala bombings began at the High Court of Uganda. The hearings had been delayed for five years due to court challenges by the apprehended individuals, who accused the Ugandan police and security agencies of torture and illegal rendition. The seven Kenyans, five Ugandans, and one Tanzanian were each charged with terrorism, murder, attempted murder, and of being accessories to terrorism, All but one were accused of being Al-Shabaab members.<ref name="Lotoutsb"/>
The trial was again delayed when the prosecutor, [[Joan Kagezi]], was murdered on 30 March 2015, purportedly by agents of Al-Shabaab. The trial resumed in June 2015.<ref name="ISS"/>
In May 2016, all defendants were acquitted of being members of Al-Shabaab because, in 2010, that organization was not listed by Uganda as a terrorist organization. Seven of the suspects were convicted of terrorism, murder, and attempted murder. Ugandan [[Isa Ahmed Luyima]], who is thought to have orchestrated the attacks, Kenyan [[Hussein Hassan Agad]], Kenyan [[Idris Magondu]], Kenyan [[Habib Suleiman Njoroge]], and Kenyan [[Muhammed Ali Muhamed]] were sentenced to life imprisonment. The other two, Ugandan [[Hassan Haruna Luyima]] and Tanzanian [[Suleiman Hajjir Nyamandondo]], were sentenced to 50 years imprisonment. Five of the suspects were acquitted (Kenyan [[Yahya Suleiman Mbuthia]], Kenyan [[Muhammed Hamid Suleiman]], Kenyan [[Mohammed Awadh]], Ugandan [[Abubakari Batemetyo]], and Ugandan [[Ismail Kalule]]). Ugandan [[Muzafaru Luyima]] was acquitted of terrorism but convicted of aiding the attackers. He was sentenced to one year of community service. Two sets of brothers were tried in this case: Isa Ahmed Luyima and Muzafaru Luyima; Yahya Suleiman Mbuthia and Habib Suleiman Njoroge.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.newsweek.com/uganda-convicts-terrorists-al-shabab-2010-world-cup-bombing-464176 | title=Uganda: 7 Convicted of 2010 Al-Shabab World Cup Bombing | publisher=[[Newsweek]] | date=27 May 2016 | first=Conor | last=Gaffey | accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/26/africa/uganda-al-shabaab-bombings-conviction/ | title=8 sentenced in 2010 Al-Shabaab bombings | publisher=[[CNN]] | date=27 May 2016 | first1=Samson | last1=Ntale | first2=Ralph | last2=Ellis | accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-10821630 | title=Three Kenyan men charged with Uganda bomb attacks | publisher=[[BBC]] | date=30 July 2010 | accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.standardmedia.co.ke/article/2000203140/four-kenyans-found-guilty-of-uganda-bombing | title=Four Kenyans found guilty of Uganda bombing | publisher=[[The Standard (Kenya)]] | first=Fred | last=Makana | date=27 May 2016 | accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Power-blackout-at-high-court-ahead-of-July-2010-bombings-verdict/688334-3219374-d7uupk/index.html | title=LIVE: Seven convicted, five acquitted in the July 2010 bomb case | publisher=[[The Monitor (Uganda)|The Monitor]] | first=Anthony | last=Wesaka | date=27 May 2016 | accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of Islamist terrorist attacks]] * [[Islamic terrorism]] * [[Terrorism in Uganda]] * [[2010 FIFA World Cup]]

{{Infobox convention center | name = Koelmesse Exhibition Centre | logo = Koelnmesse Logo.svg | image = Koelnmesse Nordeingang.jpg | image_size = 300px | image_caption = Koelnmesse north entrance | address = Messeplatz 1, 50679,
[[Köln]], [[Germany]] | coordinates = {{coord|50.94257|N|6.958976|E|type:landmark_source:frwiki}} | owner = Koelnmesse GmbH private company | operator = [[Koelnmesse GmbH]] | built = | opened = 1924 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | construction_cost = | former_names = | banquets = | theatre = | total_space = {{convert|284,000 |m2|abbr=on}} | exhibit = | breakout = | ballroom = | parking = 14,500 spaces{{cite web | url=http://www.koelnmesse.com/Koelnmesse/Travel-and-Accommodation/Arriving/arriving-by-car/index.php | title=Arriving by car | accessdate=August 7, 2018 | bicycle = Yes | publictransit = S-Bahn, U-Bahn, Taxi, Plane | website = {{URL|http://www.koelnmesse.com}} }} [[File:Fortnite at Gamescom 2017.jpg|thumb|Inside Koelmesse at [[Gamescom]] 2017]] [[File:Rheinpark-Köln-OSM.png|thumb|Map of the Cologne trade fair grounds (marked ''Messegelände'')]] '''Koelnmesse GmbH''' (''Cologne Trade Fair'') is an international trade fair and exhibition center located in [[Cologne]], [[North Rhine-Westphalia]], [[Germany]]. With around 80 [[trade fair]]s and over 2,000 [[Business conference|conferences]] annually, Koelnmesse is one of the country's largest trade fair organisers[http://www.koelnmesse.com/en/messenundveranstaltungen/messenveranstaltungen_1.php Koelnmesse.com] and with 284,000 m² exhibition floor area the third largest by area.[http://www.auma.de/de/messemarkt/branchenkennzahlen/internationalemessen/seiten/hallenkapazitaeten.aspx Hall capacities by AUMA e. V.] Hall capacities by AUMA e. V. The Cologne Trade Fair ground was founded in 1922. Until 2005, the trade fair was based in the historic Rheinhallen, and since then moved into new premises next to them. The old [[Fair Tower Cologne]] (''Messeturm Köln'') is a landmark building from 1928 and features a tower restaurant on the top floor. Since 2018, the fair has been undergoing the greatest renovation works in its history. They are expected to last until 2030 and cost €600 million. Two thirds of that amount will be spent renovating the seven southern halls, dating from the 1970s.{{cite web |url=https://www.rundschau-online.de/region/koeln/sanierung-vor-gamescom-die-koelnmesse-modernisiert-sieben-suedhallen-30629372# |publisher=Kölnische Rundschau |title= Die Kölnmesse modernisiert sieben Südhallen| date= 15 June 2018 |language=German |accessdate=2 July 2018}} == Trade fairs == Among others the following [[trade fair]]s are held in Cologne: * [[Anuga Food Fair|Anuga]], the world's most important food and beverage trade fair * [[Anuga FoodTec]], the supplier fair for the food and drink industry * [[Art Cologne]] * [[Dmexco]], the leading international exposition and conference for the digital industry * [[EuVend]], the international trade fair for the [[vending]] industry * [[Gamescom]], most important trade fair for interactive games and entertainment in Europe * [[Imm Cologne]], leading trade fair for the furniture sector * [[Intermot]], international motorcycle, scooter and bicycle fair * Internationale Süßwarenmesse (ISM), world's largest confectionery trade fair * [[Photokina]], the world's leading fair for photography and imaging == Location == [[File:Bahnhofsgebäude Köln Messe Deutz - Gesamtansicht (4416-18).jpg|thumb|[[Köln Messe/Deutz station]]]] The trade fair grounds lie in Cologne's right-Rhenish district of [[Deutz, Cologne|Deutz]], directly adjacent to [[Köln Messe/Deutz station]] to the south. Among others, the station has [[Intercity-Express|ICE]] connections by [[Deutsche Bahn]] to [[Köln Hbf]] and [[Cologne/Bonn Airport station|Cologne/Bonn Airport]]. West of the trade fair grounds lies the ''[[Rheinpark]]'', a 40 hectare large park on the River [[Rhine]], and ''Tanzbrunnen'',[http://www.koelnkongress.de/wEnglisch/locations/tanzbrunnen/index.php Koelnkongress.com] an open-air theater. Apart from the Köln Messe/Deutz station to the south, the Cologne trade fair center is also served by the [[Cologne Stadtbahn]] station ''Koelnmesse'' to the East. {{s-rail-start|noclear=yes}} {{s-rail|title=KVB}} {{s-line|system=KVB|line=3|previous=Köln Messe/Deutz|next=Stegerwaldsiedlung}} {{s-line|system=KVB|line=4|previous=Köln Messe/Deutz|next=Stegerwaldsiedlung}} {{end}} [[File:Titanfall at Gamescom 2013 (9591148650).jpg|thumb|At [[Gamescom]] 2013]] == Subsidiaries == {| class="wikitable" |- | KölnKongress GmbH || [[Cologne]] || {{DEU}} || [http://www.koelnkongress.de/ www.koelnkongress.de] |- | Koelnmesse Ausstellungen GmbH || [[Cologne]] || {{DEU}} || [http://www.koelnmesse.com/ www.koelnmesse.com] |- | Koelnmesse Pte. Ltd. || [[Singapore]] || {{SGP}} || [http://www.koelnmesse.com.sg/ www.koelnmesse.com.sg] |- | Koelnmesse Inc. || [[Chicago]] || {{USA}} || [http://www.koelnmessenafta.com/ www.koelnmessenafta.com] |- | Koelnmesse Co. Ltd. || [[Beijing]] || {{PRC}} || [http://www.koelnmesse.cn/ www.koelnmesse.cn] |- | Koelnmesse Ltd. || [[Hong Kong]] || {{HKG}} || [http://www.koelnmesse.cn/ www.koelnmesse.cn] |- | Koelnmesse S.r.l. || [[Milan]] || {{ITA}} || [http://www.koelnmesse.it/ www.koelnmesse.it] |- | Koelnmesse Co. Ltd. || [[Tokyo]] || {{JPN}} || [http://www.koelnmesse.jp/ www.koelnmesse.jp] |- | Koelnmesse YA Tradefair Pvt. Ltd. || [[Mumbai]] || {{IND}} || [http://www.koelnmesse-india.com/ www.koelnmesse-india.com] |- | Koelnmesse Co., Ltd. || [[Bangkok]] || {{THA}} || [http://www.koelnmesse.com/ www.koelnmesse.com] |- | Koelnmesse Organização de Feiras Ltda. || [[Rio de Janeiro]] || {{BRA}} || [http://www.koelnmesse.com/ www.koelnmesse.com] |} == References == == External links == {{commons category|Koelnmesse}} * [http://www.koelnmesse.com Koelnmesse.com] {{de icon}} {{en icon}} * [http://www.koelnkongress.com koelnkongress.com] {{de icon}} {{en icon}} {{coord|50.9438|N|6.9745|E|source:dewiki_region:DE-NW_type:landmark|format=dms|display=title}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Cologne]] [[Category:Economy of Cologne]] [[Category:Convention centres in Germany]] [[Category:Trade fairs in Germany]] [[Category:Event management companies]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=July 2011}}
The '''LICOPA affair''' ({{lang-fr|l'affaire LICOPA}}) was a diplomatic conflict between the [[People's Republic of Congo]] ([[Congo-Brazzaville]]) and [[Zaire]] (present-day [[Democratic Republic of Congo]]) during the [[Cold War]] in the early 1970s. At the time the two neighbouring states found themselves on opposing sides in Cold War politics, with Zaire under [[Mobutu Sese Seko]] a Western ally and Congo a socialist state aligned with the [[Soviet Union]].
The Zairean authorities claimed that the Congolese embassy in [[Kinshasa]] had functioned as an intermediary between the Congolese League for Peace and Friendship between the Peoples (''LIgue COngolaise pour la Paix et l'Amitié entre les peuples'', LICOPA; 'licopa' is also the [[Lingala]] word for 'secret complot') and Zairean 'subversives'. According to Zaire, LICOPA trained Zairean opposition activists.<ref name="congo">Bazenguissa-Ganga, Rémy. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=15Qza8LQcFMC Les voies du politique au Congo: essai de sociologie historique]''. Paris: Karthala, 1997. p. 192</ref><ref name="rdc"/> Several persons accused of involvement with LICOPA were arrested in Zaire, whilst others were forced into exile.<ref name="rdc"/>
On August 21, 1971, Zaire declared the Congolese chargé d'affaires in Kinshasa, Lieutenant Eyabo, to be a ''[[persona non grata]]''.<ref name="congo"/>
In an attempt to revive Congolese-Zairean relations, the Congolese authorities carried out arrests to appease Zaire. One of the arrested was Ando Ibarra, who had been charged ''[[trial in absentia|in absentia]]'' in a Kinshasa court for endangering national security and spreading 'false rumours' in the Zairean army. Ibarra was sentenced to three years imprisonment in Congo.<ref name="congo"/><ref name="rdc">''[http://www.congointer.com/congointercaddy.htm Interview de Jonas Caddy Cadima] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106131450/http://www.congointer.com/congointercaddy.htm |date=2009-01-06 }}''</ref>
However, Congo never admitted that there had been any links between Ibarra and Lieutenant Eyado (as charged by Zaire). After being released, Ibarra was banished from Congo for ten years.<ref name="congo"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Democratic Republic of the Congo–Republic of the Congo relations]] [[Category:History of the Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:History of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Diplomatic incidents]]

{{Refimprove|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Use British English|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox theatre | name = Lausanne Opera | native_name = Opéra de Lausanne | native_name_lang = fr | image = Façade Opéra de Lausanne.jpg | image_size = 250 | image_alt = | caption = | image_map = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_map_caption= | address = Avenue du Théatre 12
1002 Lausanne | city = [[Lausanne]] | country = [[Switzerland]] | designation = | architect = | owner = | tenant = | operator = | capacity = | type = | opened = | reopened = | yearsactive = | rebuilt = | closed = | demolished = | othernames = | production = | currentuse = | website = {{URL|http://www.opera-lausanne.ch}} }} With over 140 years of history, the '''Lausanne Opera''' continues to respond to the public’s growing demand for lyrical performances. Once known as a municipal theater, it has transformed into a world renowned opera house that produces and co-produces their own productions. With a stage renovation in 2012, the Lausanne Opera offers a wide variety of operas, from baroque to contemporary, along with concerts and ballets. Thanks to its bold programming and emphasis on quality vocals and stage production, the Lausanne Opera welcomes over 45'000 spectators a year and continues to make itself known internationally. ==History== The opening ceremony took place on 10 May 1871.{{cite web|url=http://www.opera-lausanne.ch/fr/lopera/un-peu-dhistoire.html |title=Opéra de Lausanne - Un peu d'histoire |publisher=Opera-lausanne.ch |date= |accessdate=2013-09-16}} ==See also== * [[List of opera houses]] * [[List of opera companies in Europe]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Opéra de Lausanne}} * [http://www.opera-lausanne.ch Official website] * [https://archive.is/20130616102205/http://www.lausanne.ch/en/ville-officielle/administration/travaux/architecture/etudes-et-constructions/gestion-de-projets/projets-externes-termines/opera.html Page on the website of the City of Lausanne] {{Lausanne}} {{Music venues in Switzerland}} {{Authority control}} {{Portal bar|Opera|Switzerland}} {{coord|46.5181|N|6.6369|E|source:wikidata-and-enwiki-cat-tree_region:CH|display=title}} [[Category:Theatre in Switzerland]] [[Category:Opera houses in Switzerland]] [[Category:Swiss architecture]] [[Category:Dance in Switzerland]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1871]] [[Category:Music venues completed in 1871]] {{Opera-struct-stub}}

{{For|another treatment of the same material|The Assassination of the Duke of Guise}} {{italic title}} '''''{{Lang|fr|Le duc de Guise}}''''' (full title ''{{Lang|fr|Le duc de Guise, ou Les ėtats de Blois}}'' (''The [[Henry I, Duke of Guise|Duke of Guise]], or The Council of [[Blois]]))'' is an [[opéra comique]] in three acts by [[George Onslow (composer)|George Onslow]], to a [[libretto]] by [[Eugène de Planard|François-Antoine-Eugène de Planard]] and [[Jules-Henri Vernoy de Saint-Georges]], based on a play from 1809 of the same name by [[François Just Marie Raynouard]]. The opera received its premiere on 8 September 1837 at the [[Opéra-Comique]] in Paris.Tamvaco (2000), pp. 735-6. The opera, which centres on the assassination of the Duc de Guise in 1588, was the third and last of Onslow's operas to be produced. The text and music were well received by the audience, but [[Gérard de Nerval]] complained in a review that they had not offered Jenny Colon the opportunity to display her talents.Tamvaco (2000), p. 736. Onslow made an arrangement of extracts of the opera for [[string quartet]] (his Op. 60).[http://www.salon-romantique.com/Discographie-George-Onslow-Guise-ou-les-Etats-de-Blois-Le-Salon-Romantique.html Le Salon Romantique website], accessed 5 October 2014.[http://primavista.free.fr/guise.html ''Le duc de Guise''] {{fr icon}} ==Roles== {| class="wikitable" !Role ![[Voice type]] !Premiere cast,Tamvaco (2000), p. 736; le Planard (1838), p. 4
8 September 1837 |- |[[Henry III of France|Henri III]] |[[tenor]] |Théodore-François Moreau-Santi |- |[[Henry I, Duke of Guise|Henri, duc de Guise]] |tenor |[[Jean-Baptiste Chollet]] |- |Larchant, an officer of the King |[[bass (voice type)|bass]] |[[François-Louis Henry]] |- |Loignac, a [[Gascony|Gascon]] |tenor |Paul-Jean Fargueil |- |Péricart, porter of the castle of Blois |tenor |[[Joseph-Antoine-Charles Couderc]] |- |Saint-Pol, one of Guise's officers | |Victor |- |[[Catherine de' Medici|Cathérine de Médicis]] | |Mme. Boulanger |- |La marquise de Sauve. mistress of the duc de Guise | |Mme. Prévost |- |Paulette, a milkmaid |[[soprano]] |{{Interlanguage link multi|Jenny Colon|fr}} |- |colspan=3|Courtiers, bourgeois, soldiers, members of the council. |} ==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist}} '''Sources''' * De Planard and Saint-Georges (1838). ''[https://books.google.sk/books?id=LBBGAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA4&lpg=PA4&dq=le+duc+de+guise+ou+les+etats+de+blois+onslow&source=bl&ots=pk7V0wl2nd&sig=bpw3iAPHTfAI0dXrrKELeOuGni8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=faIyVLvWCYyrPPDggaAH&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=le%20duc%20de%20guise%20ou%20les%20etats%20de%20blois%20onslow&f=false Guise, ou Les états de Blois: drame lyrique en trois actes] '', Brussels: J-A Lelong. Accessed on [[Google Books]] 6 October 2014. * Tamvaco, Jean-Louis (ed.) (2000). ''Les cancans de l'opėra.'' 2 vols. Paris: CNRS Editions. {{ISBN|9782271057426}} {{DEFAULTSORT:duc de Guise, Le}} [[Category:Operas]] [[Category:1837 operas]] [[Category:French-language operas]] [[Category:Operas set in France]] [[Category:Operas based on plays]] [[Category:Opéras comiques]] [[Category:Opera world premieres at the Opéra-Comique]] [[Category:Historical operas]] [[Category:Compositions by George Onslow]]
