revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox musical artist <!-- For individuals; see Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians --> | name = Lena Meyer-Landrut | image = 1LIVE_Krone_2015-3795.jpg | caption = Lena Meyer-Landrut at 1liVE Krone 2015 | background = solo_singer | label = [[Unser Star für Oslo|USFO]], [[Universal Music Group|Universal Music Germany]] | alias = Lena | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1991|05|23|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Hanover]], [[Lower Saxony]], Germany | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[indie pop]]<ref name="Motor.de: Lena Meyer-Landrut">{{cite web|url=http://www.motor.de/kuenstler/lena_meyer_landrut |title=Motor.de: Lena Meyer-Landrut |work=[[Motor Music]] |accessdate=26 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002233817/http://www.motor.de/kuenstler/lena_meyer_landrut |archivedate=2 October 2011 }}</ref> | occupation = Singer-songwriter | years_active = 2010–present | website = {{URL|lena-meyer-landrut.de}} }}
'''Lena Johanna Therese Meyer-Landrut'''<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://archive.is/20121217210717/https://online.gema.de/werke/detailPage.do?dbkey=29283893&title=TO+THE+MOON&pdf=false |title=To the Moon |website=online.gema.de |access-date=6 March 2018}}</ref> ({{IPA-de|ˈleːna|lang}}; born 23 May 1991) is a German singer-songwriter. She represented Germany in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2010]] in [[Oslo]] winning the contest with the song "[[Satellite (Lena Meyer-Landrut song)|Satellite]]". With her three entries from the German national final ''[[Germany in the Eurovision Song Contest 2010|Unser Star für Oslo]]'' (Our Star for Oslo), Meyer-Landrut set an all-time chart record in her home country by debuting with three songs in the top five on the [[Media Control Charts|German singles chart]]. Both "Satellite" and her first album ''[[My Cassette Player]]'' debuted at [[Number-one hits of 2010 (Germany)|number one in Germany]]. The single has been certified [[Bundesverband Musikindustrie|double Platinum]], and the album has been certified five times Gold for sales of over 500,000 units. Meyer-Landrut represented Germany for the second consecutive time in the [[Eurovision Song Contest]] at [[Düsseldorf]] in [[Eurovision Song Contest 2011|2011]] with the song "[[Taken by a Stranger]]", placing 10th.
Meyer-Landrut performed as part of the interval act during the second semi-finals of the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2012]]. In September she released the single "[[Stardust (Lena Meyer-Landrut song)|Stardust]]" from the album of the same name which was released on 12 October. A second single, "[[Neon (Lonely People)]]", was released in March 2013. At the [[2013 Echo Awards]] that same month, she won the Best National Video award for "Stardust". Following her No One Can Catch Us Tour she was one of three judges on the show ''[[The Voice Kids (German TV series)|The Voice Kids]]''.
In 2014 and 2015 Meyer-Landrut returned as a judge on the second and third season of ''The Voice Kids''. In March 2015 she released the single "[[Traffic Lights (Lena Meyer-Landrut song)|Traffic Lights]]" and the fourth studio album on which it appears, ''[[Crystal Sky]]'', in May. The single from her yet to be released album ''Gemini'', "[[Lost in You (Lena Meyer-Landrut song)|Lost in You]]", was released in April 2017. She also appeared on the fourth season of the German TV show ''[[Sing meinen Song - Das Tauschkonzert]]'' (Sing My Song – The Exchange Concert).
Meyer-Landrut has also voiced characters in several [[audiobook]]s and an animated film ''[[Tarzan (2013 film)]]''. She has been a [[brand ambassador]] for [[L'Oréal]] [[hair coloring]] and skin care products.
==Early life== Lena Meyer-Landrut was born in [[Hanover]], Germany,<ref name="ad-hoc">{{cite web|title=Lena Meyer-Landrut: Zwischen Grand Prix und Schulbank|work=Ad Hoc News|date=12 March 2010|url=http://www.ad-hoc-news.de/lena-meyer-landrut-zwischen-grand-prix-und-schulbank--/de/Boulevard/Musik/21126433|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100317154012/http://www.ad-hoc-news.de/lena-meyer-landrut-zwischen-grand-prix-und-schulbank--/de/Boulevard/Musik/21126433|archivedate=17 March 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> on 23 May 1991.<ref name="Stern Interview">{{cite web|last=Maier|first=Jens|title=Interview Lena Meyer-Landrut: "An Kampf zu denken, liegt mir nicht|work=[[Stern (magazine)|Stern]]|date=14 March 2010|url=http://www.stern.de/kultur/musik/interview-lena-meyer-landrut-an-kampf-zu-denken-liegt-mir-nicht-1550854.html|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120518043228/http://www.stern.de/kultur/musik/interview-lena-meyer-landrut-an-kampf-zu-denken-liegt-mir-nicht-1550854.html|archivedate=18 May 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> She is the granddaughter of [[Andreas Meyer-Landrut]], the [[Baltic Germans|Estonian]]-born West German ambassador to the [[Soviet Union]] in Moscow from 1980 to 1983 and 1987 to 1989,<ref name="be.bra verlag">{{cite web|title=Andreas Meyer-Landrut|work=be.bra verlag|url=http://www.bebraverlag.de/autoren/autor/197-Andreas_Meyer-Landrut|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306063523/http://www.bebraverlag.de/autoren/autor/197-Andreas_Meyer-Landrut|archivedate=6 March 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="bunte"/> and Hanna Karatsony von Hodos who was born in [[Bratislava]], [[Slovakia]] of [[Hungarian nobility]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bratislavacountynobility.blogspot.ie/2012/03/karatsony-von-hodos.html|title=Karatsony von Hodos|date=22 March 2012|accessdate=17 October 2017|last1=Nagy|first1=Imrich|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171018071028/http://bratislavacountynobility.blogspot.ie/2012/03/karatsony-von-hodos.html|archivedate=18 October 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> She grew up as an only child,<ref name="be.bra verlag"/> and started taking dancing lessons at the age of five; initially doing [[ballet]] and later practising various modern styles, including [[hip-hop dance|hip-hop]] and [[jazz dance]].<ref name="profil eurovision.tv">{{cite web|title=About Lena|work=eurovision.tv|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/event/artistdetail?song=24883&event=1493#biography|accessdate=22 July 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101231052127/http://www.eurovision.tv/event/artistdetail?song=24883&event=1493#biography|archivedate=31 December 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Meyer-Landrut grew fond of singing and appeared as an [[Extra (actor)|extra]] in a number of German television series,<ref name="be.bra verlag"/> though she never received any formal acting or vocal training.<ref name="welt">{{cite web|last=Fraczek|first=Jennifer|title=Kandidatin für Oslo: Wie aus Lena Meyer-Landrut plötzlich ein Star wird|work=[[Die Welt]]|date=13 February 2010|url=https://www.welt.de/fernsehen/article6380364/Wie-aus-Lena-Meyer-Landrut-ploetzlich-ein-Star-wird.html|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022045113/http://www.welt.de/fernsehen/article6380364/Wie-aus-Lena-Meyer-Landrut-ploetzlich-ein-Star-wird.html|archivedate=22 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In June 2010 she graduated from IGS Roderbruch Hannover, a [[comprehensive school]], receiving her [[Abitur]] diploma.<ref name="abi">{{cite web|last=Sedelies|first=Jan|title=Lena feiert ihr Abitur|work=[[Hannoversche Allgemeine Zeitung]]|date=15 June 2010|url=http://www.haz.de/Nachrichten/Panorama/Themen/Lena-Unser-Grand-Prix-Star/Lena-feiert-ihr-Abitur|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121004202315/http://www.haz.de/Nachrichten/Panorama/Themen/Lena-Unser-Grand-Prix-Star/Lena-feiert-ihr-Abitur|archivedate=4 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Career==
===2009–2011: ''Unser Star für Oslo'' and Eurovision Song Contest=== Meyer-Landrut decided to take part in the talent show ''[[Germany in the Eurovision Song Contest 2010|Unser Star für Oslo]]'' (Our Star for Oslo), a newly created national television programme to select the German entry for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2010]] in Oslo.<ref name="welt"/> The show was organised by public broadcaster [[ARD (broadcaster)|ARD]] and private television station [[ProSieben]], as well as entertainer, music producer and former Eurovision entrant [[Stefan Raab]]. From 4,500 entrants, Meyer-Landrut was picked as one of the 20 contestants for the show. Asked about her motivation to apply, she said, "I like to test myself. I wanted to see how I am perceived, and I wanted to hear what people with knowledge have to say about it. I personally can't judge myself at all."<ref name="bunte">{{cite web|last=Harders|first=Antje|title=NACHGEFRAGT ... bei Nachwuchstalent Lena Meyer-Landrut|work=[[Bunte]]|date=July 2010|page=110|language=German}}</ref>
After her first appearance, performing "[[My Same]]" by British singer [[Adele]], Meyer-Landrut received much praise from the show's jury panel and was instantly considered the favourite.<ref name="welt" /> The following week, Adele's "My Same" entered the [[Media Control|German singles chart]] at number 61.<ref name="adele">{{cite web|title=Chartverfolgung / Adele / Single|work=musicline.de|url=http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/artist/Adele/?type=single|accessdate=24 March 2010|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120202035831/http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/artist/Adele/?type=single|archivedate=2 February 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Meyer-Landrut reached the final of ''Unser Star für Oslo'', mainly performing lesser-known songs by international artists [[The Bird and the Bee]], [[Kate Nash]], [[Paolo Nutini]] and [[Lisa Mitchell]]. Of her eight [[Cover version|cover]] performances, five of the original songs subsequently charted in Germany, with all but "[[Foundations (song)|Foundations]]" reaching their peak chart position.<ref name="kate nash">{{cite web|title=Chartverfolgung / Kate Nash / Single|work=musicline.de|url=http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/title/Nash%2CKate/Foundations/single|accessdate=24 March 2010|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100424231427/http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/title/Nash,Kate/Foundations/single|archivedate=24 April 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="paolo nutini">{{cite web|title=Chartverfolgung / Paolo Nutini / Single|work=musicline.de|url=http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/title/Nutini%2CPaolo/New+Shoes/single|accessdate=24 March 2010|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100508093439/http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/title/Nutini,Paolo/New+Shoes/single|archivedate=8 May 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="lisa mitchell">{{cite web|title=Chartverfolgung / Lisa Mitchell / Single|work=musicline.de|url=http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/title/Mitchell%2CLisa/Neopolitan+Dreams/single|accessdate=24 March 2010|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100421222646/http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/title/Mitchell,Lisa/Neopolitan+Dreams/single|archivedate=21 April 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="jason mraz">{{cite web|title=Chartverfolgung / Jason Mraz / Single|work=musicline.de|url=http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/title/Mraz%2CJason/Mr.curiosity/single|accessdate=24 March 2010|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100512170641/http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/title/Mraz,Jason/Mr.curiosity/single|archivedate=12 May 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In the final, on 12 March 2010, Meyer-Landrut sang three songs specifically written for the contest, "[[Bee (Lena Meyer-Landrut song)|Bee]]", "[[Satellite (Lena Meyer-Landrut song)|Satellite]]" and "[[Love Me (Lena Meyer-Landrut song)|Love Me]]". Through [[televoting]] the audience chose "Satellite", written by American [[Julie Frost]] and Dane John Gordon, to be her designated song in the event she won the show. In a second round of voting Meyer-Landrut was chosen as Germany's entry for the 55th Eurovision Song Contest, beating the last remaining contestant, [[Jennifer Braun]].<ref name="esctoday Germany sends Lena">{{cite web|last=Klier|first=Marcus|title=Germany sends Lena Meyer-Landrut to the Eurovision Song Contest|work=esctoday.com|date=12 March 2010|url=http://www.esctoday.com/?p=15370|accessdate=22 July 2012}}</ref> The music video for "Satellite" was shot during the night of the final and premiered on German television stations four days later.<ref name="dwdl">{{cite web|last=Mantel|first=Uwe|title=Lenas "Satellite" feiert Premiere auf fünf Sendern|work=dwdl.de|date=16 March 2010|url=http://www.dwdl.de/story/25206/lenas_satellite_feiert_premiere_auf_fnf_sendern/|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100322191528/http://www.dwdl.de/story/25206/lenas_satellite_feiert_premiere_auf_fnf_sendern|archivedate=22 March 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
{{Listen |filename=Lena Meyer-Landrut - Satellite.ogg |title=Lena Meyer-Landrut "Satellite" (2010) |description=Sample from the chorus of Lena Meyer-Landrut's "Satellite".}}
Throughout the show, Meyer-Landrut was seen as the clear favourite.<ref name="sueddeutsche wunder">{{cite web|last=Hoff|first=Hans|title=TV-Kritik: Stefan Raab macht ein Wunder möglich|work=[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]]|date=3 February 2010|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/medien/tv-kritik-stefan-raab-macht-ein-wunder-moeglich-1.73827|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121003071427/http://www.sueddeutsche.de/medien/tv-kritik-stefan-raab-macht-ein-wunder-moeglich-1.73827|archivedate=3 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> One day after winning ''Unser Star für Oslo'', her three songs from the finals topped the German [[iTunes Store]] sales chart,<ref name="esctoday Lena itunes charts">{{cite web|last=Klier|first=Marcus|title=Lena Meyer-Landrut at number 1, 2 and 3 of German itunes charts|work=esctoday.com|date=24 March 2010|url=http://www.esctoday.com/?p=15375|accessdate=22 July 2012}}</ref> making her the first singer to accomplish this.<ref name="oljo allzeit Rekord Download">{{cite web|title=Lena Meyer-Landrut: größter Download Hit der deutschen Geschichte|work=oljo.de|date=13 March 2010|url=http://www.oljo.de/blog/lena-meyer-landrut-allzeit-rekord-download-hit/|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620110007/http://www.oljo.de/blog/lena-meyer-landrut-allzeit-rekord-download-hit/|archivedate=20 June 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="spiegel online">{{cite web|title=Lena Meyer-Landrut schreibt Charts-Geschichte|work=[[Der Spiegel]]|date=23 March 2010|url=http://www.spiegel.de/kultur/musik/0,1518,685138,00.html|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111225123809/http://www.spiegel.de/kultur/musik/0,1518,685138,00.html|archivedate=25 December 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> "Satellite" sold over 100,000 [[Music download|downloads]] in its first week, becoming Germany's fastest-selling digital release ever.<ref name="esctoday Satellite Gold">{{cite web|last=Klier|first=Marcus|title=Germany: Satellite to be certified gold|work=esctoday.com|date=23 March 2010|url=http://www.esctoday.com/?p=15439|accessdate=22 July 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180305221342/http://esctoday.com/?p=15439|archivedate=5 March 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Her three songs entered the top five of the German singles chart reaching positions one, three and four. No artist had achieved this since the charts were first established in Germany in 1959.<ref name="spiegel online"/> "Satellite" was certified gold after the first week and platinum after the fourth week of its release.<ref name="esctoday Satellite Gold"/><ref name="stern platinum">{{cite web|last=Maier|first=Jens|title=Lena Meyer-Landrut: Satellite wird mit Platin ausgezeichnet|work=[[Stern (magazine)|Stern]]|date=14 April 2010|url=http://www.stern.de/kultur/musik/lena-meyer-landrut-satellite-wird-mit-platin-ausgezeichnet-1558558.html|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102051759/http://www.stern.de/kultur/musik/lena-meyer-landrut-satellite-wird-mit-platin-ausgezeichnet-1558558.html|archivedate=2 November 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The song remained at number one for five consecutive weeks in Germany.<ref name="Musicline Satellite"/>
While competing at ''Unser Star für Oslo'', Meyer-Landrut continued to attend school. The last show was held one month before the start of her final exams.<ref name="be.bra verlag"/> Following them she released her debut album, ''[[My Cassette Player]]'', on 7 May 2010.<ref name="pro7 presseportal">{{cite web|title=TV total Oslo spezial|work=presseportal.de|date=13 April 2010|url=http://www.presseportal.de/meldung/1594219|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010122039/http://www.presseportal.de/meldung/1594219|archivedate=10 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Produced by Stefan Raab, it includes the singles "Satellite", "Love Me" and "Bee", as well as two cover songs and eight unreleased titles. Meyer-Landrut is credited as a co-writer for the lyrics of five songs.<ref name="inlay">{{cite AV media notes|title=My Cassette Player|others=Lena|year=2010|type=CD booklet and case back cover|work=[[Universal Music Group|USFO for Universal Deutschland]]}}</ref> The album debuted at number one on the [[Media Control Charts|German albums chart]].<ref name="Ger-albumschart" /> It peaked at number one on the [[Ö3 Austria Top 40|Austrian albums chart]], and at number three on the [[Swiss Music Charts|Swiss albums chart]].<ref name="austriancharts">{{cite web|title=Discographie Lena Meyer-Landrut|work=Hung Medien|publisher=austriancharts.at|url=http://austriancharts.at/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Lena+Meyer-Landrut|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102191715/http://austriancharts.at/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Lena+Meyer-Landrut|archivedate=2 November 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="swisscharts">{{cite web|title=Discography Lena Meyer-Landrut|work=Hung Medien|publisher=swisscharts.com|url=http://swisscharts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Lena+Meyer-Landrut|accessdate=22 July 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021212601/http://swisscharts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Lena+Meyer-Landrut|archivedate=21 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> "Satellite" has been certified [[Bundesverband Musikindustrie|double Platinum]], and the album has been certified five times Gold for sales of over 500,000 units.<ref name="Musicline Satellite">{{cite web|title=Chartverfolgung: Satellite (single)|work=musicline.de|url=http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/title/Lena+Meyer-Landrut%A5USFO/Satellite/single|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=German}}</ref><ref name="Gold Platin Datenbank">Bundesverband Musikindustrie.{{cite certification|region=Germany|artist=Lena+Meyer+Landrut|accessdate=6 May 2010}}</ref><ref name="Ger-albumschart">{{cite web|title=Chartverfolgung: Lena (longplay)|work=musicline.de|url=http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/artist/Lena/longplay|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121003011133/http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/artist/Lena/longplay|archivedate=3 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Following her success in Germany Meyer-Landrut said she would enjoy pursuing a singing or acting career,<ref name="bunte" /> but explained, "I'm not fixated on doing music my whole life."<ref name="dw">{{cite web|last=Friedman|first=Deborah|title=Germany sends Eurovision star Lena into orbit (Interview)|work=[[Deutsche Welle]]|date=13 April 2010|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,5456614,00.html|accessdate=22 July 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100619134823/http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,5456614,00.html|archivedate=19 June 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> She said she originally planned to study acting after graduating school, but now is unsure "if time allows".<ref name="dw" /> She said her musical influences include [[Adele]], [[Kate Nash]], [[Vanessa Carlton]], as well as the singer [[Clueso]], and German [[pop rock]] band [[Wir sind Helden]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Lena Meyer-Landrut |work=[[Wetten, dass..?]] |url=http://www.wetten-dass.com/stars/lena-meyer-landrut-92.html |accessdate=22 July 2012 |language=German |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120605003912/http://www.wetten-dass.com/stars/lena-meyer-landrut-92.html |archivedate=5 June 2012 |df= }}</ref>
Representing a [[Eurovision Song Contest#Big Four|"big four" country]], Meyer-Landrut automatically qualified for the final of the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2010]]. Germany received a wild card during the running order draw, allowing the German representatives to choose the country's position for the final. They chose position 22 out of the 25 spots. Meyer-Landrut arrived in Oslo one week before the show and completed five rehearsals of her song "Satellite". Before the final, she was considered one of the favourites. [[Bookmakers]] regarded her as the second favourite behind Azerbaijan's [[Safura Alizadeh|Safura]], while [[Google]] projected she would win based on search volume in the participating countries.<ref name="guardian pop dominance">{{cite web|title=Europeans vie for pop dominance at song contest|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=29 May 2010|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/feedarticle/9102579|accessdate=22 July 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715105404/http://www.theguardian.com/world/feedarticle/9102579|archivedate=15 July 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> According to Norway's ''[[Aftenposten]]'' she received the most media attention of all the participants.<ref name="aftenposten">{{cite web|last=Henriksen|first=Arve|title=Fabian bød opp til sangfest|work=[[Aftenposten]]|date=26 May 2010|url=http://www.aftenposten.no/kul_und/eurovision/article3662927.ece|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=Norwegian|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629141338/http://www.aftenposten.no/kul_und/eurovision/article3662927.ece|archivedate=29 June 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The final was held on 29 May 2010 at Oslo's [[Telenor Arena]]. Appearing fourth from last, Meyer-Landrut wore a [[Little black dress|simple black dress]] and performed on a bare stage with four backing singers. Her pared-back presentation was a break from recent Eurovision trends, as it did not feature any choreography, dancers or an elaborate stage show.<ref name="irishtimes">{{cite web|last=Fricker|first=Karen|title=Voters swayed by German singer's fresh and unusual approach|work=[[The Irish Times]]|date=31 May 2010|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0531/1224271504640.html|accessdate=22 July 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021041336/http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0531/1224271504640.html|archivedate=21 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> "Satellite" received a total of 246 points, giving Germany its first win since 1982, and the first victory as a [[German reunification|unified country]].<ref name="Lena wins Eurovision Zeit">{{cite web|title=Eurovision Song Contest: Lena siegt in Oslo|work=[[Die Zeit]]|date=30 May 2010|url=http://www.zeit.de/kultur/musik/2010-05/eurovision-song-contest-lena-2|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121007090751/http://www.zeit.de/kultur/musik/2010-05/eurovision-song-contest-lena-2|archivedate=7 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="Lena wins Eurovision Eurovision.tv">{{cite web|last=Schacht|first=Andreas|title=Germany wins: See full results|work=eurovision.tv|date=30 May 2010|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=18063&_t=GERMANY+WINS%2C+SEE+FULL+RESULTS!|accessdate=22 July 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120912162048/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=18063&_t=GERMANY+WINS,+SEE+FULL+RESULTS!|archivedate=12 September 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The song won over Turkey's entry "[[We Could Be the Same]]" with a margin of 76 points, the second largest in Eurovision history, second only to [[Alexander Rybak]]'s margin of 169 points in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2009|2009 contest]]. (It would later be eclipsed by [[Loreen (singer)|Loreen]]'s victory in 2012, sporting a margin of 113 points). "Satellite" was awarded the maximum of 12 points nine times and received points from all but five countries.<ref name="Lena wins Eurovision Eurovision.tv" />
[[File:Germany ESC 2011 Lena Meyer-Landrut 001.jpg|220px|right|thumb|Lena on stage in Düsseldorf]] The [[BBC]] called "Satellite" the first "contemporary pop hit Eurovision has produced in decades," ushering in "a new era for the annual music jamboree".<ref name="bbc">{{cite web|last=Savage|first=Mark|title=Germany drags Eurovision into the 21st century|work=[[BBC News]]|date=30 May 2010|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment_and_arts/10192518.stm|accessdate=22 July 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100602081051/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment_and_arts/10192518.stm|archivedate=2 June 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Meyer-Landrut's victory received much attention in Germany and the show was seen by 15 million viewers on German television (a 49.1 percent market share).<ref name="esctoday ratings">{{cite web|last=Klier|first=Marcus|title=Germany: 14.69 million people watched the final|work=esctoday.com|date=30 May 2010|url=http://www.esctoday.com/?p=15899|accessdate=22 July 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180305221341/http://esctoday.com/?p=15899|archivedate=5 March 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> She returned to [[Hanover]] the following day, where she was greeted by 40,000 people.<ref name="Zeit Ein Solo für zwei">{{cite web|last1=Gäbler|first1=Bernd|last2=Grimm|first2=Imre|title=Ein Solo für zwei|work=[[Die Zeit]]|date=31 May 2010|url=http://www.zeit.de/kultur/2010-05/lena-oslo-hannover|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121007163428/http://www.zeit.de/kultur/2010-05/lena-oslo-hannover|archivedate=7 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In June, "Satellite" regained the top spot on the German singles chart for one week and also peaked at number one in [[List of Danish number-one hits|Denmark]],<ref name="danish">{{cite web|url=http://www.danishcharts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Lena+Meyer-Landrut|title=Lena Meyer-Landrut's positions for Denmark|work=Danishcharts.com|accessdate=18 June 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321050050/http://www.danishcharts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Lena+Meyer-Landrut|archivedate=21 March 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[List of Finnish number-one hits|Finland]],<ref name="finnish">{{cite web|url=http://finnishcharts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Lena+Meyer-Landrut|title=Lena Meyer-Landrut's positions for Finland|work=Finnishcharts.com|accessdate=18 June 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019155905/http://finnishcharts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Lena+Meyer-Landrut|archivedate=19 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[List of number-one hits in Norway#2010|Norway]],<ref name="norwegian">{{cite web|url=http://norwegiancharts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Lena+Meyer-Landrut|title=Lena Meyer-Landrut's positions for Norway|publisher=Norwegiancharts.com|accessdate=9 June 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100626110905/http://norwegiancharts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Lena+Meyer%2DLandrut|archivedate=26 June 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[List of Swedish number-one hits|Sweden]]<ref name="swedish">{{cite web|url=http://www.swedishcharts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Lena+Meyer%2DLandrut|title=Lena Meyer-Landrut's positions for Sweden|publisher=Swedishcharts.com|accessdate=9 June 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100626045132/http://swedishcharts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Lena+Meyer%2DLandrut|archivedate=26 June 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and [[List of number-one hits of 2010 (Switzerland)|Switzerland]].<ref name="swiss">{{cite web|url=http://swisscharts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Lena+Meyer-Landrut|title=Lena Meyer-Landrut's positions for Switzerland|work=Hung Medien|accessdate=9 June 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021212601/http://swisscharts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Lena+Meyer-Landrut|archivedate=21 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It also topped the [[List of European number-one hits of 2010|European Hot 100]] singles chart—the first Eurovision song to do so.<ref name="european satellite">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/#/charts/european-hot-100?chartDate=2010-06-19|title=European Hot 100 Singles: Week of June 19, 2010|work=Billboard.com|accessdate=11 June 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.billboard.com%2F%23%2Fartist%2FRihanna%2Fchart-history%2F658897%3Ff%3D793%26g%3DSingles&date=2011-10-02#/charts/european-hot-100?chartDate=2010-06-19|archivedate=2 October 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="eurovision.tv most selling single in europe">{{cite web|first=Jarmo|last=Siim|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=18673&_t=Lena%27s+Satellite+becomes+most+selling+single+in+Europe|title=Lena's Satellite becomes most selling single in Europe|work=eurovision.tv|date=12 June 2010|accessdate=22 July 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131126101457/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=18673&_t=Lena%27s+Satellite+becomes+most+selling+single+in+Europe|archivedate=26 November 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In June 2010 in the German [[Dubbing (filmmaking)|dubbed]] version of the [[Computer animation|computer-animated]] film ''[[Sammy's Adventures: The Secret Passage]]'', Meyer-Landrut provided the voice for the character originally spoken by [[Isabelle Fuhrman]].<ref name="haz voice acting">{{cite web|url=http://www.haz.de/Hannover/Aus-der-Stadt/Lena-Ein-Star-fuer-Oslo-aus-Hannover/Die-erste-Rolle-Lena-als-Schildkroete|first=Imre|last=Grimm|title=Die erste Rolle: Lena als Schildkröte|work=[[Hannoversche Allgemeine Zeitung]]|language=German|date=17 June 2010|accessdate=18 June 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100623050518/http://www.haz.de/Hannover/Aus-der-Stadt/Lena-Ein-Star-fuer-Oslo-aus-Hannover/Die-erste-Rolle-Lena-als-Schildkroete|archivedate=23 June 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In January 2011, the TV-Show ''Unser Song für Deutschland'' was held and Meyer-Landrut's 2011 Eurovision song was determined via televoting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediabolo.de/german/zuschauer/aktuelle_projekte/index.html?AKTION=INFOSND&ID=138 |title=Unser Song für Deutschland |work=mediabolo.de |accessdate=3 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304155905/http://www.mediabolo.de/german/zuschauer/aktuelle_projekte/index.html?AKTION=INFOSND&ID=138 |archivedate=4 March 2012 |df= }}</ref> The twelve songs Meyer-Landrut performed during that show were recorded on her second studio album ''[[Good News (Lena album)|Good News]],'' which was released on 8 February 2011. The album reached Gold status in Germany within one week after its release.<ref name="stern good news gold in one week">{{cite web|title=Lena gegen Lena: 3,25 Millionen Menschen sehen das Finale |work=[[Stern (magazine)|Stern]] |date=19 February 2011 |url=http://www.stern.de/news2/aktuell/lena-gegen-lena-325-millionen-menschen-sehen-das-finale-1655700.html |accessdate=22 July 2012 |language=German |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110914143024/http://www.stern.de/news2/aktuell/lena-gegen-lena-325-millionen-menschen-sehen-das-finale-1655700.html |archivedate=14 September 2011 |df= }}</ref> On 18 February 2011, the ''Unser Song für Deutschland'' final was held. It was decided through televoting that Meyer-Landrut would perform the entry "[[Taken by a Stranger]]" in the final of the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2011]].<ref name="esctoday 2011">{{cite web|first=Klier|last=Marcus|url=http://www.esctoday.com/?p=16802|title=Lena to perform Taken by a stranger in Düsseldorf|work=esctoday.com|accessdate=22 July 2012|date=18 February 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180305221341/http://esctoday.com/?p=16802|archivedate=5 March 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In April 2011, she went on her first German tour of the largest concert halls in Berlin, Hanover, Frankfurt, Dortmund, Leipzig, Hamburg, Munich, Stuttgart and Cologne,<ref name="bz tour 2011">{{cite web|url=http://www.bz-berlin.de/kultur/musik/lena-meyer-landrut-tour-start-in-berlin-article902452.html|title=Lena Meyer-Landrut: Tour-Start in Berlin|work=[[B.Z. (newspaper)|B.Z.]]|accessdate=22 July 2012|date=30 June 2010|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131109231901/http://www.bz-berlin.de/kultur/musik/lena-meyer-landrut-tour-start-in-berlin-article902452.html|archivedate=9 November 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> though the concerts were not sold out.
In May 2011, Meyer-Landrut attempted to defend her title for the second consecutive time in the [[2011 Eurovision Song Contest]] at [[Düsseldorf]].<ref name="eurovision.tv 2011 contest" /> She was the third winner to do so, and the first in over 50 years.<ref name="welt nicht wieder antreten">{{cite web|first=Patrick|last=Neumann|url=https://www.welt.de/vermischtes/article7861965/Darum-sollte-Lena-nicht-wieder-antreten.html|title=Darum sollte Lena nicht wieder antreten|work=[[Die Welt]]|accessdate=22 July 2012|date=31 May 2010|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019221018/http://www.welt.de/vermischtes/article7861965/Darum-sollte-Lena-nicht-wieder-antreten.html|archivedate=19 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> She sang the song "[[Taken by a Stranger]]", placing 10th.<ref name="eurovision.tv 2011 contest">{{cite web|last=Bakker|first=Sietse|title=Final of Eurovision 2011 set for 14 May, Lena returns!|work=Eurovision.tv|date=30 June 2010|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=18903&_t=Final+of+Eurovision+2011+set+for+14+May%2C+Lena+returns%21|accessdate=22 July 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67E2uOAxq?url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=18903|archivedate=27 April 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> She also appeared in the opening performance of the show, less than an hour before she took the stage to represent Germany.
===2012–2013: ''Stardust'' and ''The Voice''=== On 24 May 2012, Meyer-Landrut performed as part of the interval act during the second semi-finals of the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2012]] in [[Baku]], Azerbaijan. She was joined by the five Eurovision winners from 2007 to 2011, which included [[Marija Šerifović]], [[Dima Bilan]], [[Alexander Rybak]], and [[Ell & Nikki]]. Meyer-Landrut, Marija, Dima and Alexander performed their winning song entries accompanied by traditional [[Azerbaijan|Azeri]] instruments, and were joined by Ell & Nikki for a rendition of "[[Waterloo (ABBA song)|Waterloo]]".<ref name="eurovision.tv second semi-final">{{cite web|first=Gordon|last=Roxburgh|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=second_semi-final_live_we_have_our_ten_qualifiers&reaction_id=1203532|title=Second Semi-final: We have our ten qualifiers|work=eurovision.tv|date=24 May 2012|accessdate=22 July 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004222136/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=second_semi-final_live_we_have_our_ten_qualifiers&reaction_id=1203532|archivedate=4 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[File:Lena Meyer-Landrut at the Echo music award 2013.jpg|thumb|Lena Meyer-Landrut at the Echo music award 2013]] In late July and early August she went on a promotion tour, Lenas Wohnzimmer (Lena′s Lounge), which took her to Munich, Cologne, Hamburg and Berlin. She performed several of her new songs.<ref>{{cite web|first=Renzo|last=Wellinger|url=http://www.musikmarkt.de/Aktuell/News/Lena-stellt-neue-Songs-in-Muenchen-vor-mit-Videos|archive-url=https://archive.is/20121210090511/http://www.musikmarkt.de/Aktuell/News/Lena-stellt-neue-Songs-in-Muenchen-vor-mit-Videos|dead-url=yes|archive-date=10 December 2012|title=Lena stellt neue Songs in München vor|work=[[Musikmarkt]]|date=31 July 2012|accessdate=2 August 2012|language=German}}</ref>
Meyer-Landrut announced on her Twitter account that "[[Stardust (Lena Meyer-Landrut song)|Stardust]]" would be the first single from her new album [[Stardust (Lena album)|of the same name]] on ! August. The single was released on 21 September<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/Lenas_view/status/230624318332227585|title=Single announcement via Twitter (German)|publisher=|accessdate=27 September 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131013180431/https://twitter.com/Lenas_view/status/230624318332227585|archivedate=13 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and was certified Gold for selling 150,000 copies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musikindustrie.de/no_cache/gold_platin_datenbank/#topSearch |title=Lena Stardust Certification |publisher= |accessdate=27 September 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202022835/http://www.musikindustrie.de/no_cache/gold_platin_datenbank/ |archivedate= 2 December 2013 |df= }}</ref> The album was released on 12 October and debuted at number two on the German Albums chart.<ref name="Stardust album">{{cite web|title=Lena – Stardust (VÖ: 21. September 2012) |work=[[Hessischer Rundfunk#hr3|hr3]] |date=9 August 2012 |url=http://www.hr-online.de/website/radio/hr3/index.jsp?rubrik=55601&key=standard_document_45685507&xtcr=2&xtmc=lena |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130206151857/http://www.hr-online.de/website/radio/hr3/index.jsp?rubrik=55601&key=standard_document_45685507&xtcr=2&xtmc=lena |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 February 2013 |accessdate=9 August 2012 |language=German }}</ref> Since October 2012 she has performed the theme song in the opening credits of ''[[Sesamstraße]]'', the German version of ''[[Sesame Street]]'' accompanied by [[Elmo]] on trumpet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sesamstrasse.de/sendungsinfos/sesamstrasse/jubilaeum445.html|title=Alles neu bei der Sesamstraße|work=[[Sesamstraße]]|date=24 August 2012|accessdate=28 August 2012|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120826023531/http://www.sesamstrasse.de/sendungsinfos/sesamstrasse/jubilaeum445.html|archivedate=26 August 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> She covered the [[Pippi Longstocking]] song "[[Sjörövar Fabbe]]" ("Seeräuber-Opa Fabian") for the compilation album ''Giraffenaffen'' in November 2012.<ref name="Giraff">{{Cite web |url=http://www.giraffenaffen.de/musik.html |title=Giraffenaffen 1 |website=giraffenaffen.de |access-date=5 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170813111352/http://www.giraffenaffen.de/musik.html |archivedate=13 August 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
On 18 January 2013, it was announced that the second single from Meyer-Landrut's album would be "[[Neon (Lonely People)]]". The music video for it was shot in early February, by director Bode Brodmüller in Rathenau-Hallen. He also directed the video for her first single from the third album, "Stardust". Lena's video for "Neon (Lonely People)", her sixth single, premiered on Universal Music's website on 1 March. It was released on 15 March, and the video was uploaded to Meyer-Landrut's [[Vevo]] channel on [[YouTube]]. The single is different from the original version on her ''Stardust'' album. It is a remixed, slightly faster dance song. Meyer-Landrut attended the [[2013 Echo Awards]] on 21 March. She was nominated for two categories—Best National Video for "Stardust", and as Best National Female Artist. She won the Best National Video award,<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://oikotimes.com/echo-awards-2013-lena-rob-win-awards/ |title=ECHO AWARDS 2013: LENA & ROB WIN AWARDS |website= oikotimes.com |access-date= 5 March 2018}}</ref> but lost the Best Female National Artist award to singer [[Ivy Quainoo]].<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.dw.com/en/echo-2013-who-won-what/g-16688225 |title= ECHO 2013: Who won what? |website= dw.com |access-date= 5 March 2018}}</ref>
Meyer-Landrut went on a club tour through thirteen German cities starting in Stuttgart on 2 April 2013 and finishing in Offenbach am Main on 21 April. The final concert was streamed live via the Internet.<ref>{{Cite web |url= https://translate.google.ca/translate?hl=en&sl=de&u=http://www.radiohamburg.de/Musik/Konzerte/Konzertfotos/2013/April/Lena-Meyer-Landrut-live-No-One-Can-Catch-Us-Tour&prev=search |title= Lena Meyer-Landrut live |website=radiohamburg.de |access-date=5 March 2018}}</ref> The No One Can Catch Us Tour name was taken from a line on her first single from the album, ''Stardust''. In April and May 2013 she was one of three judges on the show ''[[The Voice Kids (German TV series)|The Voice Kids]]'' alongside [[Tim Bendzko]] and [[Söhne Mannheims|Henning Wehland]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RY9GO6kQQGY |title=Lena Meyer Landrut - Satellite (Olivia) {{!}} The Voice Kids 2013 {{!}} Blind Audition {{!}} SAT.1 |website=youtube.com |access-date=5 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160627222549/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RY9GO6kQQGY |archivedate=27 June 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Her seventh single, "[[Mr. Arrow Key]]", the third single from ''Stardust,'' was released on 17 May 2013. It was written by Lena, Linda Carlsson and Sonny Boy Gustafsson, who also produced the track.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lena-meyer-landrut.de/mr-arrow-key-wird-die-nachste-single/ |title= Mr. Arrow key will be the next single |date= 18 April 2013 |accessdate= 18 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130424195739/http://www.lena-meyer-landrut.de/mr-arrow-key-wird-die-nachste-single/ |archivedate=24 April 2013 |df= }}</ref> Lena was president of the German jury (including Carolin Niemczyk, Alina Süggeler, [[Tim Bendzko]] and [[Florian Silbereisen]])<ref>{{Cite web |url= https://eurovisiontimes.wordpress.com/2013/06/03/germany-jury-votes-revealed/ |title= Germany: Jury Votes Revealed |website= eurovisiontimes.wordpress.com |access-date= 5 March 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130611020818/http://eurovisiontimes.wordpress.com/2013/06/03/germany-jury-votes-revealed/ |archivedate= 11 June 2013 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> and the spokesperson for Germany, revealing the countries voting results at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2013]] final on 18 May.
In July 2013, it was announced that she would be the German voice of [[Jane Porter (Tarzan)|Jane]] in the [[motion capture]] [[animated film]] ''[[Tarzan (2013 film)|Tarzan 3D]]'', which was released in German cinemas in February 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvmovie.de/dschungelkoenig-in-3d-4498063.html |title=Der Dschungelkönig in 3D Bald kommt Tarzan in 3D ins Kino |date=8 July 2013 |work=TV Movie |language=German |accessdate=9 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130712194507/http://www.tvmovie.de/dschungelkoenig-in-3d-4498063.html |archivedate=12 July 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hitfilms.de/animations-abenteuer-tarzan-3d-kommt-erst-im-februar-2014-in-die-kinos/ |title=Animations-Abenteuer "Tarzan 3D" kommt erst im Februar 2014 in die Kinos |date=29 August 2013 |work=Hitfilms |language=German |accessdate=30 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004214144/http://hitfilms.de/animations-abenteuer-tarzan-3d-kommt-erst-im-februar-2014-in-die-kinos/ |archivedate=4 October 2013 |df= }}</ref> In the same month she dubbed the voice of three characters in the two [[audiobook]]s ''Giraffenaffen – Wir sind da!'' (Giraffe-monkeys – We are here!) and ''Giraffenaffen – Die Schatzssuche'' (Giraffe-monkeys – Treasure hunt), which were both published in October 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=527883073927456&set=a.157206940995073.30483.156008124448288&type=1&relevant_count=1|title=Facebook announcement by the publisher Oetinger Media|date=31 July 2013|work=Oettinger Media|language=German|accessdate=1 August 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180305221340/https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=527883073927456&set=a.157206940995073.30483.156008124448288&type=1&relevant_count=1|archivedate=5 March 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Meyer-Landrut re-united with her Eurovision mentor Stefan Raab in October 2013 when she was featured on "Revolution", a single released by Raab's band Dicks on Fire.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiwibloggs.com/2013/10/15/revolution-lyrics-dicks-on-fire-lena-stefan-raab/32791/|title=Lena Collaborates with Dicks on Fire for New Single "Revolution"|date=15 October 2013|work=wiwibloggs.com|accessdate=15 October 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131015160259/http://wiwibloggs.com/2013/10/15/revolution-lyrics-dicks-on-fire-lena-stefan-raab/32791/|archivedate=15 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In June 2013, this song was used for a video promoting the Doosh shower head Doosh, invented by Stefan Raab. In it Lena poses as [[Lara Croft]] in the shower. In 2013 she became a [[L'Oréal]] [[hair coloring]] and skin care products [[brand ambassador]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.brainpool.de/en/Marketing/Brands-Testimonials/Testimonials |title=Brainpool: Marketing / Brands & Testimonials /Testimonials |website=brainpool.de |access-date=5 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170127165503/http://www.brainpool.de/en/Marketing/Brands-Testimonials/Testimonials |archivedate=27 January 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
=== 2014–2015: ''Crystal Sky'' ===
From March to May 2014 she returned as coach for the second season of ''[[The Voice Kids (German TV series)|The Voice Kids]]'' along with Henning Wehland (from the band [[Söhne Mannheims]]) and Johannes Strate (from the band [[Revolverheld]]).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.prosiebensat1puls4.com/download/angebote/38/38.pdf|title=The Voice Kids|work=[[ProSiebenSat.1 Media]]|accessdate=13 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bz-berlin.de/thema/voice-of-germany/strate-ersetzt-bendzko-in-der-neuen-staffel-article1788173.html|title=Strate ersetzt Bendzko in der neuen Staffel|last=Steck|first=Melanie|date=12 January 2014|work=Berliner Zeitung|accessdate=12 January 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140113022229/http://www.bz-berlin.de/thema/voice-of-germany/strate-ersetzt-bendzko-in-der-neuen-staffel-article1788173.html|archivedate=13 January 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Meyer-Landrut began principal work on her fourth studio album ''[[Crystal Sky]]'' in 2014. Taking her sound further into the [[electro pop|electro]] and [[dance pop]] genre, she worked with the English production and songwriting team [[Biffco]], and the Berlin-based collective Beatgees on most of the album.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ampya.com/news/Aktuell/Lena-Meyer-Landrut-tueftelt-an-neuem-Album-SN105169/ |title=Lena Meyer-Landrut tüftelt an neuem Album |work=Ampya |accessdate=12 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140113040650/http://www.ampya.com/news/Aktuell/Lena-Meyer-Landrut-tueftelt-an-neuem-Album-SN105169/ |archivedate=13 January 2014 |df= }}</ref> In November 2014, one of their collaborations, the children's song "Schlaft alle" (Sleep all), appeared on the compilation album ''Giraffenaffen 3''.<ref name="Giraff"/> The same month, Meyer-Landrut's rendition of the [[Aladdin (1992 Disney film)|Aladdin]] song "[[A Whole New World]]" was included on the compilation album ''I Love Disney''.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.amazon.de/I-Love-Disney-Various/dp/B00P1W44EA |title=I Love Disney |website=amazon.de |access-date=5 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160414144701/http://www.amazon.de/I-Love-Disney-Various/dp/B00P1W44EA |archivedate=14 April 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
From February to April 2015 Meyer-Landrut reprised her role as a coach on the third season of ''[[The Voice Kids (German TV series)|The Voice Kids]]''<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://sfglobe.com/2015/06/23/13-year-old-sings-time-to-say-goodbye-at-the-voice-kids---germany/ |title=13 Year-Old Sings 'Time To Say Goodbye' At 'The Voice Kids - Germany' |website=sfglobe.com |access-date=5 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170811052921/http://sfglobe.com/2015/06/23/13-year-old-sings-time-to-say-goodbye-at-the-voice-kids---germany |archivedate=11 August 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> along with singers Johannes Strate and Mark Forster. After four press concerts in Hamburg, Berlin, Munich, and Cologne from late February to early March 2015 she released ''Crystal Sky{{'}}''s first single "[[Traffic Lights (Lena Meyer-Landrut song)|Traffic Lights]]" to radio in March 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lena: "Crystal Sky" - neues Album erscheint im Mai|work=Universal International Division|date=9 January 2015|url=http://www.presseportal.de/pm/58621/2922384/lena-crystal-sky-neues-album-erscheint-im-mai|accessdate=9 January 2015|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150109231254/http://www.presseportal.de/pm/58621/2922384/lena-crystal-sky-neues-album-erscheint-im-mai|archivedate=9 January 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It reached the top twenty of the [[German Singles Chart]].
''Crystal Sky'' was released in May 2015. It marked her fourth consecutive album to reach the top two of the [[German Albums Chart]]. But it was less successful in Austria and Switzerland, where it failed to reach the top twenty on both music markets' charts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tonight.de/duesseldorf/news/musik/crystal-sky-neues-album-von-lena-meyer-landrut.989631|title="Crystal Sky": Neues Album von Lena Meyer-Landrut|author=Marlena Schönfeld|work=www.tonight.de|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150927210709/http://www.tonight.de/duesseldorf/news/musik/crystal-sky-neues-album-von-lena-meyer-landrut.989631|archivedate=27 September 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In September 2015, Meyer-Landrut released "[[Wild & Free (Lena Meyer-Landrut song)|Wild & Free]]", the theme song for the motion picture ''[[Fack ju Göhte 2]]'' as a single.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.universal-music.de/fack-ju-goehte/videos/wild-and-free-380127 |title=Wild & Free |website=universal-music.de |access-date=5 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180305221341/https://www.universal-music.de/fack-ju-goehte/videos/wild-and-free-380127 |archivedate=5 March 2018 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The song peaked at number eight on the German Singles Chart, becoming her highest-charting single in three years.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/artist/Lena/?type=single |title=Lena (Lena Meyer-Landrut, * 1991) |website=musicline.de |access-date=5 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160513170557/http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/artist/Lena/?type=single |archivedate=13 May 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
=== 2016–present: ''Only Love, L'' and ''Sing meinen Song'' === In December 2016, Meyer-Landrut revealed on her Twitter account her forthcoming fifth studio album would be called ''Gemini'' and that she had already began working on it.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/lenas_view/status/807238288125947904?lang=de |title=Archived copy |accessdate=3 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180305221341/https://twitter.com/lenas_view/status/807238288125947904?lang=de |archivedate=5 March 2018 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In April 2017, Meyer-Landrut released a new song called "[[Lost in You (Lena Meyer-Landrut song)|Lost in You]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=Süße Liebeserklärung an Freund Max|url=http://www.gala.de/stars/news/lena-meyer-landrut--suesse-liebeserklaerung-an-freund-max-21348938.html|publisher=''[[Gala (magazine)|Gala]]''|accessdate=16 April 2017|language=German|date=16 April 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170416222313/http://www.gala.de/stars/news/lena-meyer-landrut--suesse-liebeserklaerung-an-freund-max-21348938.html|archivedate=16 April 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It was released on 14 April,<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://itunes.apple.com/de/album/lost-in-you-single/id1225730291 |title=Lost In You - Single |website=itunes.apple.com |access-date=5 March 2018}}</ref> and reached number 58 on the [[GfK Entertainment Charts]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.offiziellecharts.de/titel-details-1653058 |title=Lena - Lost in You |website=offiziellecharts.de |access-date=5 March 2018}}</ref> In November 2017 Meyer-Landrut stated via YouTube that she scrapped the album, because she was not happy with it. <ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5Di8782C1d4</ref>
Meyer-Landrut participated in the fourth season of the German TV show ''[[Sing meinen Song - Das Tauschkonzert]]'' (Sing My Song – The Exchange Concert).<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.vox.de/cms/sing-meinen-song-2017-das-ist-lena-meyer-landrut-4105107.html |title=Sing meinen Song 2017: Das ist Lena Meyer-Landrut |website=vox.de |access-date=5 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170806221120/http://www.vox.de/cms/sing-meinen-song-2017-das-ist-lena-meyer-landrut-4105107.html |archivedate=6 August 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In the third episode on 6 June, when the other artists performed Lena's songs, she premiered a new song "[[If I Wasn't Your Daughter]]".<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.vox.de/cms/sing-meinen-song-2017-lena-meyer-landrut-spricht-zum-ersten-mal-ueber-ihren-vater-4116292.html |title=Sing meinen Song 2017: Lena Meyer-Landrut spricht zum ersten Mal über ihren Vater |website=vox.de |access-date=5 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170812223012/http://www.vox.de/cms/sing-meinen-song-2017-lena-meyer-landrut-spricht-zum-ersten-mal-ueber-ihren-vater-4116292.html |archivedate=12 August 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> German press instantly discussed the song's content, which refers to Lena's relationship with her father who left the family when she was two. She has had no contact with him for more than twenty years.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www1.wdr.de/mediathek/audio/wdr4/wdr4-zur-sache/audio-lena-meyer-landrut--botschaft-an-den-verlorenen-vater-100.html |title=Lena Meyer-Landrut – Botschaft an den verlorenen Vater |website=wdr.de |access-date=5 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170905101024/http://www1.wdr.de/mediathek/audio/wdr4/wdr4-zur-sache/audio-lena-meyer-landrut--botschaft-an-den-verlorenen-vater-100.html |archivedate=5 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www1.wdr.de/mediathek/audio/wdr4/wdr4-zur-sache/audio-lena-meyer-landrut--botschaft-an-den-verlorenen-vater-100.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=8 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170611081643/http://www1.wdr.de/mediathek/audio/wdr4/wdr4-zur-sache/audio-lena-meyer-landrut--botschaft-an-den-verlorenen-vater-100.html |archivedate=11 June 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The song peaked at number 35 on the German charts.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.offiziellecharts.de/titel-details-1666847 |title=If I Wasn't Your Daughter |website=offiziellecharts.de |access-date=5 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180305221341/https://www.offiziellecharts.de/titel-details-1666847 |archivedate=5 March 2018 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In August 2017, Lena collaborated with the [[German hip hop]] group [[Genetikk]] where they recorded the single ''Lang lebe die Gang''. It was her second single with German lyrics after her cover version of ''Durch die Nacht'' by [[Silbermond]] from the television show Sing meinen Song in May 2017. In June 2018, she collaborated with [[Topic (DJ)|DJ Topic]] and Spanish super star [[Juan Magán]] at the single ''Sólo Contigo''.
In October 2018 it was revealed, that Lena will return as coach for ''[[The Voice Kids (German TV series)|The Voice Kids]]'' 2019.
In November 2018, Lena released her first single ''Thank You'' from her upcoming fifth studio album ''Only Love, L''. The album will be released on 5 April 2019.<ref>https://itunes.apple.com/de/album/only-love-l/1441313689</ref>
== Media image == Meyer-Landrut has been noted for her unconventional way of handling the press,<ref name="HAZ Umgang mit Medien">{{cite web|last=Sedelies|first=Jan|title=Lenas Umgang mit den Medien kommt nicht bei allen gut an|work=[[Hannoversche Allgemeine Zeitung]]|date=25 May 2010|url=http://www.haz.de/Hannover/Aus-der-Stadt/Lena-Ein-Star-fuer-Oslo-aus-Hannover/Lenas-Umgang-mit-den-Medien-kommt-nicht-bei-allen-gut-an|accessdate=8 June 2010|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528170835/http://www.haz.de/Hannover/Aus-der-Stadt/Lena-Ein-Star-fuer-Oslo-aus-Hannover/Lenas-Umgang-mit-den-Medien-kommt-nicht-bei-allen-gut-an|archivedate=28 May 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> which has been labelled "aloof" as well as "quick-witted" and "intuitive".<ref name="HAZ Umgang mit Medien"/> She usually refuses to answer questions about her private life, including her family, friends and personal beliefs, sometimes calling questions "stupid" or responding with counterquestions instead.<ref name="HAZ Umgang mit Medien" /> This has drawn praise as well as criticism, including allegations of being arrogant<ref name="Vienna.at Lena arrogant">{{cite web|title=Lena ist "zickig und arrogant"|work=vienna.at|date=31 May 2010|url=http://www.vienna.at/society/promis/artikel/lena-ist-zickig-und-arrogant/cn/news-20100531-10295178|accessdate=8 June 2010|language=German}}</ref> and disrespectful.<ref name="RP Lena bei Elstner">{{cite web|title=Respektlos oder ehrlich? Lenas Auftritt bei Frank Elstner|work=rp-online.de|date=12 May 2011|url=http://www.rp-online.de/region-duesseldorf/duesseldorf/nachrichten/song-contest/lenas-auftritt-bei-frank-elstner-1.1282820|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120829063827/http://www.rp-online.de/region-duesseldorf/duesseldorf/nachrichten/song-contest/lenas-auftritt-bei-frank-elstner-1.1282820|archivedate=29 August 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Meyer-Landrut's demeanour has been described as "carefree",<ref name="taz Junge Frau in Oslo">{{cite web|last=Feddersen|first=Jan|title=Junge Frau in Oslo, unbekümmert|work=[[Die Tageszeitung]]|date=28 May 2010|url=http://www.taz.de/1/leben/musik/artikel/1/junge-frau-in-oslo-unbekuemmert/|accessdate=8 June 2010|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100531170656/http://taz.de/1/leben/musik/artikel/1/junge-frau-in-oslo-unbekuemmert|archivedate=31 May 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and "laid-back and self-effacing".<ref name="msnbc Singing sensation">{{cite web|last=Eckardt |first=Andy |title=Singing sensation helps Germans shed 'dull' image |work=[[MSNBC]] |date=31 May 2010 |url=http://worldblog.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2010/05/31/4442515-singing-sensation-helps-germans-shed-dull-image |accessdate=8 June 2010 |language=German |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100603030105/http://worldblog.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2010/05/31/4442515-singing-sensation-helps-germans-shed-dull-image |archivedate=3 June 2010 |df= }}</ref> She has been said to possess an "adequate youthful megalomania," to "cultivate her forwardness" and to stand for "unadorned genuineness"<ref name="taz Junge Frau in Oslo" /> and "sincerity".<ref name="RP Lena bei Elstner" /> She has also been described as giving "infatuation a rhythm" and blurring the "fine line between puppy love and psychotic obsession" in her song "Satellite".<ref name="Huffington Post">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/will-adams/germanys-eurovision-2010_b_560260.html|title=Germany's Eurovision 2010 Song: 'Satellite' by Lena Meyer-Landrut|first=Will|last=Adams|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=4 May 2010|accessdate=8 June 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100521121825/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/will-adams/germanys-eurovision-2010_b_560260.html|archivedate=21 May 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Her vocals have been both praised<ref name="T-Online">{{cite web|url=http://unterhaltung.t-online.de/kritik-an-lena-meyer-landrut-das-lied-wird-wieder-unter-die-letzten-kommen-/id_41151050/index|title=Das Lied wird wieder unter die letzten kommen|work=[[T-Online]]|date=26 March 2010|accessdate=8 June 2010|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100401081341/http://unterhaltung.t-online.de/kritik-an-lena-meyer-landrut-das-lied-wird-wieder-unter-die-letzten-kommen-/id_41151050/index|archivedate=1 April 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and criticised.<ref name="T-Online" /> In an attempt to explain Meyer-Landrut's success, her appearance has been called a "mix of loveliness, professionalism and a little craziness".<ref name="Süddeutsche Ein bisschen Wahnsinn">{{cite web|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/medien/eurovision-song-contest-lena-meyer-landrut-ein-bisschen-wahnsinn-1.951761|title=Lena Meyer-Landrut: Ein bisschen Wahnsinn|first=Hans|last=Hoff|work=[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]]|date=30 May 2010|accessdate=8 June 2010|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100609022637/http://www.sueddeutsche.de/medien/eurovision-song-contest-lena-meyer-landrut-ein-bisschen-wahnsinn-1.951761|archivedate=9 June 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> She has also been lauded for her stage presence<ref name="Süddeutsche Ein bisschen Wahnsinn" /> and charisma.<ref name="SWR3 Biographie">{{cite web|title=SWR3 Poplexikon: Biographie: Lena|work=[[Südwestrundfunk|SWR]]|date=31 January 2012|url=http://www.swr3.de/musik/poplexikon/Lena/-/id=927882/did=729550/1npj6bh/index.html|accessdate=22 July 2012|language=German|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121120102343/http://www.swr3.de/musik/poplexikon/Lena/-/id=927882/did=729550/1npj6bh/index.html|archivedate=20 November 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox video game | title = ''Liberation 71'' | image =Liberation '71.jpg | caption = | developer = Team 71 | publisher =Khelo Bangladesh | engine = [[Unreal Engine 4]] | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]] | released = | genre = [[First person shooter]], [[war]], [[adventure game|adventure]] | modes = [[Single-player]], [[multiplayer]] | director = Farhad Rakib | producer = Faysal Ahmed | designer = '''Graphics Designers'''
Syed Muzakkir Faiyaz, Mainul Hossain Noman, Ahmed Hasan Baky | programmer= Saud Al Abedin,
Sakhawat Hossain, Ehsanur Rahman Rhythm | composer = }} '''Update (10/12/2017):''' Game developments have been '''suspended''' by devs due to lack of budget and is no longer being developed. There's no official info about how much of the game was developed. '''''Liberation 71''''' is a [[first person shooter]] video game based on the 1971 Bangladesh Liberation War.{{cite web|url=http://www.samakal.net/2014/03/27/48602|title=আসছে মুক্তিযুদ্ধের গেম 'লিবারেশন ৭১' - প্রযুক্তি প্রতিদিন - Samakal Online Version|work=samakal.net}} The game is being developed by a group of young developers named "Team 71".{{cite web|last1=Islam|first1=Muhammad Zahidul|title=Games and app launched marking Independence Day|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/sci-tech/2014/mar/28/games-and-app-launched-marking-independence-day|website=dhakatribune.com|publisher=Dhaka Tribune|accessdate=6 July 2015}} The objective is to fight against the [[Pakistan Army]] in the 1971 [[Bangladesh Liberation war]] as a [[Mukti Bahini]].{{cite web|last1=Prothom Alo Desk|title=HomeScience & Tech Computer game "Liberation 71"|url=http://en.prothom-alo.com/science-technology/news/45869/Computer-game-on-Liberation-71|website=en.prothom-alo.com|publisher=Prothom Alo|accessdate=6 July 2015}} Some young people got the idea of developing this game through communicating on the social network website [[Facebook]].{{cite web|url=http://www.kalerkantho.com/print-edition/news/2014/03/27/66100|title=কম্পিউটার গেম 'লিবারেশন ৭১' - খবর - কালের কণ্ঠ|work=কালের কণ্ঠ}} They published the alpha version of the game on 25 March 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailysangbad.com/index_arch.php?view=details&type=gold&data=Tax&pub_no=1718&menu_id=28&news_type_id=1&val=159338|title=দৈনিক সংবাদ|work=thedailysangbad.com}} The full version of ''Liberation 71'' is yet to be released. [[Unreal Engine|Unreal 4]] is being used to develop the game.[http://observerbd.com/details.php?id=10674 Computer game Liberation-71 Bangladesh Liberation War in international market] The story of the game is supplementing the rotation of the 1971 Bangladesh Liberation War. It will be developed following the appropriate events and actual stories of the war.{{cite web|url=http://dutimz.com/?p=3570|title=মুক্তিযুদ্ধ ভিত্তিক কম্পিউটার গেম 'লিবারেশন '৭১' রিলিজ পেল, ডেভেলপার ঢাবির দুই ছাত্র|author=editor dutimz|work=DUTIMZ.COM}} It also includes the seven greatest freedom fighters in (Birshreshtha) history, Rajarbag Police Resistance and Operation jackpot.[http://techalarmbd.com/গেইমস/alarm-id/4842/ মুক্তিযুদ্ধের প্রেক্ষাপটে কম্পিউটার গেম ,লিবারেশন ৭১ | টেকএলার্মবিডি।সবচেয়ে বড় বাংলা টিউটোরিয়াল এবং ব্লগ]{{cite web|url=http://techshohor.com/news/9422|title=স্মার্টফোন এক্সপোর বাড়তি আকর্ষণ 'লিবারেশন ৭১'|work=টেক শহর}} ==See also== {{Portal|Bangladesh|Bangladesh Liberation War|Video games}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Video games developed in Bangladesh]] [[Category:Video games set in Bangladesh]] [[Category:Aftermath of the Bangladesh Liberation War]] [[Category:Upcoming video games]] [[Category:War video games]] [[Category:War video games set in Asia]] [[Category:Bangladesh Liberation War games]]

revision.text:
[[File:Cincinnati Riots 1884 Courthouse after riot.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Hamilton County, Ohio|Hamilton County]] Courthouse, Cincinnati, after the 1884 riots]] There has been a long history of '''rioting in [[Cincinnati]]''', [[Ohio]], United States, since the city was founded in 1788. Some riots were fueled by racial tension, while others by issues such as employment conditions and political justice.<ref name=Kiesewetter2001/>
==1792==
The first riot recorded in Cincinnati was in 1792, after a merchant named John Bartle was beaten by a soldier. Fifty people were involved in the fighting.<ref name=Kiesewetter2001/> The riot between settlers and soldiers occurred when spring flooding had driven many people out of their cabins.<ref name=Hurt1998/>
==1829== {{Main article|Cincinnati riots of 1829}} By 1829, African Americans numbered almost 10% of the city's population. In the [[Cincinnati Riots of 1829]], about 1,000 of them were driven out of the town by violent mobs. Some of the displaced people moved north to settle in Canada.<ref name=Kiesewetter2001/> After the 1829 riots, a growing number of whites became sympathetic to the rights of Negroes, as they were called then.<ref name=Rodriguez2007/>
==1836== [[File:James G. Birney.jpg|thumb|[[James G. Birney]], [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionist]] publisher whose press was twice destroyed during the 1836 riots.]] {{Main article|Cincinnati riots of 1836}} The [[Cincinnati Riots of 1836]] were caused by racial tensions at a time when African Americans, some of whom had escaped from slavery in the southern states of the United States, were competing with whites for jobs. The riots occurred in April and July.<ref name=Brown1975/> The rioters attacked both Negroes and the whites who supported them.<ref name=Rodriguez2007/> A former slave owner from [[Alabama]], [[James Gillespie Birney]], had become an abolitionist. In January 1836 he set up the ''Cincinnati Weekly and Abolitionist'', a newspaper sponsored by the Ohio Anti-Slavery Society.<ref name=Bryant1994/> The newspaper targeted slaveholders across the [[Ohio River]] in [[Kentucky]] with anti-slavery propaganda. This angered local businessmen who were keen to do business with the southern states.<ref name=Aaron1992/> A riot broke out in April in which buildings were burned and several blacks lost their lives. The riot was only brought under control when the governor intervened and declared martial law.<ref name=Trotter1998/> In July, the press that printed Birney's newspaper was twice destroyed, and further damage was caused to Negro properties.<ref name=Stowe1890/>
==1841== {{Main article|Cincinnati riots of 1841}} In the [[Cincinnati riots of 1841]], a mob of white men met in the Fifth Street Market and marched on "Little Africa", or "Buck Town"an area along the riverfront that was mainly inhabited by African Americans. The African Americans were armed and ready. Whites secured a cannon, rolled it down sixth street, faced it toward Buck Town, the name of the area where African American's resided, and fired it, lives were lost. Martial law was declared, 300 black men were arrested. While they were in custody, many of their homes were attacked.<ref name=Cayton2002/>
==1853== {{Main article|Cincinnati riot of 1853}}
The [[Cincinnati Riot of 1853]] broke out on 25 December 1853. An armed mob of about 500 German men with 100 women following marched on the home of Bishop John Purcell, protesting a visit by Cardinal [[Gaetano Bedini]], the emissary of Pope [[Pius IX]]. The Germans, many of whom had been involved in the European [[revolutions of 1848]], or whose families had been involved, identified Bedini with the forces of reaction and oppression. One protester was killed and over 60 were arrested.<ref name=Connelly1960/>
==1855== {{main article|Cincinnati riots of 1855}} The [[Cincinnati riots of 1855]] were clashes between "[[nativists]]" and [[German-Americans]]. The nativists supported J.D. Taylor, the mayoral candidate for the anti-immigrant American Party, also known as the [[Know-Nothing Party]]. German-Americans erected barricades in the streets leading into their [[Over-the-Rhine]] neighborhood, and fired a cannon over the heads of a mob of nativists attacking them.<ref name=Kiesewetter2001/>
==1884== [[File:Cincinnati Riots 1884 Barricade on Court Street.jpg|thumb|A hastily built barricade on Court Street, in 1884]] {{Main article|Cincinnati riots of 1884}}
The [[Cincinnati riots of 1884]], also known as the Cincinnati Courthouse riots, were the most violent in the history of the city. They were caused by public outrage over the decision of a jury to return a verdict of manslaughter in a perceived clear case of murder. A mob in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]], United States attempted to find and lynch the man. In the violence that followed over the next few days, over 50 people died and the courthouse and jail were destroyed.<ref name=OhioHistorySociety/>
==1935==
In 1935 a fight between the students at Oyler School in Price Hill, one black and one white, quickly escalated. Police were forced to block the Eighth Street viaduct to separate groups of angry whites and blacks. During the riot, sixteen people were arrested.<ref name=SafePassage/>
==1967==
The [[Avondale, Cincinnati#Riots of 1967|Avondale riot of 1967]] followed years of police abuse and deteriorating living conditions in the poor black community of [[Avondale, Cincinnati|Avondale]].<ref name=White2001/> The riots followed the disputed June 1967 conviction of Posteal Laskey Jr., accused of being the [[Cincinnati Strangler]].<ref name=Hall1998/> The riots were ignited when Laskey's cousin, who was protesting the conviction, was arrested for loitering near the Abraham Lincoln statue at Rockdale Avenue and Reading Road on 12 June 1967.<ref name=White2001/> Crowds filled the streets and threw bottles and firebombs at businesses.<ref name=Hall1998/> The [[Ohio National Guard]] was called in to restore order. One person died and there were 404 arrests. In 1968, President [[Lyndon Johnson]]'s Commission on Civil Disorders issued a report that blamed the riots on the poverty of the segregated neighborhoods in Cincinnati and the practice of police officers in "stopping Negroes on foot or in cars without obvious basis" and using loitering laws disproportionately against minorities.<ref name=White2001/>
==1968==
The [[Avondale, Cincinnati#Riots of 1968|Avondale riot of 1968]] broke out in Avondale after the assassination of [[Martin Luther King Jr.]], a civil rights leader, in April 1968. A mob smashed store windows and looted the stores or burned the merchandise.<ref name=Hall1998/> The Ohio National Guard was called to restore peace in [[Avondale, Cincinnati|Avondale]]. Two people were killed, at least 220 injured and 260 arrested during two nights of violence.<ref name=Kiesewetter2001/>
==2001==
{{Main article|2001 Cincinnati riots}}
The [[2001 Cincinnati riots]] were the largest urban disorders in the United States since the [[Los Angeles riots of 1992]]. Three days of rioting were triggered by a fatal police shooting of an unarmed African-American teenager, Timothy Thomas.<ref name=MacDonald2001/> On the third night of violence, looting, and vandalizing, [[Charlie Luken]], the mayor of Cincinnati at the time, issued a citywide curfew which happened to be accompanied by rain, and the riots stopped. The curfew was for all of Cincinnati, but was generally only enforced in the downtown area. There were no reports of rioting from the 13th or later. The immediate crisis had ended but the immediate damage was estimated at $3.6 million. Many business in the downtown area were damaged in the riots. Many of 63 rioters were indicted on felony charges.<ref name=McCain21042001/>
==References== {{reflist|1|refs= <ref name=Aaron1992>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eCgVN3FKOxQC&pg=PA300 |page=300ff |title=Cincinnati, Queen City of the West: 1819-1838 |author=Daniel Aaron |publisher=Ohio State University Press |year=1992 |ISBN=0-8142-0570-4 |accessdate=2010-10-24}}</ref> <ref name=Brown1975>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vW79dBtockMC&pg=PA335 |page=335 |title=Strain of violence: historical studies of American violence and vigilantism |author=Richard Maxwell Brown |publisher=Oxford University Press US |year=1975 |ISBN=0-19-501943-1 |accessdate=2010-10-24}}</ref> <ref name=Bryant1994>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BxtzuLA0RrQC&pg=PA49 |page=49 |chapter=The Cincinnati Mob: August 10, 1836 |title=Power for sanity: selected editorials of William Cullen Bryant, 1829-1861 |author=William Cullen Bryant |publisher=Fordham Univ Press |year=1994 |ISBN=0-8232-1544-X |accessdate=2010-10-24}}</ref> <ref name=Cayton2002>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tC9d4JVvefIC&pg=PA26 |page=26 |title=Ohio: the history of a people |author=Andrew Robert Lee Cayton |publisher=Ohio State University Press |year=2002 |ISBN=0-8142-0899-1}}</ref> <ref name=Connelly1960>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tMujE27nNvcC&pg=PA96 |page=96ff |title=The visit of Archbishop Gaetano Bedini to the United States of America: June 1853-February 1854 |author=James F. Connelly |publisher=Editrice Pontificia Università Gregoriana |year=1960 |ISBN=88-7652-082-1}}</ref> <ref name=Hall1998>{{cite web |url=http://homefinder.cincinnati.com/closetohome/cth_avondale_030298.html |title=Area working to rise above crime, riots |author=SHERI HALL |work=The Cincinnati Enquirer |date=March 2, 1998 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708154051/http://homefinder.cincinnati.com/closetohome/cth_avondale_030298.html |archivedate=2011-07-08 |df= }}</ref> <ref name=Hurt1998>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=obkP_1V-fyYC&pg=PA188 |page=188 |title=The Ohio Frontier: Crucible of the Old Northwest, 1720--1830 |author=R. Douglas Hurt |publisher=Indiana University Press |year=1998 |ISBN=0-253-21212-X}}</ref> <ref name=Kiesewetter2001>{{cite web |url=http://www.enquirer.com/editions/2001/07/15/tem_civil_unrest_woven.html |date=July 15, 2001 |title=Civil unrest woven into city's history |author=John Kiesewetter |work=[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]] |accessdate=2010-10-24}}</ref> <ref name=MacDonald2001>{{cite web |url=http://www.city-journal.org/html/11_3_what_really_happened.html |title=What Really Happened in Cincinnati |author=Heather MacDonald |work=City Journal |date=Summer 2001}}</ref> <ref name=McCain21042001>{{cite web |author=McCain, Marie. |title=Grand jury indicts 63 in looting, violence |work=The Cincinnati Enquirer |date=21 April 2001 |accessdate=2010-10-30 |url=http://www.enquirer.com/editions/2001/04/21/loc_1grand_jury_indicts.html}}</ref> <ref name=OhioHistorySociety>{{cite web |url=http://www.ohiohistorycentral.org/entry.php?rec=488 |title=Cincinnati Courthouse Riot |work=Ohio History Central |publisher=Ohio Historical Society |accessdate=2010-10-23}}</ref> <ref name=Rodriguez2007>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g_kuS42BxIYC&pg=PA119 |page=119 |title=Encyclopedia of slave resistance and rebellion, Volume 1 |chapter=Cincinnati, Ohio, Race Riot (1829) |author=Junius P. Rodriguez |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |year=2007 |ISBN=0-313-33272-X |accessdate=2010-10-24}}</ref> <ref name=SafePassage>{{cite web |url=http://www.safepassageohio.org/civilrights/timeline.asp |title=Timeline of Civil Rights Conflict in SW Ohio |work=Safe Passage |accessdate=2010-10-24}}</ref> <ref name=Stowe1890>{{cite book |url=http://utc.iath.virginia.edu/abolitn/abauhbsat.html |title=Life of Harriet Beecher Stowe |editor=Charles Edward Stowe |location=Boston |publisher=Houghton, Mifflin and Company |year=1890 |chapter=IV: Slavery Riots in Cincinnati |accessdate=2010-10-24}}</ref> <ref name=Trotter1998>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iZiE33RZKcIC&pg=PA35 |page=35 |title=River Jordan: African American urban life in the Ohio Valley |author=Joe William Trotter |publisher=University Press of Kentucky |year=1998 |ISBN=0-8131-0950-7 |accessdate=2010-10-24}}</ref> <ref name=White2001>{{cite web |url=http://www.wsws.org/articles/2001/may2001/cin1-m24.shtml |title=The Cincinnati riots and the class divide in America. Part 1: gentrification and police repression |author=Jerry White |date=24 May 2001 |work=World Socialist Web Site |publisher=International Committee of the Fourth International}}</ref> }}
